headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sally, and I will your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Clayton Reasor, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations, Strategy, Corporate and Government Affairs. Please go ahead, Mr. Reasor.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sally. Welcome to Phillips 66's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and CEO, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor, and Chief Financial Officer, Tim Taylor. The presentation material we'll be using during the call
componenttext:
Thank you, Sally. Welcome to Phillips 66's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and CEO, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor, and Chief Financial Officer, Tim Taylor. The presentation material we'll be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website along with supplemental financial and operating information.
Slide 2 contains our safe harbor statement. It's a reminder that we'll be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from today's comments. And factors that could cause these changes are these actual results to differ are included on the second page as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
So with that said, I'll turn the call over to Greg for some opening remarks.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Clayton. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We had a good year in 2015. Adjusted earnings were $4.2 billion, which is our highest since 2012. We generated $5.7 billion in cash from operations. This allowed us to maintain a stro
componenttext:
Thanks, Clayton. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. 
We had a good year in 2015. Adjusted earnings were $4.2 billion, which is our highest since 2012. We generated $5.7 billion in cash from operations. This allowed us to maintain a strong balance sheet and financial flexibility while funding our capital program and returning $2.7 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
We made significant progress on our growth projects in Midstream and Chemicals, and we continued to improve returns in our Refining and Marketing businesses. Despite the difficult environment experienced throughout the energy industry, our diversified asset portfolio has performed well. 
We continue to execute our plan. For us, it all starts with operating excellence. We spent $1.2 billion in sustaining capital in 2015. And from an operating reliability perspective, our businesses ran well. 
2015 was a very safe year for us. We tied our best year ever for recordable injuries. At Refining, Chemicals and Midstream were top performers in injury rates.  We also maintained the improvement in our environmental performance demonstrated in previous years. 
We ended 2015 with a solid quarter, especially when considering the current commodity price environment. Adjusted earnings were $710 million or $1.31 per share. Market cracks were down significantly in the fourth quarter from the highs that we saw last summer, but our global Refining business continue to run well with 94% utilization. Marketing earnings were healthy, and this continues to be a high-return business for us. 2015 adjusted return on capital employed was 35% for this segment.  In Midstream, we commenced operations of the Sweeny Fractionator One and supporting Clements Storage Caverns. 
2016 will be another busy year for us with several other Midstream projects scheduled for completion. Our Freeport LNG export terminal is now 80% complete. It's on track, on budget with an expected start-up in the fourth quarter of 2016. access and the pipeline projects also continue to make good progress and remain on schedule for completion by the end of this year.
Our master limited partnership, Phillips 66 Partners, remains an important part of our midstream growth strategy. The fee-based assets with PSXP's folder continued to perform well and are not impacted by the current market conditions. PSXP continues on track to achieve its stated growth objective of a 5-year 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
Adjusted EBITDA was up nearly 90% for the year at PSXP, while distribution growth and coverage were also strong. In addition, PSXP was able to raise $1.5 billion of low-cost capital through the debt and equity capital markets in 2015.
PSX continues to work on reducing costs and converting contracts to fee-based structures to improve its financial strength and flexibility. The equity contributions from the owners in the fourth quarter helped in that regard. We expect that DCP will be self-funded going forward.
In Chemicals, cash margins fell during the fourth quarter. However, they remain strong by historical standards. CPChem's geographically advantaged footprint allows it to remain profitable and able to self-fund its growth projects. Development continues on CPChem U.S. Gulf Coast petrochemicals projects, which will increase CPChem's U.S. ethylene and polyethylene capacity by over 40%. Overall goal progress on the project is approaching 70% complete with start-up planned in mid-2017. This project remains on time and on budget. 
We had another strong cash flow quarter. We generated $1.5 billion in cash from operations. We used $1 billion of that cash flow in capital spending to support Midstream growth and maintaining operating integrity and our Refining system. 
We also continue to return capital to our shareholders. During the fourth quarter, we returned over $700 million through dividends and share repurchases. Over the last 3 years, shareholder distributions have totaled more than $9 billion.
Looking forward to 2016, our focus remains on operating well and executing our $3.9 billion capital budget. We continue to target a 60-40 split between the investment and distributions, and we have targeted a dividend increase in 2016 of at least 10%. 
So now I'd like to turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to take us through the quarter's results.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg.  Good morning.  Starting on Slide 4, fourth quarter adjusted earnings were $710 million or $1.31 per share. Reported net income was $650 million, including several special items excluded from our adjusted earnings. The special items decrea
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg.  
Good morning.  Starting on Slide 4, fourth quarter adjusted earnings were $710 million or $1.31 per share. Reported net income was $650 million, including several special items excluded from our adjusted earnings. The special items decreased earnings by $60 million and included $104 million in impairments at DCP and a $33 million lower of cost or market write-down of inventory at our Wood River joint venture, offset by an $88 million gain tied to favorable changes in German tax law. Excluding negative working capital changes of $300 million, cash from operations was $1.8 billion.  Capital spending for the quarter was $1 billion excluding the $1.5 billion contribution to DCP Midstream.  Dividends and share repurchases in the fourth quarter totaled $704 million. And excluding special items, our adjusted effective income tax rate was 31%. 
Slide 5 compares fourth quarter and third quarter adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were down $937 million. All segments had lower earnings, but Refining accounted for most of the reduction.
Next, we'll cover each of the segments. I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. Transportation benefited from higher equity earnings and volumes. In , Sweeny Fractionator One came online during December. Included in the transportation and NGL results is the contribution from Phillips 66 Partners. During the quarter, PSXP contributed earnings of $37 million to the Midstream segment and increased its quarterly LP distribution by 7% over the third quarter.  DCP Midstream continues to work on its self-help initiatives to reduce costs, manage its portfolio and restructure contracts.
2015 adjusted return on capital employed to the Midstream segment was 5% based on an average capital employed of $6.8 billion. The return for this segment continues to reflect the impact of increased capital employed, driven by our significant growth investments as well as the impact of lower commodity prices on DCP earnings.
Moving to Slide 7. Midstream's fourth quarter adjusted earnings were $42 million, down $49 million from the third quarter. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter was $78 million, up $1 million from the prior quarter. NGL adjusted losses were $2 million for the quarter. The $34 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by the timing of adjustments related to the tax extenders bill signed in December as well as additional costs associated with the Sweeny hub. Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were higher in the fourth quarter due to lower natural gas and natural gas liquids marketing margins as well as the impact of lower commodity prices.
In Chemicals, the global olefins and polyolefins capacity utilization rate for the quarter was 92% and margins trended lower. SA&S was negatively impacted by planned turnaround activity.  The 2015 adjusted return of capital employed for our Chemical segment was 19% based on an average capital employed of $4.9 billion. 
As shown on Slide 9, fourth quarter adjusted earnings for Chemicals were $182 million, down from $272 million in the third quarter. In olefins and polyolefins, the decrease of $80 million was largely due to lower cash margins. However, demand for polyethylene and normal olefins product remained healthy during the quarter. 
Adjusted earnings for SA&S declined to $9 million on lower equity earnings, driven by lower volumes due to turnaround activities at CPChem's equity affiliates and lower margins. This was partially offset by higher volumes in specialty chemicals.
In Refining, realized margins were $9.41 per barrel for the quarter as market crack spreads decreased significantly. Market capture increased from 72% to 74% in the fourth quarter as we saw improvement in clean product differentials and lower losses on secondary products. Refining crude utilization was 94%. clean product yield was 85%, representing a record quarter. 
Pretax turnaround costs were $130 million compared to guidance of approximately $150 million, due primarily to the deferral of some planned maintenance. 2015 adjusted return on capital employed for Refining was 19%. This is based on average capital employed of $13.6 billion. 
Slide 11 shows a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. The Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $376 million, down $676 million from last quarter. The reduction was probably due to lower market cracks in all regions. Atlantic Basin adjusted earnings were lower this quarter due to lower gasoline and distillate margins, partially offset by higher volumes as capacity utilization exceeded 100%.  The Gulf Coast region saw lower margins and had lower volumes due to downtime at Lake Charles and Sweeny. In the central corridor, market cracks dropped by more than $8 per barrel, which accounted for approximately 90% of the $251 reduction in adjusted earnings from the first quarter. In addition, Wood River and City also had downtime due to turnaround activity.
In the western region, grass cracks fell nearly $15 per barrel. Volumes and controllable costs were also impacted by a major turnaround of our L.A. refinery that we completed in the third quarter. Santa Maria continued to be impacted by the Plain pipeline outage. 
Next, we'll cover market capture on Slide 12. Our worldwide realized margin was $9.41 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack spread of $12.77 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 74%. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries as it relates to our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 85% clean product yields for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. 
Losses in secondary products were lower this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as coke and NGLs narrowed. Feedstock advantage was somewhat higher than the third quarter, but still below average as crude differentials generally remained tight. The other category, mainly includes costs associated with RINS, freight, product differentials and inventory impacts.
Let's move to marketing specialties where we posted a solid quarter thanks to favorable global marketing margins. However, specialties saw reduced earnings on lower lubricants margins. The 2015 adjusted return on capital employed for M&S was 35% on average capital employed of $2.7 billion. 
Slide 14 shows adjusted earnings for M&S in the fourth quarter of $227 million, down $117 million from the third quarter. In marketing in other, the $93 million decrease was largely due to lower volumes in both domestic and international marketing, which decreased from the high margins in the third quarter. This was partially offset by the renewal of biodiesel tax credits. Specialties adjusted earnings decreased to $29 million due to narrowing base oil and finished lubricants margins and lower finished lubricants volumes.
On Slide 15, the Corporate and Other segment had an after-tax net loss of $117 million this quarter, an increase of $5 million from the third quarter. Net interest expense increased by $4 million, primarily due to lower capitalized interest. Corporate overhead and other expenses were in line with the prior quarter.
On Slide 16, we summarized our financial results for the year. 2015 adjusted earnings were $4.2 billion or $7.67 per share. Excluding negative working capital changes of $200 million, cash from operations was $5.9 billion. Capital spending for the year was $4.3 billion excluding the $1.5 billion contribution to DCP Midstream. Total shareholder distributions were $2.7 billion. At the end of the fourth quarter, our adjusted debt-to-capital ratio excluding Phillips 66 Partners was 25%. And after taking into account our ending cash balance, our adjusted net debt-to-capital ratio was 17%. The adjusted return on capital employed for 2015 was 14%.
Moving to Slide 17. 2015 adjusted earnings were higher than 2014 as lower earnings from Midstream and Chemicals were more than offset by improvements from our Refining and Marketing and specialties businesses. We have an 11% increase in adjusted earnings, and adjusted earnings per share increased by $1.05 or 16%.
Slide 18 shows cash flow for 2015. We began the year with a cash balance of $5.2 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations was $5.9 billion. Working capital changes reduced cash flow by $200 million. In the first quarter, $1.1 billion in debt and approximately $400 million in equity was issued by PSXP. We also retired $800 million in Phillips 66 senior notes.
in 2015, we funded $5.8 billion of capital expenditures and investments. This is -- this included $4.3 billion of capital spend, including $3 billion in Midstream and $1.1 billion in Refining. We also distributed $2.7 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the year with 529 million shares outstanding. Excluding the DCP contribution, 61% of our available cash went to reinvestment and 39% to distributions. At the end of 2015, our cash balance was $3.1 billion.
This concludes my review of the financial and operating results. Next, I'll cover a few outlook items. 
For 2016, we expect full year turnaround expenses to be between $525 million and $575 million pretax. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $480 million to $500 million. And we expect full year D&A of about $1.2 billion.
In the first quarter Chemicals, we expect the global utilization rate to be in the mid-90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rates to also be in the mid-90s and pretax turnaround expense to be approximately $150 million.  In Corporate and Other court, we expect after-tax costs to be between $120 million and $125 million. And companywide, we expect the effective income tax rate to be in the mid-30s.
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

componenttext: Yes, we said at least 10%. we raised dividend 12% last year. I'd say we'll take a look at that, obviously if the board approved this too. we have given guidance 3 years ago that we'd do double-digit increases in '14, '15 and '16. We stand by that guidance.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at that, remember, we just came out of turnaround, good shape, good clean refinery. So I think it reflects that. And then at , we continued to run a lot of process inputs to fill out our downstream units in that facility. So it was really go
componenttext: When you look at that, remember, we just came out of turnaround, good shape, good clean refinery. So I think it reflects that. And then at , we continued to run a lot of process inputs to fill out our downstream units in that facility. So it was really good quarter, and I would anticipate that it's obvious the market conditions if we can continue run it as full as we can.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Paul Cheng with Barclays.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe -- this is for Greg. With the changing market condition related to the market acceptance for the funding model in the MLP sector, how is that going to impact your way of the dropdown that I think previously you've been looking, for maybe up to
componenttext: Just maybe -- this is for Greg. With the changing market condition related to the market acceptance for the funding model in the MLP sector, how is that going to impact your way of the dropdown that I think previously you've been looking, for maybe up to $2 billion a year? I don't know whether that you have changed. And also I mean from the CapEx that you spent $3.9 billion in dividend, about 1.3 with your cash flow from operations, you don't have much for the buyback. So should we assume that you can't do much of the dropdown, you correspondingly scale down your buyback, or that you're going to increase your balance sheet to maintain the buyback in a certain way?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me try to start with the question and I'll -- Certainly, we understand the question, Paul. As we look out there, there a lot of stress in the space with people that are overlevered and will have difficulty accessing the capital equity markets, give
componenttext: So let me try to start with the question and I'll -- Certainly, we understand the question, Paul. As we look out there, there a lot of stress in the space with people that are overlevered and will have difficulty accessing the capital equity markets, given their prohibitively high cost of capital. we look at PSXP, strong sponsorship, strong investment-grade rating. You might even call this the dropdown type. And great portfolio of existing EBITDA that can be dropped, we've got these projects lined up in the queue. That imply that with the add to that right and then you kind of look at where it PSXP is trading kind around 3%. So I think investors look at PSXP, they get the growth story. They understand the growth story. I think it's a confidence in our ability to execute that. And so we would say that we think the capital markets are going to be open to us in 2016, and our plan is to be out there in there. And you've got the number about right. We kind of said kind of $2 billion a year that we need to be through the capital markets and the debt markets. They hit this $1.1 billion of EBITDA in 2018 at the MLP. And so we stand by that guidance and we will stay there. We should be at $4 billion to $5 billion mid-cycle of cash. And you kind of add another $1.5 billion to $2 billion coming out of the MLP. So I think we're fine in terms of funding our capital program and in terms of funding or growing distributions through increasing our dividend. And we'll have, as long as our share stays even interesting value, we're going to take shares in.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second question, Greg, on DCP, I mean you guys have that capital restructuring with in the fourth quarter, but the market condition continue to deteriorate in that business. So is there the possibility that later this year, what does it do if there's any
componenttext: Second question, Greg, on DCP, I mean you guys have that capital restructuring with in the fourth quarter, but the market condition continue to deteriorate in that business. So is there the possibility that later this year, what does it do if there's any more debt being mature, do we need to do additional capital infusion to that? Or that you're confident that you already fixed the problem at this point?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the contributions by both and ourselves have gone a long way to fixing the balance sheet issues at DCP. The other thing for me, you got to give the folks a lot of credit. They've done a great job of pulling costs out, restructuring cont
componenttext: Well, I think that the contributions by both and ourselves have gone a long way to fixing the balance sheet issues at DCP. The other thing for me, you got to give the folks a lot of credit. They've done a great job of pulling costs out, restructuring contracts where they can in the portfolio. So if you look at kind of pre-2015 cash breakeven, we need about $0.60 to break even on cash on NGLs. And as we kind of exit 2015, we have moved that down to about $0.40 a gallon breakeven. And then the actions that are being further taken in 2016, we expect that the cash breakeven will be somewhere mid-30s. So I think DCP is going to be fine in this environment that we're in for 2016. The only thing I would say is DCP doesn't have a debt due until 2019. DCM actually has one due in 2017, but DPM is in good shape. So I think our view is that DCP's on strong footing. We purposely set them up for success in this is low commodity price environment.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We never said something about capital in DCP.
componenttext: We never said something about capital in DCP.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Other thing is we haven't announced anything in capital, but DCP capital this year is going to down about 50% from where it was last year. I think our share of DCP capital is about 233, 233 million this year or thereabouts, give or take. So we're continui
componenttext: Other thing is we haven't announced anything in capital, but DCP capital this year is going to down about 50% from where it was last year. I think our share of DCP capital is about 233, 233 million this year or thereabouts, give or take. So we're continuing to manage capital at DCP. be more cost takeout at DCP, more work around the restructuring as the contract this year. So I think they're in pretty good shape.

componenttext: If I look at why now you are investing a of project that you commit the Midstream. So that's why your CapEx last year and this year for the total corporation are pretty high, 4.3 and 3.9. And if we base on is that you're still targeting on the long haul 60-40 between reinvestment and the payout to the shareholder, at 60% if we say at $3 billion, that would translate into a $5 billion cash flow. So from that standpoint, should we assume after the next 1 or 2 years, we should see your CapEx drop that down to the $2.5 billion to $3 billion range? Or when you say 60-40, you're also including the dropdown proceeds in the calculation.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes to both. I think capital does probably come down in the year. we've already said '15 would be peak year for us. And so you see that coming down at PSX. You see it coming down at DCP. Also at CPChem, their capital budget for this year is going to
componenttext: Yes. Yes to both. I think capital does probably come down in the year. we've already said '15 would be peak year for us. And so you see that coming down at PSX. You see it coming down at DCP. Also at CPChem, their capital budget for this year is going to be down about 20%. So there'll be $1.45 billion will be our share of the CPChem capital for 2016. truly, I think '15 is a peak year for us. But you need to add in the proceeds from the drop in the MLP to the cash and then think about that in terms of your total amount for distributions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So are we done now? Or do we in terms of operating activity in Q1?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think we've got it a higher operating rate in Q1 with that. These turnarounds are polymer units, so there's always some of that, but generally volumes come back. the real question about the margins, I think largely depend on where you think crud
componenttext: Yes, so I think we've got it a higher operating rate in Q1 with that. These turnarounds are polymer units, so there's always some of that, but generally volumes come back. the real question about the margins, I think largely depend on where you think crude prices end up. as prices fall and gas price doesn't fall as much and the ethane price, then you get some compression there. But I would say that we continue to see good demand. We don't see inventories building in that and that demand really is around the globe. So for us, we've been looking at the underlying fundamentals and still see the demand piece in there. The moving piece really is going to be around the energy price and what happens. But barring a significant change, we would expect similar industry margins that we saw on the fourth quarter.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're at the lower end of that because there is some commercial activity. we've said about 80% fee based in that number. And so we're still in that range when you look at both the frac and the dock and the caverns and the service that, that p
componenttext: Yes, I think we're at the lower end of that because there is some commercial activity. we've said about 80% fee based in that number. And so we're still in that range when you look at both the frac and the dock and the caverns and the service that, that provides. And then what's happened today, the between the U.S. and other markets in the world are narrower. But I would also say that we see shipping constraints being alleviated. So I think we're kind of in flux about what the will ultimately be, but we still look at the market here and know that the NGLs need to find another home outside the U.S. So I think this the fundamental drivers that will push that. And the real question is how much of the  ? Do we have $500 million of the EBITDA from the or something different. But in the long term, I think we feel there's going to to be a significant commercial opportunity as well as the fee-based, but the primary driver on projects are the fees.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last one for me, if I can follow on Mr. Cheng's lead to squeeze another one in. The heavy-light differentials, obviously, spreads have come in from light crude. You guys are heavy relatively resilient, even though you spend a lot of time telling us how mu
componenttext: Last one for me, if I can follow on Mr. Cheng's lead to squeeze another one in. The heavy-light differentials, obviously, spreads have come in from light crude. You guys are heavy relatively resilient, even though you spend a lot of time telling us how much effort you're moving to maximize your light sweet crude throughput. What are you doing today? And how much flexibility do you have to swing back if you chose to? I'll leave it there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we talked a lot about last year about how much more lights can we run. I think the main thing about our systems is we have the ability to flex. I think even in fourth quarter, we probably had around 3% more medium sours. We didn't run quite as much a
componenttext: Yes, we talked a lot about last year about how much more lights can we run. I think the main thing about our systems is we have the ability to flex. I think even in fourth quarter, we probably had around 3% more medium sours. We didn't run quite as much as heavy sours because of turnarounds at Los Angeles and Lake Charles that we probably would like to. We ran a little bit more Canadian heavy during the quarter. But yes, I think we have the ability to flex that. I think we're still on max gasoline mode if you want to think about it that way. But I think the important spreads for us this year are going to be the light, heavy, the sweet sour and the spreads. I think Brent and can trade near parity, and it's going to be a very volatile market. And things are going to move around in terms of the TI-Brent differentials, but we just had to watch about.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Done, actually have project billings to continue to go to even heavier sour rate that will improve and kind of capitalize on that light heavy. And then at Wood River, we're doing some work light sweet debottlenecking that will allow us push more heavies i
componenttext: Done, actually have project billings to continue to go to even heavier sour rate that will improve and kind of capitalize on that light heavy. And then at Wood River, we're doing some work light sweet debottlenecking that will allow us push more heavies into that facility. So we're taking some incremental steps to increase our ability to handle heavy and medium sour.

componenttext: I think globally, just to comment on distillate inventories that's always something that we're watching. headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Sure, the first step on those is the fractionator are relatively minor piece of that total $400 million to $500 million EBITDA guidance that we gave. The next big step is later in the year when you really reach what that our PG export terminal, larger fee-based component as well as in commercial opportunity. So smaller impact at beginning, and then toward -- assuming that we start up on time in third quarter, in the fourth quarter, begin to see full impact of that $400 million to $500 million.

componenttext: Well, we're connected both to our fractionator and -- say it's 150,000 barrels a day equivalent initially. Roughly 40,000 or so of propane comes off with our new frac. And then we're connected to Mont and other facilities to supplement that. So it really is about giving the capacity in place, the commercial agreements and then you've got the capacity to not only take the output from our track but also supplement that with each other the NGLs system in the Gulf Coast.

componenttext: The tariff impact has been where we thought in terms of the fee. That's about 80% of that. What is narrower today is the commercial opportunity, although we expect that to widen again with shipping constraints removed and as markets begin to establish that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on the risk really in the Midstream area. I mean obviously oil prices, gas prices are low. Volumes are going to be coming down across the piece. So maybe just give us a -- I don't if you've done an assessment of volume and counterparty risk. I'm
componenttext: Question on the risk really in the Midstream area. I mean obviously oil prices, gas prices are low. Volumes are going to be coming down across the piece. So maybe just give us a -- I don't if you've done an assessment of volume and counterparty risk. I'm thinking less about your new projects, which obviously you spend a lot of time working on, but more maybe in some of the legacy and DCP area.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we look across the DCP portfolio, and 90% of this is kind of investment grade. So I think they have good counterparties on the other side of that. As we think through the volume risk side of it in the portfolio year, we think from Permi
componenttext: Well, I think that we look across the DCP portfolio, and 90% of this is kind of investment grade. So I think they have good counterparties on the other side of that. As we think through the volume risk side of it in the portfolio year, we think from Permian is probably do a little bit better. We thinks PGA is going really good. Scoop's going to do good. Eagle Ford is going to decline as we think across that. And so I would just say from a pure volume metrics perspective, we're going to be probably flat to slightly lower in 2016 at DCP. We think that gasoline demand is going to be good. We think distillate demand is going to grow although we have challenged inventories there. We think petrochemical and that's going to on balance as we think about the portfolio, Midstream kinds of flat to down at DCP. Going our Midstream is what we're doing with the frac coming out export facility, bridge, coming on late '16. So we'll see increased volumes by the transportation segment there, but -- flow through and we think petrochemical's going to . Tim, I do think we can add on that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that really is. I think we're in looking at the macro environment with a production breaking over the U.S., there's not going to be a lot of extra volume drive through that. So I think it's a question of how much decline occurs around that. W
componenttext: Yes, I think that really is. I think we're in looking at the macro environment with a production breaking over the U.S., there's not going to be a lot of extra volume drive through that. So I think it's a question of how much decline occurs around that. We do think the gas markets will continue to have a pretty good, and that's a piece of what underlies DCP as well. And so to this point, we're not concerned at all and to reiterate the counter parties on our Midstream business look very solid.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: to date, we've made NGL change major crude lines with related to kind of new production, good counterparties, solid volumes on that on the site. But as we go forward, we look at our portfolio, I think that we're shifting our attention to things that support our Refining business logistically that touch existing Midstream assets or add value, perhaps just the Chemicals value chains. So we're shifting more to the downstream, the demand side as we think about the Midstream options versus a heavy focus initially on that upstream part of that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just update us on how the changes in oil price and the effects in the U.S. E&P industry are coming through, from your point of view? I'm particularly interested, the toughest one for us is always the NGL market. Can you talk about the dynamics the
componenttext: Can you just update us on how the changes in oil price and the effects in the U.S. E&P industry are coming through, from your point of view? I'm particularly interested, the toughest one for us is always the NGL market. Can you talk about the dynamics there? And if the shift in where supply is coming from shifts in the overall supply? And then update how you're going to the exports, which I think you're partly done, would be interesting if you get it from a macro perspective?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, -- on the NGL site, we continued to see growth in NGL supply, but there is no question that is going to be at a slower pace as we look out. The other interesting thing is there's a lot of ethane rejection today as the values don't pull it forwa
componenttext: Yes, Paul, -- on the NGL site, we continued to see growth in NGL supply, but there is no question that is going to be at a slower pace as we look out. The other interesting thing is there's a lot of ethane rejection today as the values don't pull it forward. So I think as the cracker starts off, there's going to be an influx of ethane, so to speak, into the NGL piece. So I think that's certainly causes us some pause when we think about how large and how much increase beyond the day in the NGL still see it, but probably not to the extent that we have that seen a couple of years ago with all the E&P activity. On the exports side, a lot of interest still in LPG cargoes for both petrochemical operations and heating markets, Asia, Latin America and even Europe. So I think we're still seeing a lot of interest around the world as people look at alternate supplies as they come on petrochemical side. So as Greg mentioned earlier, a lot of good progress on the contracts side and just a lot of interest there that we're working to continue to look at.

componenttext: Yes, I could argue I don't think it matters. I don't think you're going to see a lot of crude exports out of the U.S. I don't think the numbers work all that much. I think it probably caps the differential and as long as you see the big outs that we saw see in '13 and '14. But I think '16 and '17 are really volatile year, and there's going to be times it's just going to be hard to call what with that differential's going to be. We think 4 to 6 long term, it ought to be in that. It's what going to take the export barrels of crude out of the U.S.

componenttext: I think the other way to look at that is we're, at Beaumont and even with Sweeny in free port, we have options to capitalize should they develop. But I think generally, our view is there's just kind of a balancing point today where excess crude is to push in, and we've got local production here. So it just -- narrows that dip at the coast. And I think that's going to continue, and I think that's the -- that's a significant change from over the last 2 years.

componenttext: Here's what I'm tell you that yes, we are in the process in Whitegate. And we're kind of well into that process, so we obviously can't talk about the specifics. But we have people that are interested, and so there's a list of people that we're going through with that asset.  I think on balance, that's the only process deposits we have going on right now in terms of assets. People -- we get asked about the West Coast in the U.S.. And West Coast, like we said, it's an option in the future, but have no current programs are -- there's nothing in the way today in terms of the West Coast. And margins have been pretty good there last year to, and we've got good assets out there. We've got great people working those assets. And so, it's an option on the future is the way I look at the West Coast.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we pushed Frac Two FID from last year to this year. we're still doing engineering work on that, and we'll make a decision on that later this year, midyear, third quarter.But we won't proceed unless we got fully contracted. We're long
componenttext:
Well, as you know, we pushed Frac Two FID from last year to this year. we're still doing engineering work on that, and we'll make a decision on that later this year, midyear, third quarter.
But we won't proceed unless we got fully contracted. We're long LNG today, but it's not fully contracted, so we're not going to build a speculative frac.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just on chemicals, given the compression of gas to oil price ratio. As you look ahead, are you still considering a second cracker at this point? Would the economics work at this stage if we were to stay at these types of levels?
componenttext: First question is just on chemicals, given the compression of gas to oil price ratio. As you look ahead, are you still considering a second cracker at this point? Would the economics work at this stage if we were to stay at these types of levels?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, it's Tim. We continue to do engineering work. And again, I'll reiterate, this is a global view with a global business. North America still looks attractive long term. And today's margins do work. It's obviously not the same return that we would have
componenttext: Phil, it's Tim. We continue to do engineering work. And again, I'll reiterate, this is a global view with a global business. North America still looks attractive long term. And today's margins do work. It's obviously not the same return that we would have if it was $0.10 a pound better. So I think that for us, it's really about continuing to meet the customer demand, the opportunity. And structurally, our view of long-term advantage on U.S. or Middle East to ethane cracking in case the ethylene chain, still to us has the greatest appeal and we think long term, a competitive advantage. Although it's less than it was, it's good by historical standards.

componenttext: Okay, got it. Second question is on the specialties business. You mentioned lower margins in the step-down sequentially. Would you say that a component of that is seasonal? Or do you think that's more of a structural step-down from increased competition in that business that we should think about as more of a new run rate? Or maybe some combination of the 2? How would you think about that?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, a couple of things. You have a lag effect of that business on prices. So as prices come down, you tend to hold it and it catches up. so I think this quarter, there was a piece of that if you think about finished lubricants price versus NGL feedstock
componenttext: Okay, a couple of things. You have a lag effect of that business on prices. So as prices come down, you tend to hold it and it catches up. so I think this quarter, there was a piece of that if you think about finished lubricants price versus NGL feedstock feedstock into the base oil business. But the one segment that we're seeing in the U.S. is weak is oil and gas, as you might expect. But generally, strong automotive business that when you're looking at what's going on in Detroit. And so U.S  volumes are still pretty good this year versus last, not a lot of growth inherently in that business by the nature of it. But we see nothing fundamental there. And I think we would say next year, to us, probably looks a lot like -- or this year looks a lot like last year in terms of how we look at the lubricants. But it's a business we like, good returns. I think this quarter just has noise around it. And I would also say that you can imagine customers don't particularly like to buy a lot when they see the price falling. So we don't see a lot of inventories still in the chain, but they don't want to get caught on higher-cost inventory. So there's always some effect when you see that in any quarter which that occurs.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. last question is on the global supply demand outlook for 2016. Where do you guys stand on that? If we have global demand growth in the 400,000 to 500,000 barrel a day range, is there enough global supply to keep up with that? And what's
componenttext: Okay, understood. last question is on the global supply demand outlook for 2016. Where do you guys stand on that? If we have global demand growth in the 400,000 to 500,000 barrel a day range, is there enough global supply to keep up with that? And what's your view on gasoline cracks for this year?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we are fairly well supplied today, but basically if just break the components, we would expect stronger gasoline growth globally than distillate. We're thinking it's less than this year. But in total, the 2 probably in the million barrel a day or
componenttext: I think we are fairly well supplied today, but basically if just break the components, we would expect stronger gasoline growth globally than distillate. We're thinking it's less than this year. But in total, the 2 probably in the million barrel a day or so, with the 2/3 or so of that being on the gasoline side and 1/3 really coming from the distillate. Clearly, distillate has more headwind I think because of the general economic conditions and less capital spend as you think about the distillate activity, whereas we see a pretty strong consumer market around the world that pulls along gasoline and to some extent, the chemicals business as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let's start with the Bayou Bridge because it's closest to being in service. So there are 2 segments. One is in the Beaumont area over to Lake Charles refinery, and then from Lake Charles to St. James. That first leg to Lake Charles will be in service a
componenttext: So let's start with the Bayou Bridge because it's closest to being in service. So there are 2 segments. One is in the Beaumont area over to Lake Charles refinery, and then from Lake Charles to St. James. That first leg to Lake Charles will be in service at the end of this quarter. And DAPL will have some initial impact in terms of the Midstream earnings. And then later this year, we'll complete the leg in St. James. those are both of the report I think clearly connects the -- Texas market with Louisiana. we -- There's still a drive for that. That line is underwritten on the commitment side with TND. So there's been interest on that on the Refining side to get new source of supply. And I think that's still a piece of what needs to happen. So I think that as it continues to make through the options more available now to the eastern gulf versus what you've seen just really on the gulf. If you look at DAPL ETCOP, Bakken to , to Beaumont, I think there's a good call on northern tier on bakken today. I think that line's underwritten with TNDs but good counter parties. So I think you'll continue to see when that comes in service at the end of this year, early next year, the ability to move those crudes then into the markets that want that and ultimately, down into the Beaumont area as an option as well. And ultimately, for us, we think DAPL ETCOP as a potential way to supply via the pipe and around for the Reasor tanker in the bay way to make it very competitive with the real option that exists from the bark in 2 today. So I think it's about creating more options of the Refining site for ourselves as well as others. And it does also, once you get the Beaumont, creates an opportunity to export should that develop. So I think there's a lot of good options. And I think that project, we look at it is going to be -- continue to be the lowest cost option to get Bakken to the markets that we're talking about serving.

componenttext: Yes, so we -- I mean, we have incremental opportunities that we're going to pursue. they're value creative, but they're small projects and don't add a lot. We look at stand-alone and try to see if that makes sense. on the other hand, I don't want to be the last one, if anyone else goes , there probably be no reason for us to do it. So we'll have to assess that against our other opportunities. The small incremental things that we do this year and next year, they make a lot of sense and we'll do those.

componenttext: So we've increased truck unloading at Santa Maria to mitigate that. We do run more process inputs at San Francisco to supplement. The pipe is to something we'd like to see. componenttext: The pipe is the preferred route, but we don't control that. So I think the folks have been a great job of mitigating it. But it's had 20 25 today impact at Santa Maria. headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sally, and I will your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Clayton Re
componenttext:
Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sally, and I will your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to Clayton Reasor, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations, Strategy, Corporate and Government Affairs. Please go ahead, Mr. Reasor.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sally. Welcome to Phillips 66's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and CEO, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor; and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The presentation material we'll be using during the c
componenttext:
Thank you, Sally. Welcome to Phillips 66's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and CEO, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor; and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The presentation material we'll be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website along with supplemental financial and operating information.
Slide 2 contains our safe operating statement. It's a reminder that we'll be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from today's comments. And factors that could cause these changes or these actual results to differ are included on the second page as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
So with that said, I'll turn the call over to Greg for some opening remarks.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Clayton. Hey, good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We had a good year in 2015. Adjusted earnings were $4.2 billion, which was our highest since 2012. We generated $5.7 billion in cash from operations. This allowed us to maintain
componenttext:
Thanks, Clayton. Hey, good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. 
We had a good year in 2015. Adjusted earnings were $4.2 billion, which was our highest since 2012. We generated $5.7 billion in cash from operations. This allowed us to maintain a strong balance sheet and financial flexibility while funding our capital program and returning $2.7 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
We made significant progress on our growth projects in Midstream and Chemicals, and we continued to improve returns in our Refining and Marketing businesses. Despite the difficult environment experienced throughout the energy industry, our diversified asset portfolio has performed well. 
We continue to execute our plan. For us, it all starts with operating excellence. We spent $1.2 billion in sustaining capital in 2015. And from an operating reliability perspective, our businesses ran well. 
2015 was a very safe year for us. We tied our best year ever for recordable injuries. And Refining, Chemicals and Midstream were top performers in injury rates. We also maintained the improvement in our environmental performance demonstrated in previous years. 
We ended 2015 with a solid quarter, especially when considering the current commodity price environment. Adjusted earnings were $710 million or $1.31 per share. Market cracks were down significantly in the fourth quarter from the highs that we saw last summer, but our global Refining business continue to run well with 94% utilization. Marketing earnings were healthy, and this continues to be a high-return business for us. 2015 adjusted return on capital employed was 35% for this segment. In Midstream, we commenced operations of the Sweeny Fractionator One and supporting Clemens Storage Caverns. 
2016 will be another busy year for us with several other Midstream projects scheduled for completion. Our Freeport LNG Export Terminal is now 80% complete. It's on track, on budget with an expected start-up in the fourth quarter of 2016. The Dakota Access and ETCOP pipeline projects also continue to make good progress and remain on schedule for completion by the end of this year.
Our master limited partnership, Phillips 66 Partners, remains an important part of our Midstream growth strategy. The fee-based assets within PSXP's portfolio continue to perform well and are not impacted by the current market conditions. PSXP continues on track to achieve its stated growth objective of a 5-year 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
Adjusted EBITDA was up nearly 90% for the year at PSXP, while distribution growth and coverage were also strong. In addition, PSXP was able to raise $1.5 billion of low-cost capital through the debt and equity capital markets in 2015.
DCP continues to work on reducing costs and converting contracts to fee-based structures to improve its financial strength and flexibility. The equity contributions from the owners in the fourth quarter helped in that regard. We expect that DCP will be self-funded going forward.
In Chemicals, cash margins fell during the fourth quarter; however, they remain strong by historical standards. CPChem's geographically advantaged footprint allows it to remain profitable and able to self-fund its growth projects. Development continues on CPChem's U.S. Gulf Coast petrochemicals project, which will increase CPChem's U.S. ethylene and polyethylene capacity by over 40%. Overall progress on the project is approaching 70% complete with start-up planned in mid-2017. This project remains on time and on budget. 
We had another strong cash flow quarter. We generated $1.5 billion in cash from operations. We used $1 billion of that cash flow in capital spending to support Midstream growth and maintaining operating integrity in our Refining system. 
We also continue to return capital to our shareholders. During the fourth quarter, we returned over $700 million through dividends and share repurchases. Over the last 3 years, shareholder distributions have totaled more than $9 billion.
Looking forward to 2016, our focus remains on operating well and executing our $3.9 billion capital budget. We continue to target a 60-40 split between reinvestment and distributions, and we have targeted a dividend increase in 2016 of at least 10%. 
So now I'd like to turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to take us through the quarter's results.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, fourth quarter adjusted earnings were $710 million or $1.31 per share. Reported net income was $650 million, including several special items excluded from adjusted earnings. These special items decreased ea
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, fourth quarter adjusted earnings were $710 million or $1.31 per share. Reported net income was $650 million, including several special items excluded from adjusted earnings. These special items decreased earnings by $60 million and included $104 million in impairments at DCP and a $33 million lower of cost or market write-down of inventory at our Wood River Borger joint venture, offset by an $88 million gain tied to favorable changes in German tax law. Excluding negative working capital changes of $300 million, cash from operations was $1.8 billion. Capital spending for the quarter was $1 billion excluding the $1.5 billion contribution to DCP Midstream. Dividends and share repurchases in the fourth quarter totaled $704 million. And excluding special items, our adjusted effective income tax rate was 31%. 
Slide 5 compares fourth quarter and third quarter adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were down $937 million. All segments had lower earnings, but Refining accounted for most of the reduction.
Next, we'll cover each of the segments. I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. Transportation benefited from higher equity earnings and volumes. In NGLs, Sweeny Fractionator One came online during December. Included in the transportation and NGL results is the contribution from Phillips 66 Partners. During the quarter, PSXP contributed earnings of $37 million to the Midstream segment and increased its quarterly LP distribution by 7% over the third quarter. DCP Midstream continues to work on its self-help initiatives to reduce costs, manage its portfolio and restructure contracts.
2015 adjusted return on capital employed to the Midstream segment was 5% based on an average capital employed of $6.8 billion. The return for this segment continues to reflect the impact of increased capital employed, driven by our significant growth investments as well as the impact of low commodity prices on DCP earnings.
Moving to Slide 7. Midstream's fourth quarter adjusted earnings were $42 million, down $49 million from the third quarter. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter was $78 million, up $1 million from the prior quarter. NGL adjusted losses were $2 million for the quarter. The $34 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by the timing of adjustments related to the tax extenders bill signed in December as well as additional costs associated with the Sweeny hub. Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were higher in the fourth quarter, mainly due to lower natural gas and natural gas liquids marketing margins as well as the impact of lower commodity prices.
In Chemicals, the global olefins and polyolefins capacity utilization rate for the quarter was 92% and margins trended lower. SA&S was negatively impacted by planned turnaround activity. The 2015 adjusted return on capital employed for our Chemical segment was 19% based on an average capital employed of $4.9 billion. 
As shown on Slide 9, fourth quarter adjusted earnings for Chemicals were $182 million, down from $272 million in the third quarter. In olefins and polyolefins, the decrease of $80 million was largely due to lower cash margins. However, demand for polyethylene and normal alpha olefin products remained healthy during the quarter. 
Adjusted earnings for SA&S declined to $9 million on lower equity earnings, driven by lower volumes due to turnaround activities at CPChem's equity affiliates and lower margins. This was partially offset by higher volumes in specialty chemicals.
In Refining, realized margins were $9.41 per barrel for the quarter as market crack spreads decreased significantly. Market capture increased from 72% to 74% in the fourth quarter as we saw improvements in clean product differentials and lower losses on secondary products. Refining crude utilization was 94%. Clean product yield was 85%, representing a record quarter. 
Pretax turnaround costs were $130 million compared to guidance of approximately $150 million, due primarily to the deferral of some planned maintenance. 2015 adjusted return on capital employed for Refining was 19%. This is based on average capital employed of $13.6 billion. 
Slide 11 shows a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. The Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $376 million, down $676 million from last quarter. The reduction was probably due to lower market cracks in all regions. Atlantic Basin adjusted earnings were lower this quarter due to lower gasoline and distillate margins, partially offset by higher volumes as capacity utilization exceeded 100%. The Gulf Coast region saw lower margins and had lower volumes due to downtime at Lake Charles and Sweeny. In the Central Corridor, market cracks dropped by more than $8 per barrel, which accounted for approximately 90% of the $251 reduction in adjusted earnings from the third quarter. In addition, Wood River and Ponca City also had downtime due to turnaround activity.
In the Western region, grass cracks fell nearly $15 per barrel. Volumes and controllable costs were also impacted by a major turnaround at our L.A. refinery that we completed in the fourth quarter. Santa Maria continued to be impacted by the Plains pipeline outage. 
Next, we will cover market capture on Slide 12. Our worldwide realized margin was $9.41 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack of $12.77 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 74%. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries as it relates to our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 85% clean product yield for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. 
Losses due to secondary products were lower this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as coke and NGLs narrowed. Feedstock advantage was somewhat higher than the third quarter, but still below average as crude differentials generally remained tight. The other category mainly includes costs associated with RINs, outgoing freight, product differentials and inventory impacts.
Let's move to Marketing and Specialties where we posted a solid quarter, thanks to favorable global marketing margins. However, Specialties saw reduced earnings on lower lubricants margins. The 2015 adjusted return on capital employed for M&S was 35% on average capital employed of $2.7 billion. 
Slide 14 shows adjusted earnings for M&S in the fourth quarter of $227 million, down $117 million from the third quarter. In Marketing and Other, the $93 million decrease was largely due to lower margins in both domestic and international marketing, which decreased from the notably high margins in the third quarter. This was partially offset by the renewal of biodiesel tax credits. Specialties adjusted earnings decreased to $29 million due to narrowing base oil and finished lubricants margins and lower finished lubricants volumes.
On Slide 15, the Corporate and Other segment had an aftertax net cost of $117 million this quarter, an increase of $5 million from the third quarter. Net interest expense increased by $4 million, primarily due to lower capitalized interest, but corporate overhead and other expenses were in line with the prior quarter.
On Slide 16, we summarized our financial results for the year. 2015 adjusted earnings were $4.2 billion or $7.67 per share. Excluding negative working capital changes of $200 million, cash from operations was $5.9 billion. Capital spending for the year was $4.3 billion excluding the $1.5 billion contribution to DCP Midstream. Total shareholder distributions were $2.7 billion. At the end of the fourth quarter, our adjusted debt-to-capital ratio excluding Phillips 66 Partners was 25%. And after taking into account our ending cash balance, our adjusted net debt-to-capital ratio was 17%. The adjusted return on capital employed for 2015 was 14%.
Moving to Slide 17. 2015 adjusted earnings were higher than 2014 as lower earnings from Midstream and Chemicals were more than offset by improvements from our Refining and Marketing and Specialties businesses. We had an 11% increase in adjusted earnings, and adjusted earnings per share increased by $1.05 or 16%.
Slide 18 shows cash flow for 2015. We began the year with a cash balance of $5.2 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations was $5.9 billion. Working capital changes reduced cash flow by $200 million. In the first quarter, $1.1 billion in debt and approximately $400 million in equity was issued by PSXP. We also retired $800 million in Phillips 66 senior notes.
During 2015, we funded $5.8 billion of capital expenditures and investments. This is -- this included $4.3 billion of capital spend, including $3 billion in Midstream and $1.1 billion in Refining. We also distributed $2.7 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the year with 529 million shares outstanding. Excluding the DCP contribution, 61% of our available cash went to reinvestment and 39% to distributions. At the end of 2015, our cash balance was $3.1 billion.
This concludes my review of the financial and operating results. Next, I'll cover a few outlook items. 
For 2016, we expect full year turnaround expenses to be between $525 million and $575 million pretax. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $480 million and $500 million. And we expect full year D&A of about $1.2 billion.
In the first quarter, Chemicals, we expect the global O&P utilization rate to be in the mid-90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rate to also be in the mid-90s and pretax turnaround expense to be approximately $150 million. In Corporate and Other, we expect aftertax costs to be between $120 million and $125 million. And company-wide, we expect the effective income tax rate to be in the mid-30s.
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. On the Midstream projects, DAPL and ETCOP, given that some of the partners look like they may need capital over the next couple of years as their cost of capital gets higher. I just want to understand, would you be willing to t
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. On the Midstream projects, DAPL and ETCOP, given that some of the partners look like they may need capital over the next couple of years as their cost of capital gets higher. I just want to understand, would you be willing to take sort of a bigger interest in those assets if the opportunity presented itself?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Faisel, it's Tim. I think that, with our partners on DAPL and ETCOP, we've been exploring various options on that. I think our commitment is where we'd like it to be at this point, but certainly we'll consider that. It's all about what delivers the b
componenttext: Yes, Faisel, it's Tim. I think that, with our partners on DAPL and ETCOP, we've been exploring various options on that. I think our commitment is where we'd like it to be at this point, but certainly we'll consider that. It's all about what delivers the best value for us.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then you talked about in your prepared remarks, you're targeting a dividend growth rate of 10% for this year. I mean, is that sort of locked in? Or is there sort of a wiggle room if markets change or things become a little bit more dyna
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then you talked about in your prepared remarks, you're targeting a dividend growth rate of 10% for this year. I mean, is that sort of locked in? Or is there sort of a wiggle room if markets change or things become a little bit more dynamic?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we said at least 10%. Now we raised dividend 12% last year. But I think we'll take a look at that. Obviously, we need the board to approve this, too, but we had given guidance 3 years ago that we'd do double-digit increases in '14, '15 and '16. We st
componenttext: Yes, we said at least 10%. Now we raised dividend 12% last year. But I think we'll take a look at that. Obviously, we need the board to approve this, too, but we had given guidance 3 years ago that we'd do double-digit increases in '14, '15 and '16. We stand by that guidance.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, last question for me. In the Atlantic Basin, you guys ran over 100%. Throughput was strong and so was uptime. Does that -- is this sort of a new set of reliability in the Atlantic Basin? Or is this unusual circumstance where things just ran sort of
componenttext: Okay, last question for me. In the Atlantic Basin, you guys ran over 100%. Throughput was strong and so was uptime. Does that -- is this sort of a new set of reliability in the Atlantic Basin? Or is this unusual circumstance where things just ran sort of at a higher level for the quarter?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at that, remember, we just came out of a Humber turnaround, really came out of that in good shape, good clean refinery. So I think it reflects that. And then at Bayway, we continued to run a lot of process inputs to fill out our downstream u
componenttext: When you look at that, remember, we just came out of a Humber turnaround, really came out of that in good shape, good clean refinery. So I think it reflects that. And then at Bayway, we continued to run a lot of process inputs to fill out our downstream units in that facility. So it was really good quarter, and I would anticipate [indiscernible] market conditions that we'd continue to try to run as full as we can.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul Cheng from Barclays is online with a question.
componenttext: Paul Cheng from Barclays is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- maybe that this is for Greg. With the changing market condition related to the market acceptance for the funding model in the MLP sector, how that is going to impact your way of the drop-down that I think previously that you've been looking for ma
componenttext: Just -- maybe that this is for Greg. With the changing market condition related to the market acceptance for the funding model in the MLP sector, how that is going to impact your way of the drop-down that I think previously that you've been looking for maybe up to $2 billion a year? I don't know whether that you have changed. And also that, I mean, from the CapEx that you spent $3.9 billion in dividend, about $1.3 billion with your cash flow from operations, you don't have much for the buyback. So should we assume that you can't do much of the drop-down, you will correspondingly scale down your buyback, or that you're going to increase your balance sheet to maintain the buyback in a certain way?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, okay. So let me try to start with the question and I'll -- Certainly, we understand the question, Paul. As we look out there, there's a lot of stress in the space with people that are overlevered and will have difficulty accessing the capital equity
componenttext: Well, okay. So let me try to start with the question and I'll -- Certainly, we understand the question, Paul. As we look out there, there's a lot of stress in the space with people that are overlevered and will have difficulty accessing the capital equity markets given their prohibitively high cost of capital. We look at PSXP, strong sponsorship, strong investment-grade rating, you might even call us a drop-down titan, maybe, but a great portfolio of existing EBITDA that can be dropped. We've got these projects lined up in the queue that are in flight that really add to that. And then you kind of look at where PSXP is trading kind around 3%. So I think that investors look at PSXP, they get the growth story. They understand the growth story. I think that's a confidence in our ability to execute that. And so we would say that we think the capital markets are going to be open to us in 2016, and our plan is to be out there in there. And you've got the number about right. We kind of said kind of $2 billion a year that we need to be through the capital markets and the debt markets. They hit this $1.1 billion of EBITDA in 2018 at the MLP. And so we stand by that guidance and we'll stay there. We should generate $4 billion to $5 billion mid-cycle of cash, then you kind of add another $1.5 billion to $2 billion coming out of the MLP. So I think we're fine in terms of funding our capital program and in terms of funding growing distributions through increasing our dividend. And we'll have -- as long as our shares are trading below interesting value, we're going to take shares in.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second question, Greg, on DCP, I mean, you guys have that capital restructuring with your partner in the fourth quarter, but the market condition continue to deteriorate in that business. So is there a possibility that later this year, whether that's
componenttext: The second question, Greg, on DCP, I mean, you guys have that capital restructuring with your partner in the fourth quarter, but the market condition continue to deteriorate in that business. So is there a possibility that later this year, whether that's due to if there's any more debt being mature, do we need to do additional capital infusion into that? Or that you're confident that you already fixed the problem at this point?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the contributions by both SE [ph] and ourselves have gone a long way towards fixing the balance sheet issues at DCP. So the other thing, you've got to give the folks at DCP a lot of credit. They've done a great job of pulling costs out,
componenttext: Well, I think that the contributions by both SE [ph] and ourselves have gone a long way towards fixing the balance sheet issues at DCP. So the other thing, you've got to give the folks at DCP a lot of credit. They've done a great job of pulling costs out, restructuring contracts where they can in the portfolio. And so if you look kind of pre-2015 cash breakeven, we need about $0.60 to break even on cash on NGLs. And as kind of we exit 2015, we had moved that down to about $0.40 a gallon breakeven. And then the actions that are being further taken in 2016, we expect that the cash breakeven will be somewhere mid-30s. So I think DCP is going to be fine in this environment that we're in for 2016. The other thing I would say is DCP doesn't have a debt due until 2019. DPM actually has one due in 2017, but DPM is in pretty good shape. So I think our view is that DCP is on pretty strong footing. We purposely set them up for success in this low commodity price environment.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you may want so say something on capital in DCP.
componenttext: And you may want so say something on capital in DCP.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing is that we haven't really announced the capital, but DCP capital this year is going to be down about 50% from what it was last year. I think our share of DCP capital is about $233 million this year, thereabouts, give or take. So we're cont
componenttext: The other thing is that we haven't really announced the capital, but DCP capital this year is going to be down about 50% from what it was last year. I think our share of DCP capital is about $233 million this year, thereabouts, give or take. So we're continuing to manage capital at DCP. There will be more costs taken out at DCP this year, more work around the restructuring of the contracts this year. So I think they're in pretty good shape.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I have a final question, one last one?
componenttext: Can I have a final question, one last one?

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I look at why now you are investing a number of projects that you commit on the Midstream. So that's why your CapEx last year and this year for the total corporation are pretty high, 4.3 and 3.9. And if we base on you suggest that you're still targetin
componenttext: If I look at why now you are investing a number of projects that you commit on the Midstream. So that's why your CapEx last year and this year for the total corporation are pretty high, 4.3 and 3.9. And if we base on you suggest that you're still targeting on the long haul 60-40 between reinvestment and the payout to the shareholder, at 60% if we, say, snap at $3 billion, that would translate into a $5 billion cash flow. So from that standpoint, should we assume after the next 1 or 2 years we should see your CapEx drop back down to -- into the $2.5 billion to $3 billion range? Or that when you say 60-40, you're also including the drop-down proceeds in the calculation.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, yes to both. I think capital probably does come down in the year. We've always said '15 would be peak year for us. And so you see that coming down at PSX. You see it coming down at DCP. Also at CPChem, their capital budget for this year is goin
componenttext: Yes. Well, yes to both. I think capital probably does come down in the year. We've always said '15 would be peak year for us. And so you see that coming down at PSX. You see it coming down at DCP. Also at CPChem, their capital budget for this year is going to be down about 20%. So there'll be a $1.45 billion will be our share of the CPChem capital for 2016. So truly, I think '15 is a peak year for us. But you need to add in the proceeds from the drop in the MLP to the cash and then think about that in terms of your total amount for distributions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch is online with a question.
componenttext: Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
