componenttext: Welcome to the first quarter 2016 Phillips 66 earnings conference call. My name is Sally, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Rosy , General manager, Investor Relations. Rosy, you may begin.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Greg Garland; President Tim Taylor; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Greg Garland; President Tim Taylor; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The presentation material we will be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website, along with supplemental financial and operating information.
Slide 2 contains our safe harbor statement. It is a reminder that will be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from today's comments. Factors that could cause our actual results to differ are included here as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg Garland for some opening remarks.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. We had a good operating quarter running well across all of our businesses. However, weaker margins has significant impact on our earnings this quarter. In Refining, distillate crack spreads
componenttext:
Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. 
We had a good operating quarter running well across all of our businesses. However, weaker margins has significant impact on our earnings this quarter. In Refining, distillate crack spreads were the lowest since 2010. In Chemicals, benchmark industry olefin chain margins were down from last quarter, and Midstream was impacted by lower NGL prices. We experienced solid results from our Marketing and Specialties business.
Total adjusted earnings were $360 million. And excluding working capital changes, we generated $722 million in cash from operations. We remain focused on operating excellence, notably in our growth projects in Midstream and Chemicals we see great value in opportunity long term. We're maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation and believe that our strong balance sheet is a competitive advantage that positions as well to execute our plan to the commodity price cycles.
During the quarter, we reinvested $750 million back into the business and distributed $687 million to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. Since May of 2012, we returned $11.8 billion to shareholders through dividends and our repurchase or exchange of 115 million shares. We continue to target a 60-40 split between reinvestment in our business and distributions back to our shareholders, and we've targeted another dividend increase this year of at least 10%.
We've made good progress in our major growth projects. In Midstream, we received all the permits necessary for the Dakota Access Pipeline to start laying pipe in May and we would expect and on schedule completion by year-end. In the Gulf Coast, the Beaumont Terminal expansion is going well. The terminal currently has 7.1 million barrels of storage capacity. We have 3.2 million barrels of new capacity under construction. Longer term, this facility can expand to 16 million barrels of storage capacity. 
Also, development of first phase of Sweeny hub is nearing completion. LPG export terminal is 80% complete, is on time and on budget. The completion of the terminal represents a major step in the development of their world-class energy complex within a Refining, chemical in Midstream assets. 
PSXP remains an important part of our Midstream growth strategy. The fee-based assets within its portfolio continue to perform well. PSXP increased its limited partner distribution by 5% this quarter and remains on track to achieve a steady growth objective of a 5-year, 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
DCP Midstream is reducing its cash breakeven through self-help initiatives and expect to achieve breakeven and NGL prices below $0.35 per gallon this year. They're reducing costs, cutting capital substantially and converting commodity-exposed contracts to fee-based to improve financial strength and flexibility. 
In addition, the equity contributions from the owners last year strengthened the balance sheet, increased fee-based earnings and position DCP for success in the future. We expect the DCP will be self-funded going forward.
In Chemicals, demand for consumer products remain strong. In response, CPChem's continues to run at high rates across its system. Because CPChem's primary production centers are in North America and in the Middle East, underpinned by Vantage feedstock, we believe CPChem's asset base provides us with a competitive advantage. CPChem's continues to advance the U.S. Gulf Coast Petrochemicals Project. It is 75% complete with expected start-up in mid-2017. Once running, CPChem's global ethylene and polyethylene capacity will increase by approximately 1/3. 
In Refining, we see good gasoline supply and demand fundamentals for the remainder the year, we expect strong demand as we head some of the summer driving season. Our focus in Refining is operating excellence, maintaining our cost and capital discipline, increasing returns to selective investment. We projects that are quick payoff, low cost and high returns. During the quarter, we advanced several of these Refining projects. At the Wood River refinery, we're undergoing debottlenecking and are on schedule for completion in the third quarter. At Bayway, work on the SEC modernization is on schedule. At the Billings refinery, effort is underway to increase the amount of heavy Canadian crude we can run to 100%. Each of these project has a projected return on investment of about 30%.
So that, I'll turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to review the quarter results. Having be

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, first quarter adjusted earnings were $360 million or $0.67 per share. Reported net income was $385 million. Excluding working capital, cash from operations was $722 million. Capital spending for the quart
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. 
Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, first quarter adjusted earnings were $360 million or $0.67 per share. Reported net income was $385 million. Excluding working capital, cash from operations was $722 million. Capital spending for the quarter was $750 million, with approximately $450 million spend in Midstream primarily at our growth projects. Distributions to shareholders in the first quarter totaled $687 million, including $296 million and dividends and $391 million in share repurchases. At the end of the first quarter, our debt-to-capital ratio was 27%. And after taking into account our ending cash balance, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 23%. Annualized adjusted return on capital employed was 5%. Our adjusted effective income tax rate is 33%.
Slide 5 compares first quarter 2016 and fourth quarter 2015 adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were down $350 million, primarily driven by lower results in Refining. 
Next, we will cover each of the segments individually.  I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. Transportation continues to generate stable earnings. The NGL business progressed construction on the Freeport LPG Export Terminal. Fractionator utilization was reduced due to turnarounds and the impact of ethane rejection on feedstock composition. Included in the transportation and energy results is the contribution from Phillips 66 Partners. During the quarter PSXP contributed earnings of $32 million to the Midstream segment. Distributions to Phillips 66 from our LP and GP interests increased 7% over the fourth quarter. DCP Midstream -- continues to work on its self-help initiatives to reduce costs, manage its portfolio and restructure contracts.
On Slide 7, Midstream's first quarter adjusted earnings were $40 million, down $2 million from the fourth quarter. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter were $72 million, down $6 million from the prior quarter, driven by lower equity earnings from Express pipeline and Explorer pipeline. NGL adjusted losses were $11 million for the first quarter. The $9 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by seasonal storage activity, partially offset by lower tax expense. Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were lower in the first quarter, primarily due to improved reliability and contract restructuring efforts, partially offset by the impact of lower commodity prices.
In Chemicals, the global olefins and polyolefins capacity utilization rate for the quarter was 93%, and margins were lower. SA&S improve higher volumes it equity affiliates. 
As shown on Slide 9, first quarter adjusted earnings for Chemicals were $156 million, down from $182 million in the fourth quarter. In olefins and polyolefins, the decrease of $36 million was largely due to lower margins, driven by reduced polyethylene sales prices. This was partially offset by higher polyethylene sales volumes and lower controllable costs. Adjusted earnings for SA&S increased by $7 million on higher equity earnings from increased sales volumes due to fourth quarter turnaround activities at CPChem's equity affiliates.
In Refining, realized margins were $7.11 per barrel for the quarter as market crack spreads decreased significantly from the prior quarter. Gasoline market cracks were down 14% from the fourth quarter, due in part of the impact of higher-than-normal industry gasoline production in the fourth quarter as well as the impact of butane blending and seasonally lower demand. Distillate market cracks were at a 6-year low. Market capture decreased from 74% in the fourth quarter to 67% in the first quarter. Clean product yield fell to 82%, with gasoline yield at 43%. yields reflect the impact of turnaround activity as well as accelerated maintenance the secondary units due to the low-margin environment. Pretax turnaround costs were $115 million, $35 million lower than guidance due to the deferral of some catalyst change activity.
Slide 11 shows a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. The Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $86 million, down $290 million from last quarter. The reduction was largely due to the lower market cracks. Atlantic Basin adjusted earnings decreased to this quarter primarily due to lower volumes and inventory impacts. The Gulf Coast region saw lower margins and reduced volumes due to planned maintenance and unplanned downtime. 
In the Gulf Coast region as well as the Central Corridor, we had unplanned downtime as we undertook discretionary maintenance our low-margin environment. In the Central Corridor, lower margins accounted for the majority of the reduction in adjusted earnings from the fourth quarter as market cracks were 24% lower. 
On the West Coast, market cracks were 26% lower. Reduced margins were mostly offset by improvements in controllable costs and inventory impacts. Santa Maria continued to be affected by the Plains pipeline outage. 
Next, we will cover market capture on Slide 12. Our worldwide realized margin was $7.11 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack of $10.64 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 67%. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries as it relates to our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 82% clean product yield for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. Losses due to secondary products decreased this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as Coke and NGLs narrowed. Feedstock advantage was slightly higher than the fourth quarter, but crude differentials generally remained tight. The other category mainly includes costs associated with gross margins, outgoing freight, product differentials and inventory impacts.
Let's move to Marketing and Specialties where we posted a good quarter, thanks to healthy U.S. margins and volumes. Specialty saw higher earnings on improved margins.  Slide 14 shows adjusted earnings for M&S in the first quarter of $205 million, down $22 million from the fourth quarter. in Marketing and Other, the $36 million decrease was largely due to lower biodiesel tax credits and lower margins in International Marketing. This was partially offset by higher U.S. marketing margins. Specialties adjusted earnings increased to $43 million primarily due to improved base oil margins.
On Slide 15, the Corporate and Other expense had after-tax net costs of $127 million this quarter, an increase of $10 million from the fourth quarter. Net interest expense increased by $7 million primarily due to lower capitalized interest associated with the start up of Sweeny Fractionator One, while corporate overhead and other expenses increased by $3 million due to the timing of legal and environmental charges.
Slide 16 shows cash flow for the quarter. We began the year with a cash balance of $3.1 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations was $722 million. Working capital changes reduced cash flow by $464 million. The cash benefit from a U.S. tax refund received in the quarter was more than offset by the customary first quarter inventory build and the timing marketing receipts and crude cargo payments. We funded $750 million of capital expenditures and investments, and we distributed nearly $700 million to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the quarter with 526 million shares . At the end of the quarter, our cash balance was $1.7 billion.
This concludes my review of the financial and operational results. Next, I'll cover a few outlook items. In the second quarter in Chemicals, we expect the global O&P utilization rate to be in the low 90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rate to be in the mid-90s and before-tax turnaround expenses to be approximately $100 million. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $120 million and $125 million. And companywide we expect we effective income tax we to be in the mid-30s. 
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

I wonder if I could ask you about the impact of run in the quarter? Because my understanding is earlier in the quarter, you guys deliberately taken some steps to basically run at lower 
rates. And obviously I'm wondering if that was part of what fell behind the Refining result in the quarter. And my follow-up I guess is also Refining related to the diesel overhang we see currently. Obviously, you guys are a little bit more exposed to that. I'd just love to get your perspective on how you see -- if you see that creeping up, and how you see that playing out let's say over the next 3 to 6 months? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start and Tim, you can kind of give the overlook. So we ran really hard January in March, and we slowed down in February is really the story. I think the interesting thing is, we accelerated some maintenance activity, but a lot of it was on second
componenttext: So I'll start and Tim, you can kind of give the overlook. So we ran really hard January in March, and we slowed down in February is really the story. I think the interesting thing is, we accelerated some maintenance activity, but a lot of it was on secondary units. And it really didn't affect the overall utilization as much as you might suspect, but we did, we did build some intermediate inventory during the quarter. So I think that's the major impact in terms of the operations. And Tim, why don't you hit on the outlook in terms of distillate?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, on the distillate side, yes, I think exports are the key to really clearing the length in North America. And we're seeing good demand in China, India, West Africa and Latin America, and so I think that continues. That said, I think distillate f
componenttext: Yes, Doug, on the distillate side, yes, I think exports are the key to really clearing the length in North America. And we're seeing good demand in China, India, West Africa and Latin America, and so I think that continues. That said, I think distillate for us continues to look to be the challenge for the market as we go forward. But I think it will clear, but it's really turning into more of a by-product from a gasoline production standpoint. So I think as long as the export markets are open, that will continue to clear the U.S.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a quick follow-up. So you're planning to run your refineries back up into the mid-90s in the second quarter. So I'm just kind of curious if margins are so challenging in your distillate heavy yield, why would you continue to -- or you just goin
componenttext: Maybe just a quick follow-up. So you're planning to run your refineries back up into the mid-90s in the second quarter. So I'm just kind of curious if margins are so challenging in your distillate heavy yield, why would you continue to -- or you just going to press into that? Or do you think it will be more voluntary run [ph] as we go through the next 3 to 6 months? It doesn't sound like it.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. I think that we're seeing strong gasoline cracks. I mean, they really recovered in March and now in April, the summer driving season. That's going to drive the overall refinery utilization. It certainly drives our thinking. And then the distill
componenttext: Yes, Doug. I think that we're seeing strong gasoline cracks. I mean, they really recovered in March and now in April, the summer driving season. That's going to drive the overall refinery utilization. It certainly drives our thinking. And then the distillate piece, the crack spread's relatively stable where it is and has been, but I think that's the piece where we're looking to exports to clear that. But I think the gasoline pulling the refinery utilization up across the industry.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Blake Fernandez with Howard is online with a question.
componenttext: Blake Fernandez with Howard is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Maybe just to follow up on Doug's distillate question, do you have any sense that maybe once we reaccelerate activity here in the U.S. from a drilling perspective, do you think that's a critical component of kind of cleaning up the disparity we're seeing between demand and maybe some of these building inventories on the distillate site?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's part of the equation, but it's -- I mean, right now, it's probably less than 2% of total distillates demand, but it's helpful. It's maybe 40,000 or 50,000 barrels a day is our estimate.
componenttext: It's part of the equation, but it's -- I mean, right now, it's probably less than 2% of total distillates demand, but it's helpful. It's maybe 40,000 or 50,000 barrels a day is our estimate.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. That's helpful. The second piece, maybe this a question for Kevin. The buyback seem to continue at a fairly robust rate, continuing the macro environment. Just curious we're thinking about ability of the buyback program and kind of the seasona
componenttext: Okay, good. That's helpful. The second piece, maybe this a question for Kevin. The buyback seem to continue at a fairly robust rate, continuing the macro environment. Just curious we're thinking about ability of the buyback program and kind of the seasonality of what we would expect on the cash flow.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll take it, then Kevin can step in. So I kind of think about this in several different buckets. The first bucket is really, I think the first quarter is reflective of our view of what 2016 is going to be. You've seen cracks gone to $10 to $15. W
componenttext: Yes, so I'll take it, then Kevin can step in. So I kind of think about this in several different buckets. The first bucket is really, I think the first quarter is reflective of our view of what 2016 is going to be. You've seen cracks gone to $10 to $15. We've seen NGLs move go from $0.37 to $0.47, $0.48. We're seeing good demand for transportation fuels, gasoline. We're seeing good demand for petrochemicals. We're seeing margines up a couple of cents, and we think margins will continue to improve in the petchem chain. We meeting that '16 is to kind of a $4 billion to $5 billion type cash generation from operations. Second thing I would say our view is that for high-quality MLPs, we think that equity markets are open and that we would expect between some combination of debt and equity, we'd raise between $1 billion and $2 billion back into PSX this year. So this kind of moves you to about $5 billion to $7 billion of cash if you want to think about it that way. We can afford a $3.9 billion capital program, $1.2 billion in dividend and $1 billion to $2 billion of share repurchases given that. I will say just though, we're looking at the things going on. And we are going through every line item in the capital budget, for '16 and '17. And we're sharing that our premises that we started with are still valid and that these projects are going to generate returns that are acceptable and meet our requirements. And so we'll be looking at that going forward into this year.

I'm looking specifically for naphtha that whether there is more economic directly brand it into the gasoline pool in the U.S. and then add octane to begin to finished gasoline, or that is better to take them out in U.S. into the overseas to be used as a petrochemical feedstock, and the insight from you guys, given you are also a big petrochemical producer.

componenttext: Yes, clearly naphtha demands increased around the world, but we still see the best value to go into gasoline pool here, poll it with octane to blend it up. But with the demand we're seeing in gasoline, that's still the preference that we have.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: So Paul, we haven't broken out at that level of detail. As you know, we report at the sort of the NGL subsegment within our Midstream business. At the PSXP level, you can see there what they see on the fractionators, but that's a different look to the Phillips 66 look. So at this point, that's not a level of granularity that we've broken out at this time. Obviously, the fractionator just started up at the end of last year. So it's still kind of going through that start-up, a little bit of incremental costs that you wouldn't expect to be recurring. And volume's a little bit lower than capacity, given the feedstock composition. But ultimately, the full value is going to come when you see the export terminal up and running and get full contribution.

componenttext: Yes, so I would say we kind of guide or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunities. In terms of the $3.9 billion this year and how much flex do we have, I would say we're still working through that and looking at that. But it's probably $500 million-ish in terms of the amount of flex that we actually have this year.

Can you give us an idea of what export volumes have been and kind of what you would anticipate as we go into the summer? I mean, you made a comment about as long as the market remains open. Just kind of curious what that means in a numerical sense.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been running since we hit, mid-90s utilization so that's not changing. And so this last quarter, we ran 126,000, 127,000 barrels a day of exports. So from our standpoint, that's a very manageable amount to replace. our utilization really comes
componenttext: Yes, we've been running since we hit, mid-90s utilization so that's not changing. And so this last quarter, we ran 126,000, 127,000 barrels a day of exports. So from our standpoint, that's a very manageable amount to replace. our utilization really comes from stays [indiscernible] where we were. And so I think that's the key at our Gulf Coast refineries to balance that distillate.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: And I mean more, any particular level of flexibility we should consider here between gasoline and the distillate side? Or are you pretty well where you can go in the say, next 12 months or so?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've been running pretty much max gasoline as most of the industry has. We probably can flex about 3% to 4% between gasoline and diesel. So we do have some projects that are coming on that will directionally move us more towards gasoline, li
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been running pretty much max gasoline as most of the industry has. We probably can flex about 3% to 4% between gasoline and diesel. So we do have some projects that are coming on that will directionally move us more towards gasoline, like the modernization of the Bayway is a good example of that and some of the things we're doing at Wood River. I think on balance, we should expect we're going to be in the kind of 43% to 45% type gasoline yields for '16.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil Gresh with JPMorgan is online with a question.
componenttext: Phil Gresh with JPMorgan is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, on the third quarter call last year, I asked about the timing of reaching full run rate on the 2 projects, the 400 million to 500 million. I was wondering if you could give an update on that. Obviously it's a slow start on the NGL side. It
componenttext: First question, on the third quarter call last year, I asked about the timing of reaching full run rate on the 2 projects, the 400 million to 500 million. I was wondering if you could give an update on that. Obviously it's a slow start on the NGL side. It sounds like LGP is on time, but there is a market exposure piece there. So as we go through '17, I mean, what level are you, of the 400 million to 500 million, are you confident with at this point?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the 400 million to 500 million is the total from the fractionation, and that's a smaller piece of that total terminal and the access. we've always said 20%, 30% of that is commodity type of exposure. So I think there's always where the market structure
componenttext: So the 400 million to 500 million is the total from the fractionation, and that's a smaller piece of that total terminal and the access. we've always said 20%, 30% of that is commodity type of exposure. So I think there's always where the market structure is going to be, where the arch is going to be between the Gulf Coast and export markets in Asia, Europe or Latin America. So as export terminal completes late this year and you go through start-up, I think you start to see that impact really, whole chain value impacts, starts late this year in 2017. and I think the real question is going to be is what is that commercial piece of that going to be. So that's why we've always framed it a bit from the 400 million to 500 million in terms of where the markets those. But if crude prices recover globally, I think that increases that are naturally when we see that. So I think that's a variable piece of that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So x the [indiscernible] execution for around the rest. you're comfortable like mid-'17, you can hit the full run rate on the rest?
componenttext: So x the [indiscernible] execution for around the rest. you're comfortable like mid-'17, you can hit the full run rate on the rest?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: yes, I think the frac is going to be when you think about composition, you think that, that comes up, it's relatively strong contribution. it's really about cargoes. We have 8 cargoes that we're looking at. So we continue to work contracts. And then we ha
componenttext: yes, I think the frac is going to be when you think about composition, you think that, that comes up, it's relatively strong contribution. it's really about cargoes. We have 8 cargoes that we're looking at. So we continue to work contracts. And then we have commercial opportunity, and there's always spot business with that. But we believe the supply is there to fill that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is just on the NGL side, particularly from the chemicals angle. I'm just kind of wondering how you're thinking about input cost pricing with respect to ethane, propane. Obviously, there's some improved sentiment here around the expor
componenttext: Okay. Second question is just on the NGL side, particularly from the chemicals angle. I'm just kind of wondering how you're thinking about input cost pricing with respect to ethane, propane. Obviously, there's some improved sentiment here around the export impact, the demand impact on NGLs. And just wondering how you think about both availability and the cost of the NGLs for your Chemicals business.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think as we've talked about look at the NGL side, we're basically seeing parity today just between ethane, propane and butane in terms of the value and the cracking slate. our view has been that the export netback price will kind of set a price for p
componenttext: So I think as we've talked about look at the NGL side, we're basically seeing parity today just between ethane, propane and butane in terms of the value and the cracking slate. our view has been that the export netback price will kind of set a price for propane, butane. And then the ethane could reach that perhaps in terms of cracking parity, but the balance really comes about which of those feedstocks you select. But the export netback really becomes the upper limit of what we set for the cracking value. Ethane, in our view, giving, coming of rejection and what we see on the start-up of the projects, should still remain at a competitive disadvantage for the long term. And so I think it really is that interplay somewhere between gas value and propane, butane parity and cracking that determines that. But we would expect when new crackers start up, that ethane prices will come up somewhat and pull some of that ethane back out of the gas range.  -- the bottom line is we're still bullish on the operating rate side on Chemicals as well as the competitive advantage that you get from ethane and LPG cracking.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good thing I would say about the petrochemical environment right now, -- it is really a demand pull that's pulling values. And it's really not the stock costs that's setting value in the market today.
componenttext: The good thing I would say about the petrochemical environment right now, -- it is really a demand pull that's pulling values. And it's really not the stock costs that's setting value in the market today.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you'd say the margins is you did in the first quarter, you'd see as a sustainable given as input costs [indiscernible] because of the demand...
componenttext: So you'd say the margins is you did in the first quarter, you'd see as a sustainable given as input costs [indiscernible] because of the demand...

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the margins rolled off in the first quarter in the markets side, but we're seeing improvement. And I think the demand sides continue to get better, so we're seeing tightening on that. And so I think the demand side is actually going to be a po
componenttext: And I think the margins rolled off in the first quarter in the markets side, but we're seeing improvement. And I think the demand sides continue to get better, so we're seeing tightening on that. And so I think the demand side is actually going to be a positive as we look out to the rest of the year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Jeff Dietert with Simmons is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on the chemical margin discussion, are you seeing margins widen as we move through April with increase in oil price? And I noticed that utilization actually was going down in the second quarter relative to their first quarter. Could you talk
componenttext: Following up on the chemical margin discussion, are you seeing margins widen as we move through April with increase in oil price? And I noticed that utilization actually was going down in the second quarter relative to their first quarter. Could you talk about these topics?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- I'll hit the utilization first since it -- I would say that the turnarounds in the industry and CPChem has a cracker in turnaround as well, that you're seeing utilizations fall from a turnaround perspective. And we've always felt '16 was going t
componenttext: So the -- I'll hit the utilization first since it -- I would say that the turnarounds in the industry and CPChem has a cracker in turnaround as well, that you're seeing utilizations fall from a turnaround perspective. And we've always felt '16 was going to be a fairly heavy turnaround for the U.S. industry. And as far as the current pricing, we are seeing strengthening in that on the derivatives side. And I think that's both in response to demand as well you're now seeing move up in crude oil. you're seeing 2 things kind of influence that price from a global standpoint on, say, the polyethylene is the key derivative for that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second, following up on the gas distillate yields. It's my understanding gasoline cracks are higher than distillate cracks. There's kind of a shift towards maximizing gasoline. as you look at distillate cracks at half the level they were last year, are th
componenttext: Second, following up on the gas distillate yields. It's my understanding gasoline cracks are higher than distillate cracks. There's kind of a shift towards maximizing gasoline. as you look at distillate cracks at half the level they were last year, are there incremental things you can do year-on-year to increase gasoline yield and perhaps moderate distillate yield?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Greg mentioned some of the things that we're doing to increase conversion across FCCs and convert some of that feed into that. Beyond that, it's a longer-term investment and we'd have to see a longer-term signal. But I think I look at distillate a
componenttext: I think Greg mentioned some of the things that we're doing to increase conversion across FCCs and convert some of that feed into that. Beyond that, it's a longer-term investment and we'd have to see a longer-term signal. But I think I look at distillate also say that if the economy industrial across the world picks up, you will see more distillate demand. And that's been a factor in the distillate -- sluggish distillate demand we're seeing. We're seeing good consumer demand, weaker industrial. And so I think you've got to take a view that industrial piece at some point does come back. And I think we're seeing signs of that perhaps in Asia, but that's a big piece of that trade piece in the distillate that really drives industrial side. So I think we look at this and say it's not clear that you've got a permanent separation. we've got to think about that form an investment standpoint.

componenttext: Okay. So what we're seeing is we're seeing NGL volumes still hanging in there. You would expect with the drilling activity, you would -- eventually expect to see that to break over a bit. we're still seeing good NGL volumes coming in into the Gulf Coast. The Permian in particular looks really good, and I think that probably what you see on the crude side. The Eagle Ford; being -- we're seeing decline rates both on the NGL and crude. But overall, NGL volumes have been up to kind of holding flat. And in fact, we had record propane production, but you've got refinery input on the propane side as well, which may go back to gasoline mode. so I'd say on the NGL side, we've seen it hold. But as crude oil prices recover and drilling resumes, and you believe that North America is going to have that incremental call, [ph] we're still bullish that the NGL supply is going to continue to increase.

I think there's just a lot of activity there, and I think the economics behind the drilling and the basins that we're touching are driving that. componenttext: I think you've got the see that drilling resume to really start to see that come back. And I suspect we'll continue to see NGL volumes kind of holding steady, perhaps decline a bit. And then it takes time, I think, would be our be on the E&P side to kind of restart all of that activity. And your guess is as good as mine about exactly where they are. But w x the capital expenditures budgets where they are on the upstream, it's hard to see that you're going to see a lot of extra volume over the next 12 months until that program ramps back up. And so sustained crude oil prices will help drive that. And I think -- over a period of months, that's what you'll begin to see. But I think we're kind of -- I think our view's we're probably getting closer to the bottom. We may stay here a while, and we're certainly going to seeing you continue to see volatility.

componenttext: Yes, I think on the volume side, we haven't wavered that. It's going to come up. There will be good demand globally. You always going to get the cracker stable. So I think that's the good news. On the margin side, the spread between ethane and crude and that ultimately that crude prices sets those, say, polyethylene or derivative price. That's narrowed a bit. I think that our view would be that that's an upfront a little bit of the headwind. But as you look out and if you believe crude comes back to another level above $60. And I think we look at the premises still are pretty much in line with our investment thesis. I think we still like it. from a return standpoint even in today's margins, there's a significant cost advantage with this new complex on the operating side of the business that offsets some of that margin. But I think we still have expectations that this will be a very strong profit driver for CPChem, for us. Our share of that on the EBITDA basis incrementally as that -- just crackers starts up is roughly $500 million with some upside.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext:
Welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sally, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to Rosy Zuklic, General Manager, Investor Relations. Rosy, you may begin.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The presentation material we will be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website, along with supplemental financial and operating information.
Slide 2 contains our safe harbor statement. It is a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from today's comments. Factors that could cause our actual results to differ are included here as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg Garland for some opening remarks. Greg?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. We had a good operating quarter running well across all of our businesses. However, weaker margin has a significant impact on our earnings this quarter. In Refining, distillate crack spreads
componenttext:
Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. We had a good operating quarter running well across all of our businesses. However, weaker margin has a significant impact on our earnings this quarter. In Refining, distillate crack spreads were the lowest since 2010. In Chemicals, benchmark industry olefin chain margins were down from last quarter, and Midstream was impacted by lower NGL prices. We experienced solid results from our Marketing and Specialties business.
Total adjusted earnings were $360 million. And excluding working capital changes, we generated $722 million in cash from operations. We remain focused on operating excellence and completing our growth projects in Midstream and Chemicals where we see great value in opportunity long term. We're maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation and believe that our strong balance sheet is a competitive advantage that positions as well to execute our plans to the commodity price cycles.
During the quarter, we reinvested $750 million back into the business, and we distributed $687 million to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. Since May of 2012, we returned $11.8 billion to shareholders through dividends and our repurchase or exchange of 115 million shares. We continue to target a 60-40 split between reinvestment in our business and distributions back to our shareholders, and we've targeted another dividend increase this year of at least 10%.
We've made good progress on our major growth projects. In Midstream, we received all the permits necessary for the Dakota Access Pipeline to start laying pipe in May, and we would expect and on-schedule completion by year-end. In the Gulf Coast, the Beaumont Terminal expansion is going well. The terminal currently has 7.1 million barrels of storage capacity. We have 3.2 million barrels of new capacity under construction. Longer term, this facility can expand to 16 million barrels of storage capacity. 
Also, development of the first phase of the Sweeny hub is nearing completion. The LPG export terminal is 80% complete, is on time and on budget. The completion of the terminal will represent a major step in the development of a world-class energy complex with integrated Refining, Chemical and Midstream assets. 
PSXP remains an important part of our Midstream growth strategy. The fee-based assets within its portfolio continue to perform well. PSXP increased its limited partner distributions by 5% this quarter and remains on track to achieve a steady growth objective of a 5-year, 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
DCP Midstream is reducing its cash breakeven through self-help initiatives and expects to achieve breakeven and NGL prices below $0.35 per gallon this year. They're reducing costs, cutting capital substantially and converting commodity-exposed contracts to fee-based to improve financial strength and flexibility. 
In addition, the equity contributions from the owners last year strengthened the balance sheet, increased fee-based earnings and positioned DCP for success in the future. We expect the DCP will be self-funded going forward.
In Chemicals, demand for consumer products remain strong. In response, CPChem continues to run at high rates across its system. Because CPChem's primary production centers are in North America and in the Middle East, underpinned by advantaged feedstocks, we believe CPChem's asset base provides us with a competitive advantage. CPChem continues to advance the U.S. Gulf Coast Petrochemicals Project. It is now 75% complete, with expected start-up in mid-2017. Once running, CPChem's global ethylene and polyethylene capacity will increase by approximately 1/3. 
In Refining, we see good gasoline supply and demand fundamentals for the remainder the year, and we expect strong demand as we head into the summer driving season. Our focus in Refining is operating excellence, maintaining our cost and capital discipline, increasing returns to selective investment. We invested in projects that are quick payoff, low cost and high return. During the quarter, we advanced several of these Refining projects. At the Wood River refinery, we're undergoing debottlenecking and are on schedule for completion in the third quarter. At Bayway, work on the FCC modernization is on schedule. At the Billings refinery, effort is underway to increase the amount of heavy Canadian crude we can run to 100%. Each of these projects has a projected return on investment of about 30%.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to review the quarter results. Kevin?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, first quarter adjusted earnings were $360 million or $0.67 per share. Reported net income was $385 million. Excluding working capital, cash from operations was $722 million. Capital spending for the quarter
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, first quarter adjusted earnings were $360 million or $0.67 per share. Reported net income was $385 million. Excluding working capital, cash from operations was $722 million. Capital spending for the quarter was $750 million, with approximately $450 million spent in Midstream, primarily on our growth projects. Distributions to shareholders in the first quarter totaled $687 million, including $296 million in dividends and $391 million in share repurchases. At the end of the first quarter, our debt-to-capital ratio was 27%. And after taking into account our ending cash balance, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 23%. Annualized adjusted return on capital employed was 5%. Our adjusted effective income tax rate is 33%.
Slide 5 compares first quarter 2016 and fourth quarter 2015 adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were down $350 million, primarily driven by lower results in Refining. Next, we will cover each of the segments individually.  
I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. Transportation continues to generate stable earnings. The NGL business progressed construction on the Freeport LPG Export Terminal. Fractionator utilization was reduced due to turnarounds and the impact of ethane rejection on feedstock composition. Included in the transportation and NGL results is the contribution from Phillips 66 Partners. During the quarter PSXP contributed earnings of $32 million to the Midstream segment. Distributions to Phillips 66 from our LP and GP interests increased 7% over the fourth quarter. DCP Midstream continues to work on its self-help initiatives to reduce costs, manage its portfolio and restructure contracts.
On Slide 7, Midstream's first quarter adjusted earnings were $40 million, down $2 million from the fourth quarter. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter were $72 million, down $6 million from the prior quarter, driven by lower equity earnings from Rockies Express pipeline and Explorer pipeline. NGL adjusted losses were $11 million for the first quarter. A $9 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by seasonal storage activity, partially offset by lower tax expense. Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were lower in the first quarter, primarily due to improved reliability and contract restructuring efforts, partially offset by the impact of lower commodity prices.
In Chemicals, the global olefins and polyolefins capacity utilization rate for the quarter was 93%, and margins were lower. SA&S had improved equity earnings due to higher volumes at equity affiliates. 
As shown on Slide 9, first quarter adjusted earnings for Chemicals were $156 million, down from $182 million in the fourth quarter. In olefins and polyolefins, the decrease of $36 million was largely due to lower margins, driven by reduced polyethylene sales prices. This was partially offset by higher polyethylene sales volumes and lower controllable costs. Adjusted earnings for SA&S increased by $7 million on higher equity earnings from increased sales volumes due to fourth quarter turnaround activities at CPChem's equity affiliates.
In Refining, realized margins were $7.11 per barrel for the quarter as market crack spreads decreased significantly from the prior quarter. Gasoline market cracks were down 14% from the fourth quarter due in part to the impact of higher-than-normal industry gasoline production in the fourth quarter as well as the impacts of butane blending and seasonally lower demand. Distillate market cracks were at a 6-year low. Market capture decreased from 74% in the fourth quarter to 67% in the first quarter. Clean product yield fell to 82%, with gasoline yield at 43%. These yields reflect the impact of turnaround activity as well as accelerated maintenance on secondary units due to the low-margin environment. Pretax turnaround costs were $115 million, $35 million lower than guidance due to the deferral of some catalyst change out activity.
Slide 11 shows a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. The Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $86 million, down $290 million from last quarter. The reduction was largely due to lower market cracks. Atlantic Basin adjusted earnings decreased this quarter, primarily due to lower volumes and inventory impacts. The Gulf Coast region saw lower margins and reduced volumes due to planned maintenance and unplanned downtime. In the Gulf Coast region as well as the Central Corridor, we had unplanned downtime as we undertook discretionary maintenance in a low-margin environment. In the Central Corridor, lower margins accounted for the majority of the reduction in adjusted earnings from the fourth quarter as market cracks were 24% lower. On the West Coast, market cracks were 26% lower. Reduced margins were mostly offset by improvements in controllable costs and inventory impacts. Santa Maria continued to be affected by the Plains pipeline outage. 
Next, we will cover market capture on Slide 12. Our worldwide realized margin was $7.11 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack of $10.64 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 67%. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries as it relates to our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 82% clean product yield for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. Losses due to secondary products decreased this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as coke and NGLs narrowed. Feedstock advantage was slightly higher than the fourth quarter, but crude differentials generally remained tight. The other category mainly includes costs associated with RINs, outgoing freight, product differentials and inventory impacts.
Let's move to Marketing and Specialties where we posted a good quarter, thanks to healthy U.S. margins and volumes. Specialties saw higher earnings on improved margins.  
Slide 14 shows adjusted earnings for M&S in the first quarter of $205 million, down $22 million from the fourth quarter. In Marketing and Other, the $36 million decrease was largely due to lower biodiesel tax credits and lower margins in international Marketing. This was partially offset by higher U.S. marketing margins. Specialties adjusted earnings increased to $43 million, primarily due to improved base oil margins.
On Slide 15, the Corporate and Other expense had aftertax net costs of $127 million this quarter, an increase of $10 million from the fourth quarter. Net interest expense increased by $7 million, primarily due to lower capitalized interest associated with the start-up of Sweeny Fractionator One, while corporate overhead and other expenses increased by $3 million due to the timing of legal and environmental charges.
Slide 16 shows cash flow for the quarter. We began the year with a cash balance of $3.1 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations was $722 million. Working capital changes reduced cash flow by $464 million. The cash benefit of a U.S. tax refund received in the quarter was more than offset by the customary first quarter inventory build and the timing of marketing receipts and crude cargo payments. We funded $750 million of capital expenditures and investments, and we distributed nearly $700 million to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the quarter with 526 million shares  outstanding. At the end of the quarter, our cash balance was $1.7 billion.
This concludes my review of the financial and operational results. 
Next, I'll cover a few outlook items. In the second quarter, in Chemicals, we expect the global O&P utilization rate to be in the low 90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rate to be in the mid-90s and before-tax turnaround expenses to be approximately $100 million. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $120 million and $125 million. And companywide, we expect the effective income tax rate to be in the mid-30s. 
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch is online with a question.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I could ask you about the impact of run cuts in the quarter. Because my understanding is earlier in the quarter, you guys had deliberately taken some steps to basically run at lower rates. And obviously, I'm wondering if that was part of wha
componenttext:
I wonder if I could ask you about the impact of run cuts in the quarter. Because my understanding is earlier in the quarter, you guys had deliberately taken some steps to basically run at lower 
rates. And obviously, I'm wondering if that was part of what fell behind the Refining result in the quarter. And my follow-up, I guess, is also Refining related to the diesel overhang we see currently. Obviously, you guys are a little bit more exposed to that. I'd just love to get your perspective on how you see -- if you see that cleaning up and how you see that playing out, let's say, over the next 3 to 6 months. And I'll leave it there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start and then, Tim, you can kind of give the overlook on these. So we ran really hard January and March, and we slowed down in February. It's really the story. I think the interesting thing is, we accelerated some maintenance activity, but a lot
componenttext: So I'll start and then, Tim, you can kind of give the overlook on these. So we ran really hard January and March, and we slowed down in February. It's really the story. I think the interesting thing is, we accelerated some maintenance activity, but a lot of it was on secondary units. And it really didn't affect the overall utilization as much as you might suspect, but we did build some intermediate inventory during the quarter. So I think that's the major impact in terms of the operations. And Tim, why don't you hit on the outlook in terms of distillate?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, on the distillate side, I think exports are the key to really clearing the length in North America. And we're seeing good demand in China, India, West Africa and Latin America, and so I think that continues. That said, I think distillate for us
componenttext: Yes, Doug, on the distillate side, I think exports are the key to really clearing the length in North America. And we're seeing good demand in China, India, West Africa and Latin America, and so I think that continues. That said, I think distillate for us continues to look to be the challenge for the market as we go forward. But I think it will clear, but it's really turning into more of a by-product from a gasoline production standpoint. So I think as long as export markets are open, that will continue to clear the U.S.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a quick follow-up. So you're planning to run your refineries back up into the mid-90s in the second quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, if margins are so challenging in your distillate heavy yield, why would you continue to -- or you just goi
componenttext: Maybe just a quick follow-up. So you're planning to run your refineries back up into the mid-90s in the second quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, if margins are so challenging in your distillate heavy yield, why would you continue to -- or you just going to press into that? Or do you think it will be more voluntary run cuts as we go through the next 3 to 6 months? It doesn't sound like it.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. I think that we're seeing strong gasoline cracks. I mean, they've really recovered in March and now in April, the summer driving season. That's going to drive the overall refinery utilization. It certainly drives our thinking. And then the dist
componenttext: Yes, Doug. I think that we're seeing strong gasoline cracks. I mean, they've really recovered in March and now in April, the summer driving season. That's going to drive the overall refinery utilization. It certainly drives our thinking. And then the distillate piece, the crack spread is really relatively stable where it is and has been, but I think that's the piece where we're looking the exports to clear that. But I think the gasoline is pulling the refinery utilization up across the industry.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Blake Fernandez with Howard Weil is online with a question.
componenttext: Blake Fernandez with Howard Weil is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to follow up on Doug's distillate question, do you have any sense that maybe once we reaccelerate activity here in the U.S. from a drilling perspective, do you think that's a critical component of kind of cleaning up the disparity we're seeing
componenttext: Maybe just to follow up on Doug's distillate question, do you have any sense that maybe once we reaccelerate activity here in the U.S. from a drilling perspective, do you think that's a critical component of kind of cleaning up the disparity we're seeing between demand and maybe some of these building inventories on the distillate side?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's part of the equation, but it's -- I mean, right now, it's probably less than 2% of total distillates demand, but it's helpful. It was maybe 40,000 or 50,000 barrels a day is our estimate.
componenttext: It's part of the equation, but it's -- I mean, right now, it's probably less than 2% of total distillates demand, but it's helpful. It was maybe 40,000 or 50,000 barrels a day is our estimate.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. That's helpful. The second piece, and maybe this a question for Kevin. The buyback seem to continue at a fairly robust rate, continuing the macro environment. Just curious, your thinking about ratability of the buyback program and kind of the
componenttext: Okay, good. That's helpful. The second piece, and maybe this a question for Kevin. The buyback seem to continue at a fairly robust rate, continuing the macro environment. Just curious, your thinking about ratability of the buyback program and kind of the seasonality of what we would expect on the cash flow.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll take it, then Kevin can step in. So I kind of think about this in several different buckets. The first bucket is really, I don't think the first quarter is reflective of our view of what 2016 is going to be. You've seen cracks have gone from
componenttext: Yes. So I'll take it, then Kevin can step in. So I kind of think about this in several different buckets. The first bucket is really, I don't think the first quarter is reflective of our view of what 2016 is going to be. You've seen cracks have gone from $10 to $15. We've seen NGLs move from $0.37 to $0.47, $0.48. We're seeing good demand for transportation fuels, gasoline. We're seeing good demand for petrochemicals. We're seeing margins up a couple of cents, and we think margins will continue to improve in the petchem chain. So we think that '16 is to kind of a $4 billion to $5 billion-type cash generation year from us from operations. Second, I would say our view is that for high-quality MLPs, we think that the equity markets are open, and that we would expect between some combination of debt and equity, we'd raise between $1 billion and $2 billion back into PSX this year. So this kind of moves you to $5 billion to $7 billion of cash if you want to think about it that way. We can afford a $3.9 billion capital program, $1.2 billion dividend and $1 billion to $2 billion of share repurchases given that. I will say just though, we're looking at things going on. And we're going through every line item in the capital budget, both for '16 and '17. And we're assuring that our premises that we started with are still valid and that these projects are going to generate returns that are acceptable and meet our requirements. And so we'll be looking at that going forward into this year.

componenttext: No, Tim. I'm sorry, Tim, Tim, I'm sorry. I probably I did not make my question. I'm looking specifically for naphtha that, whether it's more economic to directly blend brand it into the gasoline pool in U.S. and then add octane to begin to finished gasoline, or that it's better to take them out in U.S. into the overseas to be used as a petrochemical feedstock, and the insight from you guys, given you are also a big petrochemical producer.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, clearly naphtha demands increased around the world, but we still see the best value to go into gasoline pool here, pull it with octane to blend it up. But with the demand we're seeing in gasoline, that's still the preference that we have.
componenttext: Yes, clearly naphtha demands increased around the world, but we still see the best value to go into gasoline pool here, pull it with octane to blend it up. But with the demand we're seeing in gasoline, that's still the preference that we have.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Paul, we haven't broken out at that level of detail. As you know, we report at the sort of NGL subsegment within our Midstream business. At the PSXP level, you can see there what they see on the fractionator, but that's a different look to the Phillips
componenttext: So Paul, we haven't broken out at that level of detail. As you know, we report at the sort of NGL subsegment within our Midstream business. At the PSXP level, you can see there what they see on the fractionator, but that's a different look to the Phillips 66 look. So at this point, that's not a level of granularity that we've broken out at this time. Obviously, the fractionator just started up at the end of last year. So it's still kind of going through that start-up, a little bit of incremental costs that you wouldn't expect to be recurring. And volume's a little bit lower than capacity, given the feedstock composition. But ultimately, the full value is going to come when you see the export terminal up and running and get full contribution.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, on Tier 3, can you tell us where are you in the process?

componenttextpreview: So we're in the midst of really reinvesting to deal with the -- taking more sulfur out across our system. So we have a number of projects that, at our refineries, that we're in the process of implementing to complete that. But that's been a piece of our m
componenttext: So we're in the midst of really reinvesting to deal with the -- taking more sulfur out across our system. So we have a number of projects that, at our refineries, that we're in the process of implementing to complete that. But that's been a piece of our maintenance capital or long-term maintenance capital over the last 7 years and in the next year so to complete that.

componenttext: They will come in compliance at different times, given the investment schedule through 2018 that will hit, Paul. I think we have investment at most to the other refineries for Tier 3, some more than others.

componenttext: Okay. The final question. Greg, I hear you about -- that the -- how to balance the cash flow and expecting $1 billion to $2 billion of NPL x the cash contribution to the C corp. To the degree, if that didn't materialize, should we assume that you're going to borrow money that you continue to fund the temporary shortfall on the buyback? Or that the buyback will take a backseat?

componenttext: So if in the event that the MLP market is not available there to raise additional equity or debt for PSXP, and so as a result, that you won't get that $1 billion to $2 billion of the cash you expect from the subsidiary into the C corp, should we assume, because you review it as a temporary development, that you would just borrow money in the C corp to fund the buyback? Or that the buyback will take a pause and wait until that you have the cash to do so?

componenttext: Well, I think that we said we could flex between $1 billion to $2 billion, and that's kind of the guidance we've given. But I would just kind of reiterate, we feel pretty strongly that the markets are going to be open to us.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Greg, it relates to your capital flexibility in 2016 and '17 as we see some volatility in your business. I mean, I know you talked about the expected recovery to cash flow. Yet, as much as -- how much of the capital plans are flexible w
componenttext: My first question, Greg, it relates to your capital flexibility in 2016 and '17 as we see some volatility in your business. I mean, I know you talked about the expected recovery to cash flow. Yet, as much as -- how much of the capital plans are flexible when you think about 2016 and 2017? And what drives how you flex that?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say, we kind of guided or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunities
componenttext: Yes, so I would say, we kind of guided or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunities. In terms of the $3.9 billion this year and how much flex do we have, I would say we're still working through that and looking at that. But it's probably $500 million-ish in terms of the amount of flex that we actually have this year.
