headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Greg, it relates to your capital flexibility in 2016 and '17 as we see some volatility in your business. I mean, I know you talked about the expected recovery to cash flow. Yet, as much as -- how much of the capital plans are flexible w
componenttext: My first question, Greg, it relates to your capital flexibility in 2016 and '17 as we see some volatility in your business. I mean, I know you talked about the expected recovery to cash flow. Yet, as much as -- how much of the capital plans are flexible when you think about 2016 and 2017? And what drives how you flex that?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say, we kind of guided or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth of kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunit
componenttext: Yes, so I would say, we kind of guided or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth of kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunities. In terms of the $3.9 billion this year and how much flex do we have, I would say we're still working through that and looking at that. But it's probably $500 million-ish in terms of the amount of flex that we actually have this year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And second on Midstream, results were weaker than expected there, at least versus our numbers. Maybe you could discuss some of the drivers there, I mean, likely related to frac start-up, and how those factors impacted results and may trend through
componenttext: Got it. And second on Midstream, results were weaker than expected there, at least versus our numbers. Maybe you could discuss some of the drivers there, I mean, likely related to frac start-up, and how those factors impacted results and may trend through '16. I imagine some of those would unwind.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, it's Tim. So basically, you look at transportation segment, consistent earnings quarter-to-quarter, so the DCP was slightly improved as well. So that leaves you with the NGL, and that's largely the impacts -- some commercial impacts on the inve
componenttext: Yes, Evan, it's Tim. So basically, you look at transportation segment, consistent earnings quarter-to-quarter, so the DCP was slightly improved as well. So that leaves you with the NGL, and that's largely the impacts -- some commercial impacts on the inventory, some higher costs associated with the start-up of the frac, and that's really -- as we line that out, we expect that to come more in line.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Anything relating to the...
componenttext: Right. Anything relating to the...

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think we should mention, we had a turnaround at our GCF frac, so the expenses were up as well with that turnaround.
componenttext: Oh, I think we should mention, we had a turnaround at our GCF frac, so the expenses were up as well with that turnaround.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add, Evan, on DCP, so it was improved results, but it was still a loss for the quarter on an adjusted basis. And that reflects the sort of mid-30s NGL prices, which have recovered quite a bit since then. So that result should be getting
componenttext: Yes, I would just add, Evan, on DCP, so it was improved results, but it was still a loss for the quarter on an adjusted basis. And that reflects the sort of mid-30s NGL prices, which have recovered quite a bit since then. So that result should be getting back to something a little bit more respectable.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger Read with Wells Fargo is online with a question.
componenttext: Roger Read with Wells Fargo is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe coming back to a little bit on the question on the ability to run at the high levels on the Refining side and the export market. Can you give us an idea of what export volumes have been and kind of what you would anticipate as we go into the su
componenttext: Just maybe coming back to a little bit on the question on the ability to run at the high levels on the Refining side and the export market. Can you give us an idea of what export volumes have been and kind of what you would anticipate as we go into the summer? I mean, you made the comment about as long as the market remains open. Just kind of curious what that means in a numerical sense.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been running, essentially, at mid-90s utilization, so that's not changing. And so this last quarter, we ran 126,000, 127,000 barrels a day of exports. And so from our standpoint, that's a very manageable amount to place. But our utilization rea
componenttext: Yes, we've been running, essentially, at mid-90s utilization, so that's not changing. And so this last quarter, we ran 126,000, 127,000 barrels a day of exports. And so from our standpoint, that's a very manageable amount to place. But our utilization really kind of stays where we were. And so I think that's the key at our Gulf Coast Refineries to balance that distillate.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any more -- or any particular level of flexibility we should consider here between gasoline and the distillate side? Or are you pretty well where you can go in the, say, next 12 months or so?
componenttext: And any more -- or any particular level of flexibility we should consider here between gasoline and the distillate side? Or are you pretty well where you can go in the, say, next 12 months or so?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've been running pretty much max gasoline as most of the industry has. We can probably -- we can flex about 3% to 4% between gasoline and diesel. So we do have some projects that are coming on that will, directionally, move us more towards
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been running pretty much max gasoline as most of the industry has. We can probably -- we can flex about 3% to 4% between gasoline and diesel. So we do have some projects that are coming on that will, directionally, move us more towards gasoline, like the modernization of the FCC at Bayway is a good example of that and some of the things we're doing at Wood River. But I think on balance, you should expect we're going to be in kind of 43% to 45%-type gasoline yields for '16.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil Gresh with JPMorgan is online with a question.
componenttext: Phil Gresh with JPMorgan is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, on the third quarter call last year, I'd asked about the timing of reaching full run rate on the 2 projects, the 400 million to 500 million. I was just wondering if you could give an update on that. Obviously, it's a little bit of a slow s
componenttext: First question, on the third quarter call last year, I'd asked about the timing of reaching full run rate on the 2 projects, the 400 million to 500 million. I was just wondering if you could give an update on that. Obviously, it's a little bit of a slow start on the NGL side. It sounds like LPG is on time, but there is a market exposure piece there. So as we go through '17, I mean, what level are you, of the 400 million to 500 million, are you confident with at this point?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the 400 million to 500 million is really the total for the fractionation, and that's a smaller piece of that total then, that LPG terminal and the access. And we've always said 20%, 30% of that is commodity type of exposure. So I think there's always w
componenttext: So the 400 million to 500 million is really the total for the fractionation, and that's a smaller piece of that total then, that LPG terminal and the access. And we've always said 20%, 30% of that is commodity type of exposure. So I think there's always where the market structure is going to be and where that arb is going to be between the Gulf Coast and export markets in Asia, Europe or Latin America. So as this export terminal completes late this year and you go through start-up, I think you start to see that impact really -- full-chain value impact, really start to hit late this year in 2017. And I think the real question is going to be is, what is that commercial piece of that going to be? So that's why we've always framed it a bit from the 400 million to 500 million in terms of where the market goes. But if crude prices recover, globally, I think that increases that arb naturally when we see that. So I think that's a variable that's a piece of that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So x the arb piece, you'd say -- just on the execution front and the rest, you're comfortable like mid-'17, you could hit the full run rate on the rest?
componenttext: So x the arb piece, you'd say -- just on the execution front and the rest, you're comfortable like mid-'17, you could hit the full run rate on the rest?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think the frac is going to be -- when you think about composition, you think about that, that comes up. It's a relatively small contribution. Then it's really about the cargoes. We have 8 cargoes that we're looking at. So we continue to wor
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the frac is going to be -- when you think about composition, you think about that, that comes up. It's a relatively small contribution. Then it's really about the cargoes. We have 8 cargoes that we're looking at. So we continue to work contracts. And then we have commercial opportunity, and there's always spot business with that. But we believe the supply is there to fill that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is just on the NGL side, particularly from the chemicals angle. I'm just kind of wondering how you're thinking about input cost pricing with respect to ethane, propane. Obviously, there's some improved sentiment here around the expor
componenttext: Okay. Second question is just on the NGL side, particularly from the chemicals angle. I'm just kind of wondering how you're thinking about input cost pricing with respect to ethane, propane. Obviously, there's some improved sentiment here around the export impact, the demand impact on NGLs. I'm just wondering how you think about both availability and the cost of the NGLs for your Chemicals business.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think as we've thought about the -- and we'll call it the NGL side, we're basically seeing parity today between ethane, propane and butane in terms of the value and the cracking slate. And our view has been that the export netback price will kind of
componenttext: So I think as we've thought about the -- and we'll call it the NGL side, we're basically seeing parity today between ethane, propane and butane in terms of the value and the cracking slate. And our view has been that the export netback price will kind of set a price for propane, butane. And then the ethane could reach that perhaps in terms of cracking parity, but the balance really comes about which of those feedstocks you select. But the export netback really becomes the upper limit of what we set for the cracking value. Ethane, in our view, giving -- coming out of rejection and what we see on the start-up of the projects, should still remain at a competitive disadvantage for the long term. And so I think it really is that interplay somewhere between gas value and propane, butane parity and the cracking that determines that. But we would expect when the new crackers start up that ethane prices will come up somewhat to pull some of that ethane back out of the gas stream. But we're still -- the bottom line is we're still bullish on the operating rate side on Chemicals as well as the competitive advantage that you get from ethane and LPG cracking.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good thing I would say about the petrochemical environment right now, you really -- it is a demand pull that's pulling values. And it's really not destock cost that's setting value in the market today.
componenttext: The good thing I would say about the petrochemical environment right now, you really -- it is a demand pull that's pulling values. And it's really not destock cost that's setting value in the market today.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you'd say that the margins that you've achieved, let's say, in the first quarter, you'd see as sustainable even if input costs rose, because of the demand?
componenttext: So you'd say that the margins that you've achieved, let's say, in the first quarter, you'd see as sustainable even if input costs rose, because of the demand?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the margins rolled off in the first quarter in the markets side, but we're seeing improvement. And I think the demand side has continued to get better, so we're seeing tightening on that. And so I think the demand side is actually going to be
componenttext: Yes, I think the margins rolled off in the first quarter in the markets side, but we're seeing improvement. And I think the demand side has continued to get better, so we're seeing tightening on that. And so I think the demand side is actually going to be a positive as we look out to the rest of the year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff Dietert with Simmons is online with a question.
componenttext: Jeff Dietert with Simmons is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on the Chemical margin discussion, are you seeing margins widen as we move through April with the increase in oil price? And I noticed that utilization actually was going down in the second quarter relative to first quarter. Could you talk ab
componenttext: Following up on the Chemical margin discussion, are you seeing margins widen as we move through April with the increase in oil price? And I noticed that utilization actually was going down in the second quarter relative to first quarter. Could you talk about these topics?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll hit the utilization first since it -- I would say that with turnarounds in the industry, and CPChem currently has a cracker in turnaround as well, that you're seeing utilizations fall from a turnaround perspective. And we've always felt '16 was go
componenttext: So I'll hit the utilization first since it -- I would say that with turnarounds in the industry, and CPChem currently has a cracker in turnaround as well, that you're seeing utilizations fall from a turnaround perspective. And we've always felt '16 was going to be a fairly heavy turnaround for the U.S. industry. And as far as the current pricing, we're seeing strengthening in that on the derivative side. And I think that's both the response to both demand as well as you're now seeing the move-up in crude oil. So you're seeing 2 things that kind of influence that price from a global standpoint, on the, say, the polyethylene is the key derivative for that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And second, following up on the gasoline versus distillate yield. It's my understanding, once gasoline cracks are higher than distillate cracks, there's kind of a shift towards maximizing gasoline. But as you look at distillate cracks at half the le
componenttext: Okay. And second, following up on the gasoline versus distillate yield. It's my understanding, once gasoline cracks are higher than distillate cracks, there's kind of a shift towards maximizing gasoline. But as you look at distillate cracks at half the level they were last year, are there incremental things you can do year-on-year to increase gasoline yield and perhaps moderate distillate yield?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Greg alluded to some of the things we're doing to increase conversion across FCCs and convert some of that feed into that. Beyond that, it's a longer-term investment, and we'd have to see a longer-term signal. But I think I look at distillate and
componenttext: I think Greg alluded to some of the things we're doing to increase conversion across FCCs and convert some of that feed into that. Beyond that, it's a longer-term investment, and we'd have to see a longer-term signal. But I think I look at distillate and also say that if the economy, industrially, across the world picks up, you will see more distillate demand. And that's been a factor in the distillate -- sluggish distillate demand that we're seeing. And we're seeing good consumer demand, weaker industrial. And so I think you've got to take a view that the industrial piece at some point does come back. And I think we're seeing signs of that, perhaps, in Asia, but that's a big piece of the trade piece in the distillate that really drives the industrial side. So I think we look at this and say, it's not clear that you've got a permanent separation. We've got to think about that from an investment standpoint.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research is online with a question.
componenttext: Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've kind of gone beyond the answer to this question, which is about the NGL market. You've talked about pricing. Could you just update us, given the changes in the market, on how volumes have shifted both in terms of just over the past year, but also t
componenttext: You've kind of gone beyond the answer to this question, which is about the NGL market. You've talked about pricing. Could you just update us, given the changes in the market, on how volumes have shifted both in terms of just over the past year, but also to any extent that your outlook has shifted and especially the impact you might have on market? I know you've addressed this kind of from a price standpoint, but could you talk about volume?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the raw NGL volumes, Paul?
componenttext: On the raw NGL volumes, Paul?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we always struggle with this market because it's just sort of nebulous area but...
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we always struggle with this market because it's just sort of nebulous area but...

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what we're seeing is we're seeing NGL volumes still hanging in there. You would expect with drilling activity, you would eventually expect to see that to break over a bit. But we're still seeing good NGL volumes coming in into the Gulf Coast. The
componenttext: Okay. So what we're seeing is we're seeing NGL volumes still hanging in there. You would expect with drilling activity, you would eventually expect to see that to break over a bit. But we're still seeing good NGL volumes coming in into the Gulf Coast. The Permian, in particular, looks really good. And I think that ties back to what you see on the crude side. The Eagle Ford being -- we're seeing decline rates both on NGL and crude. But overall, NGL volumes have been up to kind of holding flat. And in fact, we had record propane production, but you've got a refinery input on the propane side as well, which may tie back to gasoline mode. So I'd say, on the NGL side we've seen it hold, and as crude oil prices recover and drilling resumes and if you believe that North America is going to have that incremental call, we're still bullish that the NGL supply is going to continue to increase.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: What do you attribute the volumes surprisingly holding up to?
componenttext: What do you attribute the volumes surprisingly holding up to?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just we see kind of the same story on the crude side. I think there's just a lot of latent activity there, and then I think the economics behind the drilling and the basins that we're touching are driving that. So we've seen that hold, and I
componenttext: I think it's just we see kind of the same story on the crude side. I think there's just a lot of latent activity there, and then I think the economics behind the drilling and the basins that we're touching are driving that. So we've seen that hold, and I think it just reflects what the production side of the business is seeing on the E&P side.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you might almost be thinking that we're actually bottoming out in terms of volumes and, actually, will hold or go higher from here?
componenttext: So you might almost be thinking that we're actually bottoming out in terms of volumes and, actually, will hold or go higher from here?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you've got to see that drilling resume to really start to see that come back. And I suspect we'll continue to see NGL volumes kind of holding steady, perhaps decline a bit. And then it takes time, I think, would be our view on the E&P side to kind
componenttext: I think you've got to see that drilling resume to really start to see that come back. And I suspect we'll continue to see NGL volumes kind of holding steady, perhaps decline a bit. And then it takes time, I think, would be our view on the E&P side to kind of restart all that activity. And your guess is as good as mine about exactly where they are. But with the capital expenditures budgets where they are on the upstream, it's hard to see that you're going to see a lot of extra volume over the next 12 months until that program ramps back up. And so sustained crude oil prices would help drive that. And we think over a period of months that's what you'll begin to see. But I think we're kind of -- and I think our view is, we're probably getting closer to the bottom. We may stay here a while. And we're certainly going to continue to see volatility.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. I was working on the idea that your guess would be better than mine. This may be a very quick answer, and I fully understand if it is. But you've had a significant shift in shareholder structure over the past year or so. Has that had any impac
componenttext: Understood. I was working on the idea that your guess would be better than mine. This may be a very quick answer, and I fully understand if it is. But you've had a significant shift in shareholder structure over the past year or so. Has that had any impact on your board or on your strategy?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're pretty open about what our strategy is. It's been very consistent, and so you can draw your own conclusion from that. The board is still the same. We have a great board, and we have a great shareholder base. So I think that's how I'd answer
componenttext: I think we're pretty open about what our strategy is. It's been very consistent, and so you can draw your own conclusion from that. The board is still the same. We have a great board, and we have a great shareholder base. So I think that's how I'd answer your question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad Heffern with RBC Capital Markets is online with a question.
componenttext: Brad Heffern with RBC Capital Markets is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask a question about Rockies Express. You obviously have the ROFR and chose not to exercise it. So I'm curious how strategic you view that pipeline longer term.
componenttext: I was hoping to ask a question about Rockies Express. You obviously have the ROFR and chose not to exercise it. So I'm curious how strategic you view that pipeline longer term.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we look at REX and I'd say Tallgrass has done a good job of creating value around a pipeline that was designed to go west to east and with what they've done. So we like what they've done from a value standpoint. In terms of the ROFR, we got a pretty ex
componenttext: So we look at REX and I'd say Tallgrass has done a good job of creating value around a pipeline that was designed to go west to east and with what they've done. So we like what they've done from a value standpoint. In terms of the ROFR, we got a pretty expansive organic program that really fits around our Chemicals, Refining, NGL assets, and that's where the -- that capital goes. So we elected to stay where we are with that, and it really didn't scale our investment side to that. But we think Tallgrass is doing a good job creating value, so we like it -- the REX pipeline with that. And it gives us some insights into the gas markets as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And I guess, circling back to CPChem. Thinking about the cracker, I'm curious, your outlook for the economics of that project now versus the investment case. Obviously, you wouldn't have assumed that oil prices were going to be as low as
componenttext: Okay, understood. And I guess, circling back to CPChem. Thinking about the cracker, I'm curious, your outlook for the economics of that project now versus the investment case. Obviously, you wouldn't have assumed that oil prices were going to be as low as they are, but at the same time I assume that demand is probably better than you expected. So what are kind of the puts and takes there?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the volume side, we haven't wavered that it's going to be -- come up. There'll be good demand globally. You always going to get the cracker stable. So I think that's the good news. On the margin side, the spread between ethane and crude, a
componenttext: Yes, I think on the volume side, we haven't wavered that it's going to be -- come up. There'll be good demand globally. You always going to get the cracker stable. So I think that's the good news. On the margin side, the spread between ethane and crude, and that ultimately, that crude price sets those, say, polyethylene or derivative price, that's narrowed a bit. I think that our view would be that that's a -- upfront, a little bit of a headwind. But as you look out and if you believe crude comes back to another level above $60, and I think we looked at the premises still are pretty much in line with our investment thesis. So I think we still like it from a return standpoint. Even at today's margins, there's a significant cost advantage with this new complex just on the operating side of the business that offsets some of that margin. But I think we still have expectations that this will be a very strong profit driver for CPChem, for us. Our share of that on the EBITDA basis incrementally, as that crack -- just the cracker starts up, is roughly $500 million with some upside.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So another way to think about that is you look at kind of industry markers today, full chain margins. Ethane is $0.28, $0.29. That's certainly well above reinvestment levels. And so I think you'd be happy with that investment with today's margins out ther
componenttext: So another way to think about that is you look at kind of industry markers today, full chain margins. Ethane is $0.28, $0.29. That's certainly well above reinvestment levels. And so I think you'd be happy with that investment with today's margins out there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel Khan with Citigroup is online with a question.
componenttext: Faisel Khan with Citigroup is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On -- just a couple of questions, one LPG and one on gasoline. On the LPG side, you guys talked about the -- you're looking for additional contracts on the capacity that you still have open. I was just curious, is that capacity or is that market to export
componenttext: On -- just a couple of questions, one LPG and one on gasoline. On the LPG side, you guys talked about the -- you're looking for additional contracts on the capacity that you still have open. I was just curious, is that capacity or is that market to export off your docks? Is that still in that $0.13 a gallon sort of range? Is that still the market price? Or is this something different?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that on a contract basis, you just -- we haven't disclosed the terms, specifically, and it's a range of things. I would say that the contract market long term is higher than the spot market. It's maybe how I'd like to answer that. So I think
componenttext: Well, I think that on a contract basis, you just -- we haven't disclosed the terms, specifically, and it's a range of things. I would say that the contract market long term is higher than the spot market. It's maybe how I'd like to answer that. So I think as you see these projects come on, the contract piece with the length that we're seeing -- or the short that we're seeing on the demand side has moved that spot market down. But we're still seeing good contract prices. And I think the customers that you talked to have a vision about long-term supply, and that's an important dimension. So I think with all assets you just have to look at the mix and decide which way you can go.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And did I hear your comments right that on the LPG sort of demand pull side on the export side of the equation that that's  -- that right now that's fairly pricing elastic because of the demand for light feedstock into global petrochemical capacity?
componenttext: Okay. And did I hear your comments right that on the LPG sort of demand pull side on the export side of the equation that that's  -- that right now that's fairly pricing elastic because of the demand for light feedstock into global petrochemical capacity? Or is that -- did I hear that wrong?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I was talking about we're fairly neutral in the U.S. about what we choose to crack. And so the length in the LPG still needs to be exported. We're still seeing good demand for PDH or propane dehydro units for cracker feeds around that. So I -- it was
componenttext: No, I was talking about we're fairly neutral in the U.S. about what we choose to crack. And so the length in the LPG still needs to be exported. We're still seeing good demand for PDH or propane dehydro units for cracker feeds around that. So I -- it was really a comment around the U.S. with its existing petrochemical operations, fairly stable. And we're close to indifferent in terms of feedstock, and every producer has their own preference for which feedstock they crack. And so that leaves you with that there's excess LPG that still needs to be exported. You're seeing it with propane, butane and some of the C5. And now you're starting to see some things happen on the ethane side as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what about ethylene, is that something that you could move across these docks as well?
componenttext: Okay. And what about ethylene, is that something that you could move across these docks as well?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So ethylene has actually been exported in limited quantities out of the U.S. and other parts. It's a more specialized trade. But yes, there's some interest in increased ethylene export capacity, and the ethane export capacity based on refrigeration is pre
componenttext: So ethylene has actually been exported in limited quantities out of the U.S. and other parts. It's a more specialized trade. But yes, there's some interest in increased ethylene export capacity, and the ethane export capacity based on refrigeration is pretty similar. So it's just the dock capacity is there. It's really around the refrigeration and how would you export that. And so can you convert what you have or just add to that to maybe add an ethylene dimension?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then on -- just on the gasoline side of the equation, so I understand the projects that you guys have sort of outstanding right now to, potentially, increase some of your gasoline yield. But if I'm looking at this coming summer versu
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then on -- just on the gasoline side of the equation, so I understand the projects that you guys have sort of outstanding right now to, potentially, increase some of your gasoline yield. But if I'm looking at this coming summer versus last summer -- because I believe last summer you were also somewhat maxed out in gasoline production capacity. Can you produce? Or would you think -- do you guys think you'll produce more gasoline -- finished gasoline this summer versus last summer?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we pretty much are running where we can. I would say, on the industry side one thing that's different this year is inventories are higher. So that may cap somewhat what you could see in terms of price response. At the same time, demand's up. S
componenttext: No, I think we pretty much are running where we can. I would say, on the industry side one thing that's different this year is inventories are higher. So that may cap somewhat what you could see in terms of price response. At the same time, demand's up. So days sales in inventories actually haven't grown as much as the gasoline absolute levels would indicate. And so I think we still expect a fairly strong gasoline driving season and a good gasoline crack through the next couple of quarters.

componenttext: Okay. So it doesn't sound like you could produce much more gasoline out of your system this summer versus last summer?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to reach out on the West Coast here. That's a place where the results came in a little bit soft relative to our expectations. Was there anything unusual in the first quarter, potentially the Plains pipeline outage or some turnaround activity t
componenttext: I just want to reach out on the West Coast here. That's a place where the results came in a little bit soft relative to our expectations. Was there anything unusual in the first quarter, potentially the Plains pipeline outage or some turnaround activity that could have impacted those results? And then as we have some of these FCCs come back online over the next couple of months, do you think the West Coast environment stays relatively strong just because we're going through a summer demand season? Or do you think we're going to see some margin compression out there?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we had San Francisco down on turnaround in the first quarter, so that impacted results versus what you would have thought. We still have some impact to Plains. It's less than $10 million for the quarter, but we're trying to mitigate that to the ex
componenttext: Yes, so we had San Francisco down on turnaround in the first quarter, so that impacted results versus what you would have thought. We still have some impact to Plains. It's less than $10 million for the quarter, but we're trying to mitigate that to the extent that we can. And then I think as Torrance comes back up it's going to have an impact in California. The good news is demand is up quite a bit relative to the last couple of years. And so I think you still got good demand going for you there, but I do think that you're not going to see the volatility in California that we've seen in the past year or 2.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's helpful. And then stepping back, as you think about your whole portfolio here, is everything that's part of PSX right now would you consider core? I mean, I know the West Coast has come up in the past as a potential asset divestiture tar
componenttext: All right, that's helpful. And then stepping back, as you think about your whole portfolio here, is everything that's part of PSX right now would you consider core? I mean, I know the West Coast has come up in the past as a potential asset divestiture target. But what are your thoughts in terms of how your portfolio looks right now, and whether -- anything you would consider noncore here?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do have a process underway at Whitegate, and we expect that we will conclude that process this year. California, we've talked about a lot. The hold cost or option value to hold is really not much. There's not a lot of capital in front of us in Calif
componenttext: So we do have a process underway at Whitegate, and we expect that we will conclude that process this year. California, we've talked about a lot. The hold cost or option value to hold is really not much. There's not a lot of capital in front of us in California. The last few years, margins have been very good in California, so it's a net cash contributor. And you think about could you sell the asset? Probably. But can we get good value for it? Probably not. And so I think we just hold it at this point in time. They're good assets. They're probably mid-back in terms where they sit in their cost structures. But given the option value to keep, I think we'll just hang on to them.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Phillips 66 earnings conference call. My name is Sally, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Rosy Zuk
componenttext:
Welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Phillips 66 earnings conference call. My name is Sally, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to Rosy Zuklic, General Manager, Investor Relations. Rosy, you may begin.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 first quarter earnings conference call. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 first quarter earnings conference call. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Greg Garland; President, Tim Taylor; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Kevin Mitchell. The presentation material we will be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website, along with supplemental financial and operating information.
Slide 2 contains our safe harbor statement. It is a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from today's comments. Factors that could cause our actual results to differ are included here as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg Garland for some opening remarks. Greg?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. We had a good operating quarter running well across all of our businesses. However, weaker margins had a significant impact on our earnings this quarter. In Refining, distillate crack spreads
componenttext:
Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. We had a good operating quarter running well across all of our businesses. However, weaker margins had a significant impact on our earnings this quarter. In Refining, distillate crack spreads were the lowest since 2010. In Chemicals, benchmark industry olefin chain margins were down from last quarter, and Midstream was impacted by lower NGL prices. We experienced solid results from our Marketing and Specialties business.
Total adjusted earnings were $360 million. And excluding working capital changes, we generated $722 million in cash from operations. We remain focused on operating excellence and completing our growth projects in Midstream and Chemicals where we see great value and opportunity long term. We're maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation and believe that our strong balance sheet is a competitive advantage that positions us well to execute our plans through the commodity price cycles.
During the quarter, we reinvested $750 million back into the business, and we distributed $687 million to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. Since May of 2012, we've returned $11.8 billion to shareholders through dividends and our repurchase or exchange of 115 million shares. We continue to target a 60-40 split between reinvestment in our business and distributions back to our shareholders, and we've targeted another dividend increase this year of at least 10%.
We've made good progress on our major growth projects. In Midstream, we received all the permits necessary for the Dakota Access Pipeline to start laying pipe in May, and we would expect an on-schedule completion by year-end. In the Gulf Coast the Beaumont Terminal expansion is going well. The terminal currently has 7.1 million barrels of storage capacity. We have 3.2 million barrels of new capacity under construction. Longer term, this facility can expand to 16 million barrels of storage capacity. 
Also, development of the first phase of the Sweeny hub is nearing completion. The LPG export terminal is 80% complete, is on time and on budget. The completion of the terminal will represent a major step in the development of a world-class energy complex with integrated Refining, Chemical and Midstream assets. 
PSXP remains an important part of our Midstream growth strategy. The fee-based assets within its portfolio continue to perform well. PSXP increased its limited partner distributions by 5% this quarter and remains on track to achieve a steady growth objective of a 5-year, 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
DCP Midstream is reducing its cash breakeven through self-help initiatives and expects to achieve breakeven and NGL prices below $0.35 per gallon this year. They're reducing costs, cut capital substantially and converting commodity-exposed contracts to fee-based to improve financial strength and flexibility. 
In addition, the equity contributions from the owners last year strengthened the balance sheet, increased fee-based earnings and positioned DCP for success in the future. We expect the DCP will be self-funded going forward.
In Chemicals, demand for consumer products remains strong. In response, CPChem continues to run at high rates across its system. Because CPChem's primary production centers are in North America and in the Middle East, underpinned by advantaged feedstocks, we believe CPChem's asset base provides us with a competitive advantage. CPChem continues to advance the U.S. Gulf Coast Petrochemicals Project. It is now 75% complete, with expected start-up in mid-2017. Once running, CPChem's global ethylene and polyethylene capacity will increase by approximately 1/3. 
In Refining, we see good gasoline supply and demand fundamentals for the remainder the year, and we expect strong demand as we head into the summer driving season. Our focus in Refining is operating excellence, maintaining our cost and capital discipline, increasing returns through selective investment. We invest in projects that are quick payout, low cost and high return. During the quarter, we advanced several of these Refining projects. At the Wood River refinery, we're undergoing debottlenecking and are on schedule for completion in the third quarter. At Bayway, work on the FCC modernization is on schedule. At the Billings refinery, effort is underway to increase the amount of heavy Canadian crude we can run to 100%. Each of these projects has a projected return on investment of about 30%.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to review the quarter results. Kevin?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, first quarter adjusted earnings were $360 million or $0.67 per share. Reported net income was $385 million. Excluding working capital, cash from operations was $722 million. Capital spending for the quarter
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, first quarter adjusted earnings were $360 million or $0.67 per share. Reported net income was $385 million. Excluding working capital, cash from operations was $722 million. Capital spending for the quarter was $750 million, with approximately $450 million spent in Midstream, primarily on our growth projects. Distributions to shareholders in the first quarter totaled $687 million, including $296 million in dividends and $391 million in share repurchases. At the end of the first quarter, our debt-to-capital ratio was 27%. And after taking into account our ending cash balance, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 23%. Annualized adjusted return on capital employed was 5%. Our adjusted effective income tax rate is 33%.
Slide 5 compares first quarter 2016 and fourth quarter 2015 adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were down $350 million, primarily driven by lower results in Refining. Next, we will cover each of the segments individually. 
I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. Transportation continues to generate stable earnings. The NGL business progressed construction on the Freeport LPG Export Terminal. Fractionator utilization was reduced due to turnarounds and the impact of ethane rejection on feedstock composition. Included in the transportation and NGL results is the contribution from Phillips 66 Partners. During the quarter PSXP contributed earnings of $32 million to the Midstream segment. Distributions to Phillips 66 from our LP and GP interests increased 7% over the fourth quarter. DCP Midstream continues to work on its self-help initiatives to reduce costs, manage its portfolio and restructure contracts.
On Slide 7, Midstream's first quarter adjusted earnings were $40 million, down $2 million from the fourth quarter. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter were $72 million, down $6 million from the prior quarter, driven by lower equity earnings from Rockies Express pipeline and Explorer pipeline. NGL adjusted losses were $11 million for the first quarter. A $9 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by seasonal storage activity, partially offset by lower tax expense. Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were lower in the first quarter, primarily due to improved reliability and contract restructuring efforts, partially offset by the impact of lower commodity prices.
In Chemicals, the global olefins and polyolefins capacity utilization rate for the quarter was 93%, and margins were lower. SA&S had improved equity earnings due to higher volumes at equity affiliates. 
As shown on Slide 9, first quarter adjusted earnings for Chemicals were $156 million, down from $182 million in the fourth quarter. In olefins and polyolefins, the decrease of $36 million was largely due to lower margins, driven by reduced polyethylene sales prices. This was partially offset by higher polyethylene sales volumes and lower controllable costs. Adjusted earnings for SA&S increased by $7 million on higher equity earnings from increased sales volumes due to fourth quarter turnaround activities at CPChem's equity affiliates.
In Refining, realized margins were $7.11 per barrel for the quarter as market crack spreads decreased significantly from the prior quarter. Gasoline market cracks were down 14% from the fourth quarter due in part to the impact of higher-than-normal industry gasoline production in the fourth quarter as well as the impacts of butane blending and seasonally lower demand. Distillate market cracks were at a 6-year low. Market capture decreased from 74% in the fourth quarter to 67% in the first quarter. Clean product yield fell to 82%, with gasoline yield at 43%. These yields reflect the impact of turnaround activity as well as accelerated maintenance on secondary units due to the low-margin environment. Pretax turnaround costs were $115 million, $35 million lower than guidance due to the deferral of some catalyst change-out activity.
Slide 11 shows a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. The Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $86 million, down $290 million from last quarter. The reduction was largely due to lower market cracks. Atlantic Basin adjusted earnings decreased this quarter, primarily due to lower volumes and inventory impacts. The Gulf Coast region saw lower margins and reduced volumes due to planned maintenance and unplanned downtime. In the Gulf Coast region as well as the Central Corridor, we had unplanned downtime as we undertook discretionary maintenance in a low-margin environment. In the Central Corridor, lower margins accounted for the majority of the reduction in adjusted earnings from the fourth quarter as market cracks were 24% lower. On the West Coast, market cracks were 26% lower. Reduced margins were mostly offset by improvements in controllable costs and inventory impacts. Santa Maria continued to be affected by the Plains pipeline outage. 
Next, we will cover market capture on Slide 12. Our worldwide realized margin was $7.11 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack of $10.64 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 67%. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries as it relates to our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 82% clean product yield for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. Losses due to secondary products decreased this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as coke and NGLs narrowed. Feedstock advantage was slightly higher than the fourth quarter, but crude differentials generally remained tight. The other category mainly includes costs associated with RINs, outgoing freight, product differentials and inventory impacts.
Let's move to Marketing and Specialties where we posted a good quarter, thanks to healthy U.S. margins and volumes. Specialties saw higher earnings on improved margins. 
Slide 14 shows adjusted earnings for M&S in the first quarter of $205 million, down $22 million from the fourth quarter. In Marketing and Other, the $36 million decrease was largely due to lower biodiesel tax credits and lower margins in international Marketing. This was partially offset by higher U.S. marketing margins. Specialties adjusted earnings increased to $43 million, primarily due to improved base oil margins.
On Slide 15, the Corporate and Other expense had after-tax net costs of $127 million this quarter, an increase of $10 million from the fourth quarter. Net interest expense increased by $7 million, primarily due to lower capitalized interest associated with the start-up of Sweeny Fractionator One, while corporate overhead and other expenses increased by $3 million due to the timing of legal and environmental charges.
Slide 16 shows cash flow for the quarter. We began the year with a cash balance of $3.1 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations was $722 million. Working capital changes reduced cash flow by $464 million. The cash benefit of a U.S. tax refund received in the quarter was more than offset by the customary first quarter inventory build and the timing of marketing receipts and crude cargo payments. We funded $750 million of capital expenditures and investments, and we distributed nearly $700 million to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the quarter with 526 million shares outstanding. At the end of the quarter, our cash balance was $1.7 billion.
This concludes my review of the financial and operational results. 
Next, I'll cover a few outlook items. In the second quarter, in Chemicals, we expect the global O&P utilization rate to be in the low 90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rate to be in the mid-90s and before-tax turnaround expenses to be approximately $100 million. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $120 million and $125 million. And company-wide, we expect the effective income tax rate to be in the mid-30s. 
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch is online with a question.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I could ask you about the impact of run cuts in the quarter. Because my understanding is earlier in the quarter, you guys had deliberately taken some steps to basically run at lower rates. And obviously, I'm wondering if that was part of what
componenttext: I wonder if I could ask you about the impact of run cuts in the quarter. Because my understanding is earlier in the quarter, you guys had deliberately taken some steps to basically run at lower rates. And obviously, I'm wondering if that was part of what fell behind the Refining result in the quarter. And my follow-up, I guess, is also Refining related to the diesel overhang we see currently. Obviously, you guys are a little bit more exposed to that. I'd just love to get your perspective on how you see -- if you see that cleaning up and how you see that playing out, let's say, over the next 3 to 6 months. And I'll leave it there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start and then, Tim, you can kind of give the overlook on these. So we ran really hard in January and March, and we slowed down in February is, really, the story. I think the interesting thing is we accelerated some maintenance activity but a lot
componenttext: So I'll start and then, Tim, you can kind of give the overlook on these. So we ran really hard in January and March, and we slowed down in February is, really, the story. I think the interesting thing is we accelerated some maintenance activity but a lot of it was on secondary units. And it really didn't affect the overall utilization as much as you might expect, but we did build some intermediate inventory during the quarter. So I think that's the major impact in terms of the operations. And Tim, why don't you hit on the outlook in terms of distillate?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, on the distillate side, I think exports are the key to really clearing the length in North America. And we're seeing good demand in China, India, West Africa and Latin America, and so I think that continues. That said, I think distillate for us
componenttext: Yes, Doug, on the distillate side, I think exports are the key to really clearing the length in North America. And we're seeing good demand in China, India, West Africa and Latin America, and so I think that continues. That said, I think distillate for us continues to look to be the challenge for the market as we go forward. But I think it will clear, but it's really turning into more of a by-product from a gasoline production standpoint. So I think as long as export markets are open, that will continue to clear the U.S.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a quick follow-up. So you're planning to run your refineries back up into the mid-90s in the second quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, if margins are still challenging in your distillate heavy yield, why would you continue to -- or you just
componenttext: Maybe just a quick follow-up. So you're planning to run your refineries back up into the mid-90s in the second quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, if margins are still challenging in your distillate heavy yield, why would you continue to -- or you just going to press into that? Or do you think there'll be more voluntary run cuts as we go through the next 3 to 6 months? It doesn't sound like it.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. I think that we're seeing strong gasoline cracks. I mean, they've really recovered in March and now in April, the summer driving season. That's going to drive the overall refinery utilization. It certainly drives our thinking. And then the dist
componenttext: Yes, Doug. I think that we're seeing strong gasoline cracks. I mean, they've really recovered in March and now in April, the summer driving season. That's going to drive the overall refinery utilization. It certainly drives our thinking. And then the distillate piece, the crack spread is really relatively stable where it is and has been, but I think that's the piece where we're looking to the exports to clear that. But I think the gasoline is pulling the refinery utilization up across the industry.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Blake Fernandez with Howard Weil is online with a question.
componenttext: Blake Fernandez with Howard Weil is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to follow up on Doug's distillate question, do you have any sense that maybe once we reaccelerate activity here in the U.S. from a drilling perspective, do you think that's a critical component of kind of cleaning up the disparity we're seeing
componenttext: Maybe just to follow up on Doug's distillate question, do you have any sense that maybe once we reaccelerate activity here in the U.S. from a drilling perspective, do you think that's a critical component of kind of cleaning up the disparity we're seeing between demand and maybe some of these building inventories on the distillate side?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's part of the equation, but it's -- I mean, right now, it's probably less than 2% of total distillates demand, but it's helpful. It was maybe 40,000 or 50,000 barrels a day is our estimate.
componenttext: It's part of the equation, but it's -- I mean, right now, it's probably less than 2% of total distillates demand, but it's helpful. It was maybe 40,000 or 50,000 barrels a day is our estimate.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. That's helpful. The second piece, and maybe this a question for Kevin. The buybacks seem to continue at a fairly robust rate, continuing the macro environment. I'm just curious, your thinking about ratability of the buyback program and kind of
componenttext: Okay, good. That's helpful. The second piece, and maybe this a question for Kevin. The buybacks seem to continue at a fairly robust rate, continuing the macro environment. I'm just curious, your thinking about ratability of the buyback program and kind of the seasonality of what we would expect on the cash flow.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll take it, then Kevin can step in. So I kind of think about this in several different buckets. The first bucket is really, I don't think the first quarter is reflective of our view of what 2016 is going to be. You've seen cracks have gone from
componenttext: Yes. So I'll take it, then Kevin can step in. So I kind of think about this in several different buckets. The first bucket is really, I don't think the first quarter is reflective of our view of what 2016 is going to be. You've seen cracks have gone from $10 to $15. We've seen NGLs move from $0.37 to $0.47, $0.48. We're seeing good demand for transportation fuels, gasoline. We're seeing good demand for petrochemicals. We're seeing margins up a couple of cents, and we think margins will continue to improve in the petchem chain. So we think that '16 is still kind of a $4 billion to $5 billion-type cash generation year from us from operations. Second, I would say our view is that for high-quality MLPs, we think that the equity markets are open, and that we would expect between some combination of debt and equity, we'd raise between $1 billion and $2 billion back into PSX this year. So this kind of moves you to $5 billion to $7 billion of cash if you want to think about it that way. We can afford a $3.9 billion capital program, $1.2 billion dividend and $1 billion to $2 billion of share repurchases given that. I will say just though, we're looking at things going on. And we're going through every line item in the capital budget both for '16 and '17. And we're assuring that our premises that we started with are still valid and that these projects are going to generate returns that are acceptable and meet our requirements. And so we'll be looking at that going forward into this year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Tim. I'm sorry, Tim, Tim, I'm sorry. I probably I did not make my question. I'm looking, specifically, for naphtha that -- whether it's more economic to directly blend it into the gasoline pool in U.S. and then add octane to begin to finish gasoline,
componenttext: No, Tim. I'm sorry, Tim, Tim, I'm sorry. I probably I did not make my question. I'm looking, specifically, for naphtha that -- whether it's more economic to directly blend it into the gasoline pool in U.S. and then add octane to begin to finish gasoline, or that it's better to take them out in U.S. into the overseas to be used as a petrochemical feedstock, and the insight from you guys, given you are also a big petrochemical producer.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, clearly naphtha demand's increased around the world, but we still see the best value to go into gasoline pool here, pull it with octane to blend it up. But with the demand we're seeing in gasoline, that's still the preference that we have.
componenttext: Yes, clearly naphtha demand's increased around the world, but we still see the best value to go into gasoline pool here, pull it with octane to blend it up. But with the demand we're seeing in gasoline, that's still the preference that we have.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
