componenttext: I see. And second question, maybe this is for Kevin. Do you have a number that you can share? What is the Sweeny NGL Fractionator One, the contribution in the first quarter?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Paul, we haven't broken out at that level of detail. As you know, we report at the sort of NGL subsegment within our Midstream business. At the PSXP level, you can see there what they see on the fractionator, but that's a different look to the Phillips
componenttext: So Paul, we haven't broken out at that level of detail. As you know, we report at the sort of NGL subsegment within our Midstream business. At the PSXP level, you can see there what they see on the fractionator, but that's a different look to the Phillips 66 look. So at this point, that's not a level of granularity that we've broken out at this time. Obviously, the fractionator just started up at the end of last year. So it's still kind of going through that start-up, a little bit of incremental cost that you wouldn't expect to be recurring. And volume's a little bit lower than capacity, given the feedstock composition. But ultimately, the full value is going to come when you see the export terminal up and running and get full contribution.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, on Tier 3, can you tell us where are you in the process?
componenttext: Tim, on Tier 3, can you tell us where are you in the process?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're in the midst of really investing to deal with the -- taking more sulfur out across our system. So we have a number of projects at our refineries that we're in the process of implementing to complete that. But that's been a piece of our maintenanc
componenttext: So we're in the midst of really investing to deal with the -- taking more sulfur out across our system. So we have a number of projects at our refineries that we're in the process of implementing to complete that. But that's been a piece of our maintenance capital or our long-term maintenance capital over the last several years and the next year or so to complete that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So West Coast -- apologies. Say, West Coast meets Tier 3 standards, so it's the other refineries we're investing in. And those investments are included within the kind of $700 million of sustaining capital that we've outlined.
componenttext: So West Coast -- apologies. Say, West Coast meets Tier 3 standards, so it's the other refineries we're investing in. And those investments are included within the kind of $700 million of sustaining capital that we've outlined.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Greg, how -- outside West Coast, is the -- how many of the other facilities already in compliance this year? Or that all of them, we need to wait until next year before you are in compliance?
componenttext: Right. Greg, how -- outside West Coast, is the -- how many of the other facilities already in compliance this year? Or that all of them, we need to wait until next year before you are in compliance?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: They will come into compliance at different times, given the investment schedule through 2018 that will hit, Paul. I think we have investment at most of the other refineries for Tier 3, some more than others.
componenttext: They will come into compliance at different times, given the investment schedule through 2018 that will hit, Paul. I think we have investment at most of the other refineries for Tier 3, some more than others.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The final question. Greg, I hear you about -- that the -- how to balance the cash flow and expecting $1 billion to $2 billion of NPL x the cash contribution to the C corp. To the degree, if that didn't materialize, should we assume that you're going
componenttext: Okay. The final question. Greg, I hear you about -- that the -- how to balance the cash flow and expecting $1 billion to $2 billion of NPL x the cash contribution to the C corp. To the degree, if that didn't materialize, should we assume that you're going to borrow money that you continue to fund the temporary shortfall on the buyback? Or that the buyback will take a backseat?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: To the -- let me rephrase your question, Paul, to the extent that we can't access the market...
componenttext: To the -- let me rephrase your question, Paul, to the extent that we can't access the market...

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if in the event that the MLP market is not available there to raise additional equity or debt for PSXP, and so as a result, that you won't get that $1 billion to $2 billion of the cash you expect from the subsidiary into the C corp, should we assume, b
componenttext: So if in the event that the MLP market is not available there to raise additional equity or debt for PSXP, and so as a result, that you won't get that $1 billion to $2 billion of the cash you expect from the subsidiary into the C corp, should we assume, because you review it as a temporary development, that you would just borrow money in the C corp to fund the buyback? Or that the buyback will take a pause and wait until that you have the cash to do so?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we said we could flex between $1 billion to $2 billion, and that's kind of the guidance we've given. But I would just kind of reiterate, we feel pretty strongly that the markets are going to be open to us.
componenttext: Well, I think that we said we could flex between $1 billion to $2 billion, and that's kind of the guidance we've given. But I would just kind of reiterate, we feel pretty strongly that the markets are going to be open to us.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley is online with a question.
componenttext: Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Greg, it relates to your capital flexibility in 2016 and '17 as we see some volatility in your business. I mean, I know you talked about the expected recovery to cash flow. Yet, as much as -- how much of the capital plans are flexible w
componenttext: My first question, Greg, it relates to your capital flexibility in 2016 and '17 as we see some volatility in your business. I mean, I know you talked about the expected recovery to cash flow. Yet, as much as -- how much of the capital plans are flexible when you think about 2016 and 2017? And what drives how you flex that?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say, we kind of guided or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth of kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunit
componenttext: Yes, so I would say, we kind of guided or said that we're on a glide slope to kind of a $3 billion capital program in '17 and '18, with $1 billion sustaining and $2 billion worth of kind of growth capital, primarily directed at Midstream growth opportunities. In terms of the $3.9 billion this year and how much flex do we have, I would say we're still working through that and looking at that. But it's probably $500 million-ish in terms of the amount of flex that we actually have this year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And second on Midstream, results were weaker than expected there, at least versus our numbers. Maybe you could discuss some of the drivers there, I mean, likely related to frac start-up, and how those factors impacted results and may trend through
componenttext: Got it. And second on Midstream, results were weaker than expected there, at least versus our numbers. Maybe you could discuss some of the drivers there, I mean, likely related to frac start-up, and how those factors impacted results and may trend through '16. I imagine some of those would unwind.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, it's Tim. So basically, you look at transportation segment, consistent earnings quarter-to-quarter, so the DCP was slightly improved as well. So that leaves you with the NGL, and that's largely the impacts -- some commercial impacts on the inve
componenttext: Yes, Evan, it's Tim. So basically, you look at transportation segment, consistent earnings quarter-to-quarter, so the DCP was slightly improved as well. So that leaves you with the NGL, and that's largely the impacts -- some commercial impacts on the inventory, some higher costs associated with the start-up of the frac, and that's really -- as we line that out, we expect that to come more in line.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Anything relating to the...
componenttext: Right. Anything relating to the...

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think we should mention, we had a turnaround at our GCF frac, so the expenses were up as well with that turnaround.
componenttext: Oh, I think we should mention, we had a turnaround at our GCF frac, so the expenses were up as well with that turnaround.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add, Evan, on DCP, so it was improved results, but it was still a loss for the quarter on an adjusted basis. And that reflects the sort of mid-30s NGL prices, which have recovered quite a bit since then. So that result should be getting
componenttext: Yes, I would just add, Evan, on DCP, so it was improved results, but it was still a loss for the quarter on an adjusted basis. And that reflects the sort of mid-30s NGL prices, which have recovered quite a bit since then. So that result should be getting back to something a little bit more respectable.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger Read with Wells Fargo is online with a question.
componenttext: Roger Read with Wells Fargo is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe coming back to a little bit on the question on the ability to run at the high levels on the Refining side and the export market. Can you give us an idea of what export volumes have been and kind of what you would anticipate as we go into the su
componenttext: Just maybe coming back to a little bit on the question on the ability to run at the high levels on the Refining side and the export market. Can you give us an idea of what export volumes have been and kind of what you would anticipate as we go into the summer? I mean, you made the comment about as long as the market remains open. Just kind of curious what that means in a numerical sense.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been running, essentially, at mid-90s utilization, so that's not changing. And so this last quarter, we ran 126,000, 127,000 barrels a day of exports. And so from our standpoint, that's a very manageable amount to place. But our utilization rea
componenttext: Yes, we've been running, essentially, at mid-90s utilization, so that's not changing. And so this last quarter, we ran 126,000, 127,000 barrels a day of exports. And so from our standpoint, that's a very manageable amount to place. But our utilization really kind of stays where we were. And so I think that's the key at our Gulf Coast Refineries to balance that distillate.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any more -- or any particular level of flexibility we should consider here between gasoline and the distillate side? Or are you pretty well where you can go in the, say, next 12 months or so?
componenttext: And any more -- or any particular level of flexibility we should consider here between gasoline and the distillate side? Or are you pretty well where you can go in the, say, next 12 months or so?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've been running pretty much max gasoline as most of the industry has. We can probably -- we can flex about 3% to 4% between gasoline and diesel. So we do have some projects that are coming on that will, directionally, move us more towards
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been running pretty much max gasoline as most of the industry has. We can probably -- we can flex about 3% to 4% between gasoline and diesel. So we do have some projects that are coming on that will, directionally, move us more towards gasoline, like the modernization of the FCC at Bayway is a good example of that and some of the things we're doing at Wood River. But I think on balance, you should expect we're going to be in kind of 43% to 45%-type gasoline yields for '16.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil Gresh with JPMorgan is online with a question.
componenttext: Phil Gresh with JPMorgan is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, on the third quarter call last year, I'd asked about the timing of reaching full run rate on the 2 projects, the 400 million to 500 million. I was just wondering if you could give an update on that. Obviously, it's a little bit of a slow s
componenttext: First question, on the third quarter call last year, I'd asked about the timing of reaching full run rate on the 2 projects, the 400 million to 500 million. I was just wondering if you could give an update on that. Obviously, it's a little bit of a slow start on the NGL side. It sounds like LPG is on time, but there is a market exposure piece there. So as we go through '17, I mean, what level are you, of the 400 million to 500 million, are you confident with at this point?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the 400 million to 500 million is really the total for the fractionation, and that's a smaller piece of that total then, that LPG terminal and the access. And we've always said 20%, 30% of that is commodity type of exposure. So I think there's always w
componenttext: So the 400 million to 500 million is really the total for the fractionation, and that's a smaller piece of that total then, that LPG terminal and the access. And we've always said 20%, 30% of that is commodity type of exposure. So I think there's always where the market structure is going to be and where that arb is going to be between the Gulf Coast and export markets in Asia, Europe or Latin America. So as this export terminal completes late this year and you go through start-up, I think you start to see that impact really -- full-chain value impact, really start to hit late this year in 2017. And I think the real question is going to be is, what is that commercial piece of that going to be? So that's why we've always framed it a bit from the 400 million to 500 million in terms of where the market goes. But if crude prices recover, globally, I think that increases that arb naturally when we see that. So I think that's a variable that's a piece of that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So x the arb piece, you'd say -- just on the execution front and the rest, you're comfortable like mid-'17, you could hit the full run rate on the rest?
componenttext: So x the arb piece, you'd say -- just on the execution front and the rest, you're comfortable like mid-'17, you could hit the full run rate on the rest?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think the frac is going to be -- when you think about composition, you think about that, that comes up. It's a relatively small contribution. Then it's really about the cargoes. We have 8 cargoes that we're looking at. So we continue to wor
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the frac is going to be -- when you think about composition, you think about that, that comes up. It's a relatively small contribution. Then it's really about the cargoes. We have 8 cargoes that we're looking at. So we continue to work contracts. And then we have commercial opportunity, and there's always spot business with that. But we believe the supply is there to fill that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is just on the NGL side, particularly from the chemicals angle. I'm just kind of wondering how you're thinking about input cost pricing with respect to ethane, propane. Obviously, there's some improved sentiment here around the expor
componenttext: Okay. Second question is just on the NGL side, particularly from the chemicals angle. I'm just kind of wondering how you're thinking about input cost pricing with respect to ethane, propane. Obviously, there's some improved sentiment here around the export impact, the demand impact on NGLs. I'm just wondering how you think about both availability and the cost of the NGLs for your Chemicals business.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think as we've thought about the -- and we'll call it the NGL side, we're basically seeing parity today between ethane, propane and butane in terms of the value and the cracking slate. And our view has been that the export netback price will kind of
componenttext: So I think as we've thought about the -- and we'll call it the NGL side, we're basically seeing parity today between ethane, propane and butane in terms of the value and the cracking slate. And our view has been that the export netback price will kind of set a price for propane, butane. And then the ethane could reach that perhaps in terms of cracking parity, but the balance really comes about which of those feedstocks you select. But the export netback really becomes the upper limit of what we set for the cracking value. Ethane, in our view, giving -- coming out of rejection and what we see on the start-up of the projects, should still remain at a competitive disadvantage for the long term. And so I think it really is that interplay somewhere between gas value and propane, butane parity and the cracking that determines that. But we would expect when the new crackers start up that ethane prices will come up somewhat to pull some of that ethane back out of the gas stream. But we're still -- the bottom line is we're still bullish on the operating rate side on Chemicals as well as the competitive advantage that you get from ethane and LPG cracking.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good thing I would say about the petrochemical environment right now, you really -- it is a demand pull that's pulling values. And it's really not destock cost that's setting value in the market today.
componenttext: The good thing I would say about the petrochemical environment right now, you really -- it is a demand pull that's pulling values. And it's really not destock cost that's setting value in the market today.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you'd say that the margins that you've achieved, let's say, in the first quarter, you'd see as sustainable even if input costs rose, because of the demand?
componenttext: So you'd say that the margins that you've achieved, let's say, in the first quarter, you'd see as sustainable even if input costs rose, because of the demand?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the margins rolled off in the first quarter in the markets side, but we're seeing improvement. And I think the demand side has continued to get better, so we're seeing tightening on that. And so I think the demand side is actually going to be
componenttext: Yes, I think the margins rolled off in the first quarter in the markets side, but we're seeing improvement. And I think the demand side has continued to get better, so we're seeing tightening on that. And so I think the demand side is actually going to be a positive as we look out to the rest of the year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff Dietert with Simmons is online with a question.
componenttext: Jeff Dietert with Simmons is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on the Chemical margin discussion, are you seeing margins widen as we move through April with the increase in oil price? And I noticed that utilization actually was going down in the second quarter relative to first quarter. Could you talk ab
componenttext: Following up on the Chemical margin discussion, are you seeing margins widen as we move through April with the increase in oil price? And I noticed that utilization actually was going down in the second quarter relative to first quarter. Could you talk about these topics?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll hit the utilization first since it -- I would say that with turnarounds in the industry, and CPChem currently has a cracker in turnaround as well, that you're seeing utilizations fall from a turnaround perspective. And we've always felt '16 was go
componenttext: So I'll hit the utilization first since it -- I would say that with turnarounds in the industry, and CPChem currently has a cracker in turnaround as well, that you're seeing utilizations fall from a turnaround perspective. And we've always felt '16 was going to be a fairly heavy turnaround for the U.S. industry. And as far as the current pricing, we're seeing strengthening in that on the derivative side. And I think that's both the response to both demand as well as you're now seeing the move-up in crude oil. So you're seeing 2 things that kind of influence that price from a global standpoint, on the, say, the polyethylene is the key derivative for that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And second, following up on the gasoline versus distillate yield. It's my understanding, once gasoline cracks are higher than distillate cracks, there's kind of a shift towards maximizing gasoline. But as you look at distillate cracks at half the le
componenttext: Okay. And second, following up on the gasoline versus distillate yield. It's my understanding, once gasoline cracks are higher than distillate cracks, there's kind of a shift towards maximizing gasoline. But as you look at distillate cracks at half the level they were last year, are there incremental things you can do year-on-year to increase gasoline yield and perhaps moderate distillate yield?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Greg alluded to some of the things we're doing to increase conversion across FCCs and convert some of that feed into that. Beyond that, it's a longer-term investment, and we'd have to see a longer-term signal. But I think I look at distillate and
componenttext: I think Greg alluded to some of the things we're doing to increase conversion across FCCs and convert some of that feed into that. Beyond that, it's a longer-term investment, and we'd have to see a longer-term signal. But I think I look at distillate and also say that if the economy, industrially, across the world picks up, you will see more distillate demand. And that's been a factor in the distillate -- sluggish distillate demand that we're seeing. And we're seeing good consumer demand, weaker industrial. And so I think you've got to take a view that the industrial piece at some point does come back. And I think we're seeing signs of that, perhaps, in Asia, but that's a big piece of the trade piece in the distillate that really drives the industrial side. So I think we look at this and say, it's not clear that you've got a permanent separation. We've got to think about that from an investment standpoint.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research is online with a question.
componenttext: Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've kind of gone beyond the answer to this question, which is about the NGL market. You've talked about pricing. Could you just update us, given the changes in the market, on how volumes have shifted both in terms of just over the past year, but also t
componenttext: You've kind of gone beyond the answer to this question, which is about the NGL market. You've talked about pricing. Could you just update us, given the changes in the market, on how volumes have shifted both in terms of just over the past year, but also to any extent that your outlook has shifted and especially the impact you might have on market? I know you've addressed this kind of from a price standpoint, but could you talk about volume?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the raw NGL volumes, Paul?
componenttext: On the raw NGL volumes, Paul?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we always struggle with this market because it's just sort of nebulous area but...
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we always struggle with this market because it's just sort of nebulous area but...

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what we're seeing is we're seeing NGL volumes still hanging in there. You would expect with drilling activity, you would eventually expect to see that to break over a bit. But we're still seeing good NGL volumes coming in into the Gulf Coast. The
componenttext: Okay. So what we're seeing is we're seeing NGL volumes still hanging in there. You would expect with drilling activity, you would eventually expect to see that to break over a bit. But we're still seeing good NGL volumes coming in into the Gulf Coast. The Permian, in particular, looks really good. And I think that ties back to what you see on the crude side. The Eagle Ford being -- we're seeing decline rates both on NGL and crude. But overall, NGL volumes have been up to kind of holding flat. And in fact, we had record propane production, but you've got a refinery input on the propane side as well, which may tie back to gasoline mode. So I'd say, on the NGL side we've seen it hold, and as crude oil prices recover and drilling resumes and if you believe that North America is going to have that incremental call, we're still bullish that the NGL supply is going to continue to increase.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: What do you attribute the volumes surprisingly holding up to?
componenttext: What do you attribute the volumes surprisingly holding up to?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just we see kind of the same story on the crude side. I think there's just a lot of latent activity there, and then I think the economics behind the drilling and the basins that we're touching are driving that. So we've seen that hold, and I
componenttext: I think it's just we see kind of the same story on the crude side. I think there's just a lot of latent activity there, and then I think the economics behind the drilling and the basins that we're touching are driving that. So we've seen that hold, and I think it just reflects what the production side of the business is seeing on the E&P side.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you might almost be thinking that we're actually bottoming out in terms of volumes and, actually, will hold or go higher from here?
componenttext: So you might almost be thinking that we're actually bottoming out in terms of volumes and, actually, will hold or go higher from here?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you've got to see that drilling resume to really start to see that come back. And I suspect we'll continue to see NGL volumes kind of holding steady, perhaps decline a bit. And then it takes time, I think, would be our view on the E&P side to kind
componenttext: I think you've got to see that drilling resume to really start to see that come back. And I suspect we'll continue to see NGL volumes kind of holding steady, perhaps decline a bit. And then it takes time, I think, would be our view on the E&P side to kind of restart all that activity. And your guess is as good as mine about exactly where they are. But with the capital expenditures budgets where they are on the upstream, it's hard to see that you're going to see a lot of extra volume over the next 12 months until that program ramps back up. And so sustained crude oil prices would help drive that. And we think over a period of months that's what you'll begin to see. But I think we're kind of -- and I think our view is, we're probably getting closer to the bottom. We may stay here a while. And we're certainly going to continue to see volatility.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. I was working on the idea that your guess would be better than mine. This may be a very quick answer, and I fully understand if it is. But you've had a significant shift in shareholder structure over the past year or so. Has that had any impac
componenttext: Understood. I was working on the idea that your guess would be better than mine. This may be a very quick answer, and I fully understand if it is. But you've had a significant shift in shareholder structure over the past year or so. Has that had any impact on your board or on your strategy?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're pretty open about what our strategy is. It's been very consistent, and so you can draw your own conclusion from that. The board is still the same. We have a great board, and we have a great shareholder base. So I think that's how I'd answer
componenttext: I think we're pretty open about what our strategy is. It's been very consistent, and so you can draw your own conclusion from that. The board is still the same. We have a great board, and we have a great shareholder base. So I think that's how I'd answer your question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad Heffern with RBC Capital Markets is online with a question.
componenttext: Brad Heffern with RBC Capital Markets is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask a question about Rockies Express. You obviously have the ROFR and chose not to exercise it. So I'm curious how strategic you view that pipeline longer term.
componenttext: I was hoping to ask a question about Rockies Express. You obviously have the ROFR and chose not to exercise it. So I'm curious how strategic you view that pipeline longer term.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we look at REX and I'd say Tallgrass has done a good job of creating value around a pipeline that was designed to go west to east and with what they've done. So we like what they've done from a value standpoint. In terms of the ROFR, we got a pretty ex
componenttext: So we look at REX and I'd say Tallgrass has done a good job of creating value around a pipeline that was designed to go west to east and with what they've done. So we like what they've done from a value standpoint. In terms of the ROFR, we got a pretty expansive organic program that really fits around our Chemicals, Refining, NGL assets, and that's where the -- that capital goes. So we elected to stay where we are with that, and it really didn't scale our investment side to that. But we think Tallgrass is doing a good job creating value, so we like it -- the REX pipeline with that. And it gives us some insights into the gas markets as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And I guess, circling back to CPChem. Thinking about the cracker, I'm curious, your outlook for the economics of that project now versus the investment case. Obviously, you wouldn't have assumed that oil prices were going to be as low as
componenttext: Okay, understood. And I guess, circling back to CPChem. Thinking about the cracker, I'm curious, your outlook for the economics of that project now versus the investment case. Obviously, you wouldn't have assumed that oil prices were going to be as low as they are, but at the same time I assume that demand is probably better than you expected. So what are kind of the puts and takes there?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the volume side, we haven't wavered that it's going to be -- come up. There'll be good demand globally. You always going to get the cracker stable. So I think that's the good news. On the margin side, the spread between ethane and crude, a
componenttext: Yes, I think on the volume side, we haven't wavered that it's going to be -- come up. There'll be good demand globally. You always going to get the cracker stable. So I think that's the good news. On the margin side, the spread between ethane and crude, and that ultimately, that crude price sets those, say, polyethylene or derivative price, that's narrowed a bit. I think that our view would be that that's a -- upfront, a little bit of a headwind. But as you look out and if you believe crude comes back to another level above $60, and I think we looked at the premises still are pretty much in line with our investment thesis. So I think we still like it from a return standpoint. Even at today's margins, there's a significant cost advantage with this new complex just on the operating side of the business that offsets some of that margin. But I think we still have expectations that this will be a very strong profit driver for CPChem, for us. Our share of that on the EBITDA basis incrementally, as that crack -- just the cracker starts up, is roughly $500 million with some upside.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So another way to think about that is you look at kind of industry markers today, full chain margins. Ethane is $0.28, $0.29. That's certainly well above reinvestment levels. And so I think you'd be happy with that investment with today's margins out ther
componenttext: So another way to think about that is you look at kind of industry markers today, full chain margins. Ethane is $0.28, $0.29. That's certainly well above reinvestment levels. And so I think you'd be happy with that investment with today's margins out there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On -- just a couple of questions, one LPG and one on gasoline. On the LPG side, you guys talked about the -- you're looking for additional contracts on the capacity that you still have open. I was just curious, is that capacity or is that market to export
componenttext: On -- just a couple of questions, one LPG and one on gasoline. On the LPG side, you guys talked about the -- you're looking for additional contracts on the capacity that you still have open. I was just curious, is that capacity or is that market to export off your docks? Is that still in that $0.13 a gallon sort of range? Is that still the market price? Or is this something different?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that on a contract basis, you just -- we haven't disclosed the terms, specifically, and it's a range of things. I would say that the contract market long term is higher than the spot market. It's maybe how I'd like to answer that. So I think
componenttext: Well, I think that on a contract basis, you just -- we haven't disclosed the terms, specifically, and it's a range of things. I would say that the contract market long term is higher than the spot market. It's maybe how I'd like to answer that. So I think as you see these projects come on, the contract piece with the length that we're seeing -- or the short that we're seeing on the demand side has moved that spot market down. But we're still seeing good contract prices. And I think the customers that you talked to have a vision about long-term supply, and that's an important dimension. So I think with all assets you just have to look at the mix and decide which way you can go.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And did I hear your comments right that on the LPG sort of demand pull side on the export side of the equation that that's -- that right now that's fairly pricing elastic because of the demand for light feedstock into global petrochemical capacity?
componenttext: Okay. And did I hear your comments right that on the LPG sort of demand pull side on the export side of the equation that that's -- that right now that's fairly pricing elastic because of the demand for light feedstock into global petrochemical capacity? Or is that -- did I hear that wrong?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I was talking about we're fairly neutral in the U.S. about what we choose to crack. And so the length in the LPG still needs to be exported. We're still seeing good demand for PDH or propane dehydro units for cracker feeds around that. So I -- it was
componenttext: No, I was talking about we're fairly neutral in the U.S. about what we choose to crack. And so the length in the LPG still needs to be exported. We're still seeing good demand for PDH or propane dehydro units for cracker feeds around that. So I -- it was really a comment around the U.S. with its existing petrochemical operations, fairly stable. And we're close to indifferent in terms of feedstock, and every producer has their own preference for which feedstock they crack. And so that leaves you with that there's excess LPG that still needs to be exported. You're seeing it with propane, butane and some of the C5. And now you're starting to see some things happen on the ethane side as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what about ethylene, is that something that you could move across these docks as well?
componenttext: Okay. And what about ethylene, is that something that you could move across these docks as well?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So ethylene has actually been exported in limited quantities out of the U.S. and other parts. It's a more specialized trade. But yes, there's some interest in increased ethylene export capacity, and the ethane export capacity based on refrigeration is pre
componenttext: So ethylene has actually been exported in limited quantities out of the U.S. and other parts. It's a more specialized trade. But yes, there's some interest in increased ethylene export capacity, and the ethane export capacity based on refrigeration is pretty similar. So it's just the dock capacity is there. It's really around the refrigeration and how would you export that. And so can you convert what you have or just add to that to maybe add an ethylene dimension?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then on -- just on the gasoline side of the equation, so I understand the projects that you guys have sort of outstanding right now to, potentially, increase some of your gasoline yield. But if I'm looking at this coming summer versu
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then on -- just on the gasoline side of the equation, so I understand the projects that you guys have sort of outstanding right now to, potentially, increase some of your gasoline yield. But if I'm looking at this coming summer versus last summer -- because I believe last summer you were also somewhat maxed out in gasoline production capacity. Can you produce? Or would you think -- do you guys think you'll produce more gasoline -- finished gasoline this summer versus last summer?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we pretty much are running where we can. I would say, on the industry side one thing that's different this year is inventories are higher. So that may cap somewhat what you could see in terms of price response. At the same time, demand's up. S
componenttext: No, I think we pretty much are running where we can. I would say, on the industry side one thing that's different this year is inventories are higher. So that may cap somewhat what you could see in terms of price response. At the same time, demand's up. So days sales in inventories actually haven't grown as much as the gasoline absolute levels would indicate. And so I think we still expect a fairly strong gasoline driving season and a good gasoline crack through the next couple of quarters.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it doesn't sound like you could produce much more gasoline out of your system this summer versus last summer?
componenttext: Okay. So it doesn't sound like you could produce much more gasoline out of your system this summer versus last summer?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so.
componenttext: No, I don't think so.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: It really -- we really are running, essentially, about maximum capacity either on both the crude input side as well as the conversion side.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to reach out on the West Coast here. That's a place where the results came in a little bit soft relative to our expectations. Was there anything unusual in the first quarter, potentially the Plains pipeline outage or some turnaround activity t
componenttext: I just want to reach out on the West Coast here. That's a place where the results came in a little bit soft relative to our expectations. Was there anything unusual in the first quarter, potentially the Plains pipeline outage or some turnaround activity that could have impacted those results? And then as we have some of these FCCs come back online over the next couple of months, do you think the West Coast environment stays relatively strong just because we're going through a summer demand season? Or do you think we're going to see some margin compression out there?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we had San Francisco down on turnaround in the first quarter, so that impacted results versus what you would have thought. We still have some impact to Plains. It's less than $10 million for the quarter, but we're trying to mitigate that to the ex
componenttext: Yes, so we had San Francisco down on turnaround in the first quarter, so that impacted results versus what you would have thought. We still have some impact to Plains. It's less than $10 million for the quarter, but we're trying to mitigate that to the extent that we can. And then I think as Torrance comes back up it's going to have an impact in California. The good news is demand is up quite a bit relative to the last couple of years. And so I think you still got good demand going for you there, but I do think that you're not going to see the volatility in California that we've seen in the past year or 2.

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's helpful. And then stepping back, as you think about your whole portfolio here, is everything that's part of PSX right now would you consider core? I mean, I know the West Coast has come up in the past as a potential asset divestiture tar
componenttext: All right, that's helpful. And then stepping back, as you think about your whole portfolio here, is everything that's part of PSX right now would you consider core? I mean, I know the West Coast has come up in the past as a potential asset divestiture target. But what are your thoughts in terms of how your portfolio looks right now, and whether -- anything you would consider noncore here?

headline: Phillips 66, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do have a process underway at Whitegate, and we expect that we will conclude that process this year. California, we've talked about a lot. The hold cost or option value to hold is really not much. There's not a lot of capital in front of us in Calif
componenttext: So we do have a process underway at Whitegate, and we expect that we will conclude that process this year. California, we've talked about a lot. The hold cost or option value to hold is really not much. There's not a lot of capital in front of us in California. The last few years, margins have been very good in California, so it's a net cash contributor. And you think about could you sell the asset? Probably. But can we get good value for it? Probably not. And so I think we just hold it at this point in time. They're good assets. They're probably mid-back in terms where they sit in their cost structures. But given the option value to keep, I think we'll just hang on to them.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Erika, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Rosy Zukl
componenttext: Welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Erika, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Rosy Zuklic, General Manager, Investor Relations. Rosy, you may begin.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Greg Garland, Chairman and CEO; Tim Taylor, President; and Kevin Mitchell Executive Vice President and CFO. The material -- the presentation
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Greg Garland, Chairman and CEO; Tim Taylor, President; and Kevin Mitchell Executive Vice President and CFO. The material -- the presentation material we will be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website, along with supplemental financial and operating information. 
Slide 2 contains our safe harbor statement. It is a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ from today's comments. And factors that could cause those differences are listed here as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg Garland for some opening remarks. Greg?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone, thank you for joining us today. We're committed to our strategy of growing our high-value businesses and are focused on performing well. Operating excellence remains a top priority, operating safely, running our ass
componenttext:
Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone, thank you for joining us today. 
We're committed to our strategy of growing our high-value businesses and are focused on performing well. Operating excellence remains a top priority, operating safely, running our assets well and managing costs.  During the quarter, we delivered solid operational excellence performance. Refining performed at record rates, achieving 100% utilization. For the first half of the year, our personal safety metric, which we believe was already among the best in our industry, improving 16%. And process safety metric improved 75% compared to the prior year. 
In Chemicals, CPChem completed 3 major turnarounds this quarter. Global olefins and polyolefins businesses operated at 91% of capacity. BCP NGL volumes are up and reliability of operations improved. 
Total adjusted earnings for the second quarter were $499 million. The market environment remained challenging as low margins continue to impact DCP Midstream, NGL trading and Refining businesses. However, our fee-based Midstream business performed well, and we continue to see good demand in Chemicals. Although demand for refined products is up relative to last year, the weighted average market crack was more than $5 per barrel from where it was a year ago, and crude differentials remained tight. We remain focused and executing our strategy in those areas under our control. Our growth projects are all progressing well, and we continue to see great value and opportunity long term.
During the second quarter, the Dakota Access Pipeline project began laying pipe and is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Once in service, the pipeline is expected to provide the most economic option for moving Bakken crude to the Gulf Coast. 
In the Gulf Coast, the Beaumont Terminal expansion is ongoing. We have 3.2 million barrels of new storage capacity under construction, 2 million of which should be in service by year-end. We have plans to ultimately expand this facility to 16 million barrels. 
Also in the Gulf, development of the first phase of the Sweeny hub is nearing completion. Sweeny Fractionator One is operating well. However, volume mix across all of our fractionators remains impacted by heavier NGL feedstock as a result of continued ethane rejection.
We expect construction of the 150,000 barrel per day Freeport LPG terminal to be completed later this year. 
Our master limited partnership, Phillips 66 Partners, remains an important part of our midstream growth strategy and a significant source of attractive funding. In May, we completed $775 million drop-down, and PSXP successfully issued over $650 million of public equity.  PSXP increased its limited partnership distributions by 5% in the second quarter and remains on track to achieve its growth objective of a 5-year 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
DCP Midstream is making progress on its strategic initiatives. DCP expect to achieve cash breakeven at NGL prices below $0.35 per gallon this year. DCP is working on its cost structure, reducing capital and converting commodity-exposed contracts to fee-based to improve financial strength. We expect DCP to be self-funded going forward. 
CPChem continues to advance the U.S. Gulf Coast Petrochemicals Project. It is now 80% complete with an expected start-up in the second half of 2017. Once running, CPChem's global ethylene and polyethylene capacity will increase by approximately 1/3. As capital spending is reduced, we should see increased distributions from CPChem starting next year.
During the quarter, we advanced several refining projects. At the Wood River refinery, we're undergoing debottlenecking and are on schedule for completion in the third quarter. As the Billings Refinery, efforts are underway to increase the amount of heavy Canadian crude we can run to 100%. And at Bayway, work on the FCC modernization is progressing. These are all high-return, quick-payout projects. 
Our marketing specialty segment is the highest returning in our portfolio. In the U.S., we are increasing branded and unbranded volumes, and we're selectively pursuing incremental growth opportunities in Europe. 
We're mindful of the current market environment, and we've maintained our capital discipline approach in terms of how we allocate capital. We continue to target a long term 60-40 split between reinvestment in our business and distributions back to the shareholders. During the quarter, we generated over $1.8 billion in cash from operations and a PSXP equity offering. We returned over $570 million of capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases in the second quarter and increased our quarterly dividend by 12.5%.  This represents our sixth dividend increase since the formation of our company, with a 33% compound annual growth rate.  We returned $12.3 billion to shareholders over this 4-year period through dividends and repurchase or exchange of 118 million shares. [ph] We reinvested $620 million into our businesses during the quarter. 
We're looking at all of our projects in our portfolio to ensure that we only advance projects that meet our return expectations. We've made a decision to defer FID on frac 2. We're also working with our partners to project finance at [indiscernible]. 
We're going to give you some more detail on our 2016 capital expenditures later this summer. But at this point, we expect our capital expenditures for the year to come in below $3.3 billion, well below our $3.9 billion capital budget.
So now I'd like to turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to review the quarter results. Kevin?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, second quarter net income was $496 million. We had 2 special items that netted to a loss of $3 million. After removing these items, adjusted earnings were $499 million or; $0.94 per share. Cash from ope
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning. 
Starting on Slide 4, second quarter net income was $496 million. We had 2 special items that netted to a loss of $3 million. After removing these items, adjusted earnings were $499 million or; $0.94 per share. 
Cash from operations for the quarter was $1.2 billion. Excluding almost $600 million of working capital benefit, operating cash flow was $560 million. 
Undistributed equity earnings totaled almost $350 million.  Capital spending for the quarter was $620 million with approximately $340 million spent on growth, mostly in Midstream. Distributions to shareholders in the second quarter totaled $571 million, including $329 million in dividends and $242 million in share repurchases. 
At the end of the second quarter, our debt-to-capital ratio was 27%. After taking into account our ending cash balance, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 22%. 
Annualized adjusted return on capital employed was 6% for the first half of 2016. Our adjusted effective income tax rate for the second quarter was 31%.
Slide 5 compares second quarter and first quarter adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter adjusted earnings were up $139 million, driven mainly by improvements in Chemicals, Refining and Marketing and Specialties. 
Next, we will cover each of the segments individually.  I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. After removing the noncontrolling interest of $22 million, Midstream second quarter adjusted earnings were $39 million, in line with the first quarter. 
Our Transportation business is composed primarily of fee-based assets. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter were $65 million, down $7 million from the prior quarter, driven by higher operating costs, including seasonal maintenance.  Equity earnings from Rockies Express pipeline were lower due in part to contract restructuring to lengthen the term of a commitment. These items are partially offset by improved volumes. 
In NGL, adjusted losses were $17 million for the quarter. The $6 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by project expenses related to the Freeport LPG Export Terminal and lower earnings due to timing effects of seasonal storage. These decreases are partially offset by the benefit of higher fractionation volumes compared to the first quarter. 
Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were $9 million in the second quarter, a $12 million improvement compared to the previous quarter. This was primarily due to improved operational efficiencies, highly recoveries, continued cost savings and increased commodity prices.
Turning to Slide 7. In Chemicals, industry chain margins increased during the quarter, but demand for polyethylene remains strong. Second quarter adjusted earnings for the segment were $190 million, up $156 million from the first quarter. 
In olefins and polyolefins, adjusted earnings increased $25 million largely due to higher margins driven by increased polyethylene sales prices. In addition, equity earnings also improved due to stronger margins. This was partially offset by higher operating costs from planned turnaround activity. Global O&P utilization was 91%. Adjusted earnings for SANS rose by $9 million on higher equity earnings from increased sales prices. In Refining, we ran well with 100% crude utilization for the quarter. In addition, clean product yield increased from 82% to 84%, with gasoline yield at 45% for the quarter. Pretax turnaround costs were $69 million, $31 million lower than guidance due in part of the deferral of certain maintenance activities. Despite higher market cracks in all regions, realized margins were $7.13 per barrel, roughly the same as in the first quarter. But this was primarily due to higher losses on secondary products and lower clean product differentials. 
The chart on Slide 8 provides a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. In total, the Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $152 million, up $66 million from last quarter. Regionally, earnings were higher in the Atlantic Basin, Central Corridor and West Coast, reflecting the benefit of higher margins and volumes. Earnings were lower in the Gulf Coast as the benefit of higher volumes was more than offset by lower margins caused by lower product differentials and higher secondary product losses. 
Next, we will cover market capture on Slide 9.  Our worldwide realized margin was $7.13 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack of $13.84 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 52% compared to 67% in the first quarter. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries and our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 84% clean product yield for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. 
Losses from secondary products of $3.41 per barrel were $1.51 per barrel higher this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as Coke and NGLs increased. Feedstock advantage was slightly higher than the first quarter, but crude differentials generally remained tight. 
The other category mainly includes costs associated with , outgoing freight, product differentials and inventory impacts. These costs were higher than the first quarter primarily due to lower clean product differentials and higher gross margins prices. 
Let's move to Marketing and Specialties where we posted a strong second quarter despite the rising commodity price environment. Adjusted earnings for M&S in the second quarter were $229 million, up $24 million from the first quarter. In marketing and other, the $37 million increase was largely due to higher margins in international marketing and higher domestic gasoline volumes. Specialties adjusted earnings decreased by $13 million primarily as a result of lower base oil margins, partially offset by higher lubricants volumes. 
On Slide 11, the Corporate and Other segment had after-tax net costs of $111 million this quarter, an improvement of $16 million from the first quarter. Net interest expense decreased by $2 million, while corporate overhead and other expenses decreased by $14 million primarily due to lower legal and remediation accruals and lower taxes.
Slide 12 shows cash flow for the year-to-date. We began the year with a cash balance of $3.1 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations in the first half was $1.3 billion. Working capital changes increased cash flow by $100 million. In May, Phillips 66 Partners raised $656 million in a public equity offering. We funded $1.4 billion of capital expenditures and investments. And we distributed nearly $1.3 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the quarter with 523 million shares outstanding. At the end of June, our cash balance stood at $2.2 billion, up from $1.7 billion at the end of the first quarter.
This concludes my review of the financial and operational results. Next, I'll cover a few outlook items.
In the third quarter, in Chemicals, we expect the global O&P utilization rate to be in the mid-90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rate to be in the mid-90s and before-tax turnaround expenses to be between $100 million and $120 million. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $115 million and $125 million after-tax. And companywide, we expect the effective income tax rate to be in the mid-30s. 
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions for you. One, wanted to clarify that CapEx comment. I just wanted to make sure below $3.3 billion was for 2016. And assuming that is the case, with these project deferrals that you mentioned, I'm assuming that alleviates some of the pres
componenttext: I had 2 questions for you. One, wanted to clarify that CapEx comment. I just wanted to make sure below $3.3 billion was for 2016. And assuming that is the case, with these project deferrals that you mentioned, I'm assuming that alleviates some of the pressure on '17 spending. So any kind of thoughts our outlook onto '17 would be helpful.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're correct, the kind of guidance of below $3.3 billion was for 2016. We're still working '17, Blake, but I -- we've been saying for most of this year that we're in a glide slope to about $3 billion, maybe slightly under. So we'll give you some upda
componenttext: So you're correct, the kind of guidance of below $3.3 billion was for 2016. We're still working '17, Blake, but I -- we've been saying for most of this year that we're in a glide slope to about $3 billion, maybe slightly under. So we'll give you some updates in the fall for where we're going to be in '17, but I think around $3 billion, pretty good number for '17.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. The second question is economic run cuts. Obviously, we have your guidance in the mid-90s, which is below 2Q but still pretty healthy. Some of your smaller peers are already talking about run cuts in 3Q. I'm just curious, does your guidance contemp
componenttext: Great. The second question is economic run cuts. Obviously, we have your guidance in the mid-90s, which is below 2Q but still pretty healthy. Some of your smaller peers are already talking about run cuts in 3Q. I'm just curious, does your guidance contemplate any run cuts? Or do you envision that happening?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that I'll let Tim jump in on his view on the industry. I think most of ours is reflective of turnarounds at this point in time. We run our LPs frequently, and we'll make those decisions as we get into the end of the third quarter. But I thin
componenttext: Well, I think that I'll let Tim jump in on his view on the industry. I think most of ours is reflective of turnarounds at this point in time. We run our LPs frequently, and we'll make those decisions as we get into the end of the third quarter. But I think my personal view is, we got a lot of inventory stacked up. And I think the industry's going to be facing run cuts in the second half of the year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes , I guess we look at it and we think inventories as a global issue as we think about where the supplies come on this year. And ultimately, the way to rebalance the products that of the market is that run cuts will come. so I think everyone's kind of l
componenttext: Yes , I guess we look at it and we think inventories as a global issue as we think about where the supplies come on this year. And ultimately, the way to rebalance the products that of the market is that run cuts will come. so I think everyone's kind of looking at their own kit, configuration and will make those calls. But I think that, that is something that will happen to kind of rebalance the whole supply side. That said, the demand side's been good. So that's been the strength of it. We definitely responded as a global industry to a lot more supply.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The projects on the Gulf Coast, cracker, is that ahead of schedule? Or are we still looking at a sort of mid-'17 type start-up?
componenttext: The projects on the Gulf Coast, cracker, is that ahead of schedule? Or are we still looking at a sort of mid-'17 type start-up?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, well, there's 2 pieces of the cracker project. one is derivatives project, polyethylene plant at Sweeny. And the second is the cracker at Baytown, which is just east of Houston. derivatives plant is -- those projects are still online. They come
componenttext: Yes, Paul, well, there's 2 pieces of the cracker project. one is derivatives project, polyethylene plant at Sweeny. And the second is the cracker at Baytown, which is just east of Houston. derivatives plant is -- those projects are still online. They come online actually before the second half of 2017 to be complete. The cracker is now looking like it's going to complete in the second half of '17. And that's really the change that we are seeing primarily related to productivity and the complexity of that project. We're seeing several months delay. So continued to progress on both of those very well, but the cracker is behind where we're seeing the derivatives project at this point.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And somewhat related to a macro question, which also relates to another business division. But what is view of the NGL market here and availability for those projects of cheap feedstocks> general -- if you could just update us on your general view of what
componenttext: And somewhat related to a macro question, which also relates to another business division. But what is view of the NGL market here and availability for those projects of cheap feedstocks> general -- if you could just update us on your general view of what you're seen NGLs, that would be great.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. So on the NGL side, we had pretty strong response in the second quarter. Ethane started coming out of rejection but we've actually seen kind of NGL prices begin to fall and I think that the real key on this is, a, export demand and the pet chem
componenttext: Yes, okay. So on the NGL side, we had pretty strong response in the second quarter. Ethane started coming out of rejection but we've actually seen kind of NGL prices begin to fall and I think that the real key on this is, a, export demand and the pet chem demand in the industry. So we're still seeing supply and we're still seeing ethane interjection that's there to feed the new crackers start-up. until crackers start up on the ethane side, we think that will be the main driver starting to pull more ethane out of the gas stream, which should strengthen the ethane price. On the propane side, we've had strong exports. And that's kept for propane market really connected to the international pricing in the international markets. We saw some short-term cancellations, I think, this summer as really the differentials between the U.S. and some other market start to close. But we're starting to see corrections. And our view is long term, you still have excess in both ethane and propane. And then the propane has to leave the market to rebalance and clear it. And so I think that what you see us, you see the market start to readjust and returning to see some of that now in the pricing this month in July. So I think still overall still see a lot of value that LPG value chain and growing production as soon as crude oil production, gas production resumes out in the future.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, the only thing I'd add short term, we think it's going to be pressured here in the back half of the year, both crude and NGLs.
componenttext: Yes, Paul, the only thing I'd add short term, we think it's going to be pressured here in the back half of the year, both crude and NGLs.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Refining side, you've got diverse portfolio across multiple regions and in different types of refineries. Could you talk about which regions, which types of refineries might be most impacted as far as refinery runs in the type of market environment
componenttext: On the Refining side, you've got diverse portfolio across multiple regions and in different types of refineries. Could you talk about which regions, which types of refineries might be most impacted as far as refinery runs in the type of market environment that we are in now?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, it's Tim. I think fundamentally, simply refineries that run on light sweet crudes are going to be the most impacted. Clearly, there's been a sustained differentials on the heavy light side bias towards the heavy medium crudes as they're pretty
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, it's Tim. I think fundamentally, simply refineries that run on light sweet crudes are going to be the most impacted. Clearly, there's been a sustained differentials on the heavy light side bias towards the heavy medium crudes as they're pretty available. So I think that as you think about the system, we do expect the heavier-oriented refineries to be very competitive in the real pinch point comes on the white refineries around the globe. And then that depends a lot on their configuration as well. And clearly as usual, we -- if you think around the world, the Atlantic Basin is going to pinch point and possibly some of the operations in Asia as we think about that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Secondly, marketing and specialty performance was a stronger than we had anticipated. Could you talk a little bit about the strength in that segment? Maybe categorize some of the seasonal strength, some of the RINs and influence and maybe comment some of
componenttext: Secondly, marketing and specialty performance was a stronger than we had anticipated. Could you talk a little bit about the strength in that segment? Maybe categorize some of the seasonal strength, some of the RINs and influence and maybe comment some of the stronger aspects in that segment.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well it begins basically with a good demand, right? you've got pull-through in terms of demand and response we've seen globally by the consumer. Certainly in U.S. our volumes are up across him of the same-store sites, roughly 2.5%. So we produce more. We
componenttext: Well it begins basically with a good demand, right? you've got pull-through in terms of demand and response we've seen globally by the consumer. Certainly in U.S. our volumes are up across him of the same-store sites, roughly 2.5%. So we produce more. We actually moved into the market. So I think it reflects the strength of the demand side. And so we were able to capture a little better margin in terms of the value of our if he will our distribution wholesale markets base I think it speaks to strength their. The RINs interesting in terms of what's impact of the costs and the capture as it moves with her price, but I think that put a bias into the price of the product as well. And if were able to capture some of that. shows up as a cost in Refining, but it's a tailwind as well if you generate the RIN in marketing. But fundamentally, the spread, the wholesale margin was improved. and I think that really reflects in our mind the strength of the consumer gasoline market. Distillate remains rather flattish from our perspective.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned product exports, 174,000 barrels a day in the quarter, which was a strong quarter for exports. Maybe a quick comment on that, and I'll let you go.
componenttext: You mentioned product exports, 174,000 barrels a day in the quarter, which was a strong quarter for exports. Maybe a quick comment on that, and I'll let you go.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we did. we were able to bring up exports about 50,000 barrels a day, good opportunity in. So I think we just look at the decisions better inland or export sale. Clearly the Gulf Coast for us is a big piece of that. And we're very well positione
componenttext: Yes, well, we did. we were able to bring up exports about 50,000 barrels a day, good opportunity in. So I think we just look at the decisions better inland or export sale. Clearly the Gulf Coast for us is a big piece of that. And we're very well positioned to supply the demand in Latin America as seeing reduction in the rates down there. So it was a good market. And then you had RIN value on top of that  that provides some incentive as well. So I think the export market would likely stay strong for U.S. refiners on the Gulf Coast.

So substantial cash flow swing at CPChem, if you think about free cash flow. And saw we are anticipating that we'll get strong distributions back from CPChem here, beginning particularly in 2018.

componenttext: My follow-up, if I may, going back to the capital question broadly. It seems you're maintaining the 5 -- return capital to shareholders, whereas the capital seems to taking the flex [ph] of the environment. I'm just wondering is that the right interpretation going forward? In other words, how do you see your buyback strategy as it relates to your proceeds from future PSX equity sales and drop-downs and so on? Is that something we should expect to be ratable? Or is there some -- ... ?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so any kind of -- let me kind of dissect that and talk about them both. I think what we said was in terms of the capital spend at PSX, we've always been on a glide slope towards $3 billion. There's no question, our capital in the last 2 years has bee
componenttext: Yes, so any kind of -- let me kind of dissect that and talk about them both. I think what we said was in terms of the capital spend at PSX, we've always been on a glide slope towards $3 billion. There's no question, our capital in the last 2 years has been very high as we tried to advance the Midstream business and get PSXP to scale quickly. So that was a decision we took really kind of in '12 coming into '13. When we think about share repurchase, we think about intrinsic value. And as long as the shares are trading below intrinsic value, we're going to be in the market buying. So we're in the market every day buying. Some days, we buys want more than others, that's true. and I'd say consistent with our guidance and we've been giving in 2016, we're going to be between $1 billion and $2 billion of share repurchases this year.

componenttext: Yes, Ed, this is Kevin. So bear in mind that the almost $350 million of undistributed equity earnings. So that gets reflected in the earnings number, but the distributions aren't coming back. The bulk of that is in CPChem, but you also see it with the WRB, JV, Excel Paralubes [ph] and there a lot of smaller JVs. Some of those, it's reflected of the investment that's taking place inside of those JVs that's consuming that cash. Some of it, a portion is just timing effects that the distributions aren't necessarily ratable. So you think about the $560  million of cash flow, excluding working capital, if you were to add back the undisputed equity earnings put it on sort of a consistent basis, that's just over $900 million of operating cash flow, which then lines up with -- what you'd expect from the earnings generated given the environment.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I think -- I mean, we've always consistently said we've never built a speculative frac. And I think our view is NGLs continue to grow, but they're going to grow slower than what we saw 2 years ago. And so I think that's a decision to push the FID on
componenttext: Well I think -- I mean, we've always consistently said we've never built a speculative frac. And I think our view is NGLs continue to grow, but they're going to grow slower than what we saw 2 years ago. And so I think that's a decision to push the FID on track 2 simply reflects that, Ed.

componenttext: Yes, I think that's a something we always look at every day in terms of inorganic growth. other thing I would say we still have a pretty good backlog of organic projects that we can vest in around our own infrastructure, whether it's more terminals, butane blending, ethanol blending, more pipes.
