headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basically, our major maintenance turnaround is still on schedule as planned. These are relatively small unit turnarounds and just were able to differ. So they just move around sometimes on planning basis but the fundamentals way that we go about the ma
componenttext: So basically, our major maintenance turnaround is still on schedule as planned. These are relatively small unit turnarounds and just were able to differ. So they just move around sometimes on planning basis but the fundamentals way that we go about the major Turner on planning is unchanged so I think our guidance. We typically get to a turnaround expenses pretty consistent year-on-year, flexes a little bit more depending on which refinery [indiscernible]. But we really haven't changed our philosophy on turnaround expenditures and timing of those.

componenttext: I wanted to circle back on some of the CapEx conversations from earlier in the call, Greg, respecting that you said you give more detail later the summer, I think. But I'm curious why the CapEx is coming and saw low. Obviously you cited the frac 2 deferral, but I wouldn't think that there was any CapEx in the budget for that. And it sounds like the major projects are on budget. So what exactly is it that's leading to the lower numbers?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's several projects in Midstream be on track to that we are looking at. I also mentioned the project financing of DAPL and . so that's going to be a very classic type project finance and. So our share of that would be somewhere around $600 million
componenttext: Well, it's several projects in Midstream be on track to that we are looking at. I also mentioned the project financing of DAPL and . so that's going to be a very classic type project finance and. So our share of that would be somewhere around $600 million-ish, I would say. Probably most of it will be '16, maybe a little bit spill over in '17. If you sum all that up and that's really how you get to a $3.3 billion level. And frankly we're still working the numbers. And I suspect it's going to come below $3.3 billion when we give you guidance in a couple of months.

Obviously the farm has been opened but it seems like products going the tanks on the East Coast so something seems to have to give on the Refining utilization a significant since you guys see both sides of the market there, how do you see that playing out?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're right. We've had a lot of build of inventory in pad 1 in New York harbor. There's been an incentive on Europe to continue to run. I think that reflects storage economics right now. But that is a place that reached a rebalance of somewhere betw
componenttext: Yes, you're right. We've had a lot of build of inventory in pad 1 in New York harbor. There's been an incentive on Europe to continue to run. I think that reflects storage economics right now. But that is a place that reached a rebalance of somewhere between the U.S. East Coast and some of the European refineries. We still look at that . There needs to be some balancing on the inventory side where the production side to balance that out and that typically tends to be a more immersion over higher cost area is another reason we think a lot about that there's a lot of dynamics in play and we have to see how it shakes out but no matter how you cut someplace, you bought another production of demand in balance a bit more the Refining size. that's why we anticipate that run cuts come. And that would seem to be one of the places we look at that think that could occur.

componenttext: So I would say we're still in process on Whitegate. I think I would tell you we are pleased with the progress at this point. And hopefully, as I said I think the last quarter, our intention is we get this closed this year.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one, a follow-up question regarding some of the PSX and PSXP strategy. I guess just curious as to whether organic cash flow business, at the base business, if you were to continue to see Refining of the Midstream and so on through 3Q and 4Q. Do
componenttext: Maybe just one, a follow-up question regarding some of the PSX and PSXP strategy. I guess just curious as to whether organic cash flow business, at the base business, if you were to continue to see Refining of the Midstream and so on through 3Q and 4Q. Does the level of organic cash flow accelerate or change the pace at all if PSXP drops in terms of how you see the timing play in '16?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think again, we look at PSXP. We talked about our $1.1 billion target. You've got to continue to progress to make the distribution coverage. So we have a strong background of MLP income available. And so we are going to continue to grow that there i
componenttext: No, I think again, we look at PSXP. We talked about our $1.1 billion target. You've got to continue to progress to make the distribution coverage. So we have a strong background of MLP income available. And so we are going to continue to grow that there in 2018. So we're continuing to see good midstream cash flows in every fee-based assets, and that's a key component of what we want PSXP to do.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just one on M&A. On your strategic portion of the note, you can't you're evaluating all parts of your portfolio what I haven't seen in prior releases. Is there -- can you I guess can you expand anymore on that, things looking at in the por
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just one on M&A. On your strategic portion of the note, you can't you're evaluating all parts of your portfolio what I haven't seen in prior releases. Is there -- can you I guess can you expand anymore on that, things looking at in the portfolio? Would you be considering selling anything within the portfolio? And if so, is there anything you can comment in terms of noncore things that might potentially be on the table?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that my comments earlier were around the capital budget and the projects that we have on debt in ensuring that any project we do meet our hurdle rates expectations. In terms of the overall portfolio, of course, we have the process on Whitegat
componenttext: Yes, I think that my comments earlier were around the capital budget and the projects that we have on debt in ensuring that any project we do meet our hurdle rates expectations. In terms of the overall portfolio, of course, we have the process on Whitegate that we talked about. But I think as we come to the end of the Whitegate process, I don't think there's a lot more in the portfolio that we have on deck, certainly for '16 or thinking about it, into '17. In terms of potential M&A, I mean, we look at it every day. I would say that price is still relatively high to us relative to the organic opportunities we made have in front of us, but we would look at that. And if we can find assets for the right value, we're certainly willing to do that. I think that the Explorer 1 [ph] was a good example, but that was at the PSXP level. And I think in terms of the Midstream, you'll see us doing more and more activities at the PSXP level.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Greg, I want to go back to your prepared comments around the Freeport export facility. I think that's -- that is beginning the commissioning phase right now. And if I remember right, I think the contracted volumes were, I think, 6 cargoes a month. I just wanted to make sure I understand some of your commentary around that, since you were talking about a lower number in the commissioning phase.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're about 97% complete on the LPG terminal. There's different pieces. So we're actually right at the front end of our commissioning and drawing out process, getting ready. So we anticipate that will be operational toward the end of the year. But
componenttext: Yes, so we're about 97% complete on the LPG terminal. There's different pieces. So we're actually right at the front end of our commissioning and drawing out process, getting ready. So we anticipate that will be operational toward the end of the year. But we are actually essentially completing construction and now working into the commissioning piece of that business. So that's about to become operational. On the market side, yes -- yes about contracts. We continue the contracts. As Greg said, the commodity environment is challenged today. So I think that the commercial arm or opportunity is narrower than what we originally planned in the short term, but we still see fundamentally that strength. And as I said, it's got to clear the market here somewhere to really make everything balance just based on the demand side. So we feel pretty good about the longer-term fundamentals there with some stress short term I think on the commercial side of that. But the load across that looks really solid to us, and we continue to work that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. do the contracts support the ramp you guys talked about of up to 400 -- $300 million to $400 million in EBITDA? Because I want to make sure that the current situation in the market doesn't impact how we model those cash flows ramping up into the first half next year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've said that the EBITDA on that project, $400 million to $500 million, 20% or so would be commercial opportunities. And so the ramp-up schedule relates more to the fee. And I think that what we're seeing is that opportunities for that are going to b
componenttext: So we've said that the EBITDA on that project, $400 million to $500 million, 20% or so would be commercial opportunities. And so the ramp-up schedule relates more to the fee. And I think that what we're seeing is that opportunities for that are going to be a bit lower, but in the commercial arm, we're seeing most of the compression in terms of that run rate. But we're ready to ramp up when that thing comes operational as these contract start to kick in and we're -- we get the asset in play. But that takes a bit of time as you bring up the operation.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the marketing specialty side, obviously that business continues to remain strong and generate high returns on capital. It looks like you're investing a little bit more capital in that business is if I'm looking at some of the commentary corre
componenttext: Okay. And on the marketing specialty side, obviously that business continues to remain strong and generate high returns on capital. It looks like you're investing a little bit more capital in that business is if I'm looking at some of the commentary correctly, so the upgrading of sites, buying more additional sites in Europe. And I'm just wondering if you could comment about whether you are you are sort of increasing the amount of capital into that business, with sort of the addition of sites and sort of improvement of branded sites across your network.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Faisal, most of that capital, capital investment in sites is in Europe. We have a great market position, good return, but it's going to be modest just given the size of the market and the rate at which it's grown. So it's really, I think a level that w
componenttext: So Faisal, most of that capital, capital investment in sites is in Europe. We have a great market position, good return, but it's going to be modest just given the size of the market and the rate at which it's grown. So it's really, I think a level that we see continuing to go forward. On the U.S. side a little bit of capital of the marketing site for that but most of this is done for our dealers and our marketers, our customers and so it's part of our marketing structure but making good progress in terms of revamping the sites, but many of the 76 or the Phillips 66 brand and we are seeing increased poultry to the branded chain so we are strengthening that really our marketing and commercial relationships versus a capital investment piece of that we are driving.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay last question for me, you guys talked about sort of the headwind from secondary products pricing during the quarter. Is most of that now resolved, now that crude flattened and come off a bit? I just want to make sure I understand sort of that had wit
componenttext: Okay last question for me, you guys talked about sort of the headwind from secondary products pricing during the quarter. Is most of that now resolved, now that crude flattened and come off a bit? I just want to make sure I understand sort of that had witnessed of continuing in third quarter? or is it completely been sort of resolved?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, crude ran up quite a bit in the second quarter. So it comes off. The margin, say, a coke and a crew that, that differential widens back out. That said, some of the other products are LPG's. And to the extent that NGL prices I mean, propane prices com
componenttext: Yes, crude ran up quite a bit in the second quarter. So it comes off. The margin, say, a coke and a crew that, that differential widens back out. That said, some of the other products are LPG's. And to the extent that NGL prices I mean, propane prices come down significantly here recently. And so as you see that, it's kind of a moving target. But generally, we do better with lower crude prices in terms of the secondary product loss, if you will, that narrows. And it basically a boost or tailwind for our margins.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, for the -- is there a number that you can share on the fractionator 1 that seems to come onstream late last year? What's the contribution in the second quarter? And also when the LPG export terminal are up and running? Should we assume that
componenttext: Just curious, for the -- is there a number that you can share on the fractionator 1 that seems to come onstream late last year? What's the contribution in the second quarter? And also when the LPG export terminal are up and running? Should we assume that the entire Sweeny NGL hub is going to report on the NGL business, or that the LPG terminal is going to be in the transportation segment?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be in NGL. Let me take a -- maybe a 30,000-foot view on this question, if I can. And then Tim can come in behind me and give you some of the details. So I know you have a concern around this, and we understand that. If I can just go to the 30,000-
componenttext: It will be in NGL. Let me take a -- maybe a 30,000-foot view on this question, if I can. And then Tim can come in behind me and give you some of the details. So I know you have a concern around this, and we understand that. If I can just go to the 30,000-foot level and just talk about the Sweeny hub in general, we still think that that's a great project and we see value creation opportunity there. If you think about NGL pipes coming out of the Permian, West Texas and the Eagle Ford and going by Sweeny, you think about world-class refining, world-class petrochemicals. We have the largest single site ethylene facility at Sweeny. We have -- we're building 1.2 million tons of polyethylene capacity building the fractionator. We're building the caverns. [ph] We're building the interconnecting pipes to Belvieu and on to Freeport, and then the 150,000 barrel a day LPG export facility. So we still like that concept in what we're creating there. I think short-term what you're seeing in the market, there's going to be stress in the LPG side of it. The frac is running well. It's running to design limits. We're seeing certainly heavier feed than what we premised. So we're running about 80 at the frac today versus 100%. But it's completely loaded in the back end of the frac. The other thing I would say is, as this project is coming up, we have a lot of project expenses that are hitting us beyond just the frac. So think about the pipes and the caverns and the commissioning the start-up of the LPG export facility. So you should expect to see those costs continue through the end of 2016. But when we talk about the frac itself, we drop it, all of it. It's at PSXP today. The [indiscernible] is off [ph] about $100 million, so $25 million a quarter. There's a little bit of leakage that goes to the noncontrolling interest, but -- so then you take that and bring it to the net income level. And that was more than offset by the project expenses we had and the seasonal trading activities that we had in our NGL business. So I think that we are not worried about this whole NGL complex we're building at Sweeny in terms of it coming up. And we're looking forward to getting the LPG export up later this year. We'll start commissioning activities actually the next couple of weeks as we start thinking about that. And so I just want to say that we still really like this project a lot. And Tim, if you want to fill anything I missed, you're welcome to do that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I really think it's about the total. And, Paul, so you know it's a PSXP asset. Greg said we're down a little bit with ethane, ethane rejection comes up naturally. It also starts to look more of the pipe and the caverns there. a relatively small contri
componenttext: No, I really think it's about the total. And, Paul, so you know it's a PSXP asset. Greg said we're down a little bit with ethane, ethane rejection comes up naturally. It also starts to look more of the pipe and the caverns there. a relatively small contribution, but it's up and it's running a lot better that great operational improvement this second quarter and so that's what we're focused on of that we get got to get this LPG up and get the entire value chain going on that one.

componenttext: My first question is you talked about the $400 million of income at PSXP going to $1.1 billion. I just want to clarify is that all I guess project-related EBITDA? Or some of that drop? And I guess what I mean, is I'm just trying to understand how much Midstream EBITDA growth you're expecting from '16 to '17, given that you have a lot of onetime costs that you're incurring this year to ramp the project?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: so the $1.1 billion is a target of both existing assets when we began as well as our growth projects. As we think about the compositions of the exactly what we drop when is something we always look at. So it's going to be a combination of both of those. B
componenttext: so the $1.1 billion is a target of both existing assets when we began as well as our growth projects. As we think about the compositions of the exactly what we drop when is something we always look at. So it's going to be a combination of both of those. But as you look at the Midstream EBITDA, we put out in 2018, we grow from around $1 billion say in Refining and Midstream income when we started in '13, '14, pushing that up over $2 billion. So that's really the growth that's there. some of that's commodity as well. So there's some depending on the commodity markets, could be some [indiscernible] about 20%. And that's really how we think about it is that look through EBITDA, you've got $1 billion plus of EBITDA growth over that period. But what you put in the PSXP is a mix question that we really don't address specifically.

componenttext: Okay. My second question is for Kevin on the balance sheet. In the past, we've talked about whether you consolidated balance sheet or ex-PSXP. generally curious how you're thinking about that today? And with this macro environment we're seeing in the back half that could be potentially worse than the first half on free cash flow, general willingness to use the balance sheet and interim period to continue buybacks, noting that 2Q buybacks were in lowest we've seen in a couple of years.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, the -- so debt to capital 27%, fully consolidated at the end of the second quarter, on a net basis, 22%. When you exclude PSXP, I think it's 25% total, 19% on a net cash basis. So still a fair amount of headroom from a balance sheet standpoint, ba
componenttext: So yes, the -- so debt to capital 27%, fully consolidated at the end of the second quarter, on a net basis, 22%. When you exclude PSXP, I think it's 25% total, 19% on a net cash basis. So still a fair amount of headroom from a balance sheet standpoint, balance sheet capacity to weather the ups and downs in the market. Most of the capital programming, Greg talked about $3.9 billion [ph] capital budget coming to something 3.3-ish for the year. But a lot of the capital is locked in. And so that's where having the balance sheet capability to deal with that over that time period certainly helps us. The MLP model is a critical part of the overall funding. So as we continue to grow the MLP drop down assets, you'll see cash coming back to the PSX level and it's going to be in the form of equity raises like we did in the second quarter annual see debt going on the MLP.

componenttext: Just one thing, Phil, that I would add to that. We're kind of a glide slope to $3 billion. And so think about kind of $1 billion-ish of sustaining capital and $2 billion of for growth. Both of that growth is really directed towards Midstream and a fully expect that we can fund that coming out of the MLP.
