componenttext: Welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Phillips 66 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Erica, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Rosy Zuklic, General Manager, Investor Relations. Rosy, you may begin.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Greg Garland, Chairman and CEO; Tim Taylor, President; and Kevin Mitchell Executive Vice President and CFO. The material -- the presentation
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to the Phillips 66 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Greg Garland, Chairman and CEO; Tim Taylor, President; and Kevin Mitchell Executive Vice President and CFO. The material -- the presentation material we will be using during the call can be found on the Investor Relations section of the Phillips 66 website along with supplemental financial and operating information. 
Slide 2 contains our safe harbor statement. It is a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the presentation and our question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ from today's comments, and factors that could cause those differences are listed here as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg Garland for some opening remarks. Greg?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We're committed to our strategy of growing our high-value businesses and are focused on performing well. Operating excellence remains a top priority, operating safely, running our a
componenttext:
Thanks, Rosy. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We're committed to our strategy of growing our high-value businesses and are focused on performing well. Operating excellence remains a top priority, operating safely, running our assets well and managing cost. During the quarter, we delivered solid operational excellence performance. Refining performed at record rates, achieving 100% utilization. For the first half of the year, our personnel safety metric, which we believe was already among the best in our industry, improved 16%. And our process safety metric improved 75% compared to the prior year. 
In Chemicals, CPChem completed 3 major turnarounds this quarter. The global olefins and polyolefins businesses operated at 91% of capacity. DCP NGL volumes were up and reliability of operations improved. 
Total adjusted earnings for the second quarter were $499 million. The market environment remained challenging as low margins continued to impact our DCP Midstream, NGL trading and Refining businesses. However, our fee-based Midstream business performed well, and we continue to see good demand in Chemicals. Although demand for refined products is up relative to last year, the weighted average market crack was more than $5 per barrel from where it was a year ago and crude differentials remained tight. We remain focused on executing our strategy in those areas under our control. Our growth projects are all progressing well, and we continue to see great value and opportunity long term.
During the second quarter, the Dakota Access Pipeline project began laying pipe and is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Once in service, the DAPL ETCOP pipeline is expected to provide the most economic option for moving Bakken crude to the Gulf Coast. 
In the Gulf Coast, the Beaumont Terminal expansion is ongoing. We have 3.2 million barrels of new storage capacity under construction, 2 million of which should be in service by year end. We have plans to ultimately expand this facility to 16 million barrels. 
Also in the Gulf, development of the first phase of the Sweeny hub is nearing completion. Sweeny Fractionator One is operating well; however, volume mix across all of our fractionators remains impacted by heavier NGL feedstock as a result of continued ethane rejection.
We expect construction of the 150,000 barrel per day Freeport LPG export terminal to be completed later this year. Our master limited partnership, Phillips 66 Partners, remains an important part of our midstream growth strategy and a significant source of attractive funding. In May, we completed $775 million drop-down, and PSXP successfully issued over $650 million of public equity.  PSXP increased its limited partner distributions by 5% in the second quarter and remains on track to achieve its growth objective of a 5-year 30% distribution compound annual growth rate through 2018. 
DCP Midstream is making progress on its strategic initiatives. DCP expects to achieve cash breakeven at NGL prices below $0.35 per gallon this year. DCP is working on its cost structure, reducing capital and converting commodity-exposed contracts to fee-based to improve financial strength. We expect DCP to be self-funded going forward. 
CPChem continues to advance the U.S. Gulf Coast Petrochemicals Project. It is now 80% complete with an expected startup in the second half of 2017. Once running, CPChem's global ethylene and polyethylene capacity will increase by approximately 1/3. As capital spending is reduced, we should see increased distributions from CPChem starting next year.
During the quarter, we advanced several refining projects. At the Wood River Refinery, we're undergoing debottlenecking and are on schedule for completion in the third quarter. At the Billings Refinery, efforts are underway to increase the amount of heavy Canadian crude we can run to 100%. And at Bayway, work on the FCC modernization is progressing. These are all high-return, quick-payout projects. 
Our Marketing and Specialties segment is the highest returning in our portfolio. In the U.S., we are increasing branded and unbranded volumes, and we're selectively pursuing incremental growth opportunities in Europe. 
We're mindful of the current market environment, and we've maintained our capital-disciplined approach in terms of how we allocate capital. We continue to target a long-term 60-40 split between reinvestment in our business and distributions back to the shareholders. During the quarter, we generated over $1.8 billion in cash from operations and a PSXP equity offering. We returned over $570 million of capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases in the second quarter and increased our quarterly dividend by 12.5%. This represents our sixth dividend increase since the formation of our company with a 33% compound annual growth rate. We've returned $12.3 billion to shareholders over this 4-year period through dividends and repurchase or exchange of 118 million shares. We reinvested $620 million into our businesses during the quarter. 
We're looking at all of our projects in our portfolio to ensure that we only advance projects that meet our return expectations. We've made a decision to defer FID on Frac 2. We're also working with our partners to project finance DAPL ETCOP.
We're going to give you some more detail around our 2016 capital expenditures later this summer. But at this point, we expect our capital expenditures for the year to come in below $3.3 billion, well below our $3.9 billion capital budget.
So now I'd like to turn the call over to Kevin Mitchell to review the quarter results. Kevin?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, second quarter net income was $496 million. We had 2 special items that netted to a loss of $3 million. After removing these items, adjusted earnings were $499 million or $0.94 per share. Cash from operatio
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning. Starting on Slide 4, second quarter net income was $496 million. We had 2 special items that netted to a loss of $3 million. After removing these items, adjusted earnings were $499 million or $0.94 per share. Cash from operations for the quarter was $1.2 billion. Excluding almost $600 million of working capital benefit, operating cash flow was $560 million. Undistributed equity earnings totaled almost $350 million. Capital spending for the quarter was $620 million with approximately $340 million spent on growth, mostly in Midstream. Distributions to shareholders in the second quarter totaled $571 million, including $329 million in dividends and $242 million in share repurchases. 
At the end of the second quarter, our debt-to-capital ratio was 27%. And after taking into account our ending cash balance, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 22%. Annualized adjusted return on capital employed was 6% for the first half of 2016. Our adjusted effective income tax rate for the second quarter was 31%.
Slide 5 compares second quarter and first quarter adjusted earnings by segment. Quarter-over-quarter adjusted earnings were up $139 million, driven mainly by improvements in Chemicals, Refining and Marketing and Specialties. 
Next we will cover each of the segments individually. I'll start with Midstream on Slide 6. After removing the noncontrolling interest of $22 million, Midstream's second quarter adjusted earnings were $39 million, in line with the first quarter. Our Transportation business is composed primarily of fee-based assets. Transportation adjusted earnings for the quarter were $65 million, down $7 million from the prior quarter, driven by higher operating costs including seasonal maintenance. Equity earnings from Rockies Express pipeline were lower, due in part to contract restructuring to lengthen the term of a commitment. These items were partially offset by improved volumes. 
In NGL, adjusted losses were $17 million for the quarter. The $6 million decrease from the prior quarter was largely driven by project expenses related to the Freeport LPG Export Terminal and lower earnings due to timing effects of seasonal storage. These decreases were partially offset by the benefit of higher fractionation volumes compared to the first quarter. 
Adjusted losses for DCP Midstream were $9 million in the second quarter, a $12 million improvement compared to the previous quarter. This was primarily due to improved operational efficiencies, higher recoveries, continued cost savings and increased commodity prices.
Turning to Slide 7. In Chemicals, industry chain margins increased during the quarter as demand for polyethylene remains strong. Second quarter adjusted earnings for the segment were $190 million, up $156 million from the first quarter. In olefins and polyolefins, adjusted earnings increased $25 million largely due to higher margins driven by increased polyethylene sales prices. In addition, equity earnings also improved due to stronger margins. This was partially offset by higher operating cost from planned turnaround activity. Global O&P utilization was 91%. Adjusted earnings for SA&S rose by $9 million on higher equity earnings from increased sales prices. 
In Refining, we ran well with 100% crude utilization for the quarter. In addition, clean product yield increased from 82% to 84%, with gasoline yield at 45% for the quarter. Pretax turnaround costs were $69 million, $31 million lower than guidance, due in part of the deferral of certain maintenance activities. Despite higher market cracks in all regions, realized margins were $7.13 per barrel, roughly the same as in the first quarter. This was primarily due to higher losses on secondary products and lower clean product differentials. 
The chart on Slide 8 provides a regional view of the change in adjusted earnings compared to the previous quarter. In total, the Refining segment had adjusted earnings of $152 million, up $66 million from last quarter. Regionally, earnings were higher in the Atlantic Basin, Central Corridor and West Coast, reflecting the benefit of higher margins and volumes. Earnings were lower in the Gulf Coast as the benefit of higher volumes was more than offset by lower margins caused by lower product differentials and higher secondary product losses. 
Next, we will cover market capture on Slide 9. Our worldwide realized margin was $7.13 per barrel versus the 3:2:1 market crack of $13.84 per barrel, resulting in an overall market capture of 52% compared to 67% in the first quarter. Market capture is impacted in part by the configuration of our refineries and our production relative to the market crack calculation. With 84% clean product yield for the quarter, we made less gasoline and slightly more distillate than premised in the 3:2:1 market crack. Losses from secondary products of $3.41 per barrel were $1.51 per barrel higher this quarter as the price differential between crude oil and lower valued products such as coke and NGLs increased. Feedstock advantage was slightly higher in the -- than the first quarter, but crude differentials generally remained tight. The other category mainly includes costs associated with RINs, outgoing freight, product differentials and inventory impacts. These costs were higher than the first quarter, primarily due to lower clean product differentials and higher RINs prices. 
Let's move to Marketing and Specialties, where we posted a strong second quarter despite the rising commodity price environment. Adjusted earnings for M&S in the second quarter were $229 million, up $24 million from the first quarter. In marketing and other, the $37 million increase was largely due to higher margins in international marketing and higher domestic gasoline volumes. Specialties adjusted earnings decreased by $13 million, primarily as a result of lower base oil margins, partially offset by higher lubricants volumes. 
On Slide 11, the Corporate and Other segment had after-tax net costs of $111 million this quarter, an improvement of $16 million from the first quarter. Net interest expense decreased by $2 million, while corporate overhead and other expenses decreased by $14 million primarily due to lower legal and remediation accruals and lower taxes.
Slide 12 shows cash flow for the year-to-date. We began the year with a cash balance of $3.1 billion. Excluding working capital impacts, cash from operations in the first half was $1.3 billion. Working capital changes increased cash flow by $100 million. In May, Phillips 66 Partners raised $656 million in a public equity offering. We funded $1.4 billion of capital expenditures and investments, and we distributed nearly $1.3 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We ended the quarter with 523 million shares outstanding. At the end of June, our cash balance stood at $2.2 billion, up from $1.7 billion at the end of the first quarter.
This concludes my review of the financial and operational results. Next, I'll cover a few outlook items. In the third quarter, in Chemicals, we expect the global O&P utilization rates to be in the mid-90s. In Refining, we expect the worldwide crude utilization rate to be in the mid-90s and before-tax turnaround expenses to be between $100 million and $120 million. We expect Corporate and Other costs to come in between $115 million and $125 million after-tax. And company-wide, we expect the effective income tax rate to be in the mid-30s. 
With that, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, Erica, we're ready for questions.
componenttext: Hello, Erica, we're ready for questions.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions for you. One, I wanted to clarify the CapEx comment. I just wanted to make sure that below $3.3 billion was indeed for 2016. And assuming that is the case, with these project deferrals that you mentioned, I'm assuming that alleviates som
componenttext: I had 2 questions for you. One, I wanted to clarify the CapEx comment. I just wanted to make sure that below $3.3 billion was indeed for 2016. And assuming that is the case, with these project deferrals that you mentioned, I'm assuming that alleviates some of the pressure on '17 spending. So any kind of thoughts or outlook on to '17 would be helpful.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're correct, the kind of guidance of below $3.3 billion was for 2016. We're still working '17, Blake. But I -- we've been saying for most of this year that we're on a glide slope to about $3 billion, maybe slightly under. So we'll give you some upda
componenttext: So you're correct, the kind of guidance of below $3.3 billion was for 2016. We're still working '17, Blake. But I -- we've been saying for most of this year that we're on a glide slope to about $3 billion, maybe slightly under. So we'll give you some updates in the fall of where we're going to be in '17. But I think around $3 billion, pretty good number for '17.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second question is on the economic run cuts. Obviously, we have your guidance here in the mid-90s, which is below 2Q but still pretty healthy. Some of your smaller peers are already talking about run cuts in 3Q. I'm just curious, does your guidance co
componenttext: The second question is on the economic run cuts. Obviously, we have your guidance here in the mid-90s, which is below 2Q but still pretty healthy. Some of your smaller peers are already talking about run cuts in 3Q. I'm just curious, does your guidance contemplate any run cuts, or do you envision that happening?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that I'll let Tim jump in on his view on the industry. I think most of ours is reflective of turnarounds at this point in time. We run our LPs pretty frequently, and we'll make those decisions as we get into the third quarter. But I think my
componenttext: Well, I think that I'll let Tim jump in on his view on the industry. I think most of ours is reflective of turnarounds at this point in time. We run our LPs pretty frequently, and we'll make those decisions as we get into the third quarter. But I think my personal view is we've got a lot of inventory stacked up, and I think the industry is going to be facing run cuts in the second half of the year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake, I guess, we look at it and we think about the inventories heading in as a global issue as we think about where the supplies come on this year. And ultimately, the way to rebalance the products out of the market is that run cuts will come. So I
componenttext: Yes, Blake, I guess, we look at it and we think about the inventories heading in as a global issue as we think about where the supplies come on this year. And ultimately, the way to rebalance the products out of the market is that run cuts will come. So I think everyone is kind of looking at their own kit, configuration and will make those calls. But I think that, that is something that will happen to kind of rebalance the whole supply side. That said, the demand side has been good. So that's been the strength of it. We've definitely responded as a global industry to a lot more supply.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The projects on the Gulf Coast, the cracker, is that ahead of schedule? Or are we still looking at a sort of mid-'17 type startup?
componenttext: The projects on the Gulf Coast, the cracker, is that ahead of schedule? Or are we still looking at a sort of mid-'17 type startup?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, well, there's 2 pieces of the cracker project. One is derivatives project, the polyethylene plants at Sweeny, and the second is the cracker at Baytown, which is just east of Houston. So the derivatives plant is -- those projects are still onlin
componenttext: Yes, Paul, well, there's 2 pieces of the cracker project. One is derivatives project, the polyethylene plants at Sweeny, and the second is the cracker at Baytown, which is just east of Houston. So the derivatives plant is -- those projects are still online. They come online actually before the second half of 2017 to be complete. The cracker is now looking like it's going to complete in the second half of '17, and that's really the change that we're seeing. Primarily related to productivity and the complexity of that project, we're seeing several months delay. So continued to progress on both of those very well, but the cracker is behind where we're seeing the derivatives project at this point.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, forgive me. I've somewhat lost the track. But I think originally, it was an end '17 startup overall, wasn't it? Or...
componenttext: Yes, forgive me. I've somewhat lost the track. But I think originally, it was an end '17 startup overall, wasn't it? Or...

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We were thinking probably startup, we were seeing mid-'17. And so like -- yes, we were. And so I think this, from an ethylene standpoint, pushes it out of the second half of the year, but the derivatives would be up earlier.
componenttext: We were thinking probably startup, we were seeing mid-'17. And so like -- yes, we were. And so I think this, from an ethylene standpoint, pushes it out of the second half of the year, but the derivatives would be up earlier.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And the costs that you implied, the costs are higher than you had anticipated?
componenttext: Understood. And the costs that you implied, the costs are higher than you had anticipated?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think they're generally in line. But with the delay, we'd expect maybe some increase in cost, but I think certainly well within the scope of what we're thinking. But I would anticipate that, that's higher than what we had thought when we hit that mid-'1
componenttext: I think they're generally in line. But with the delay, we'd expect maybe some increase in cost, but I think certainly well within the scope of what we're thinking. But I would anticipate that, that's higher than what we had thought when we hit that mid-'16 or '17.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And somewhat related just a macro question, which also relates to another business division. But what is your view of the NGL market here and the availability for those projects of cheap feedstocks? And the general -- if you could just update us on your g
componenttext: And somewhat related just a macro question, which also relates to another business division. But what is your view of the NGL market here and the availability for those projects of cheap feedstocks? And the general -- if you could just update us on your general view of what you're seeing in NGLs, that would be great.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. So on the NGL side, we had pretty strong response in the second quarter. Ethane started coming out of rejection, but we've actually seen kind of NGL prices begin to fall. And I think that the real key on this is, a, export demand and the pet ch
componenttext: Yes, okay. So on the NGL side, we had pretty strong response in the second quarter. Ethane started coming out of rejection, but we've actually seen kind of NGL prices begin to fall. And I think that the real key on this is, a, export demand and the pet chem demand in the industry. So we're still seeing supply, and we're still seeing ethane in rejection that's there to feed the new cracker startup. So until those crackers start up on the ethane side, we think that would be the main driver starting to pull more ethane out of the gas stream, which should strengthen the ethane price. On the propane side, we've had strong exports, and that's kept the propane market really connected to the international pricing in the international markets. We saw some short-term cancellations, I think, this summer as really the differentials between the U.S. and some other markets start to close. But we're starting to see corrections. And our view is that long term, you still have excess length in both ethane and propane and that propane has to lead the market to rebalance and clear. And so I think that what you see is you see the market start to readjust. And we're starting to see some of that now in the pricing this month in July. So I think we're still -- overall still see a lot of value in that LPG value chain and growing production as soon as crude oil production, gas production resumes out in the future.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing I'd add, Paul, just short term, we think it's going to be pressured here in the back half of the year, both crude and NGLs.
componenttext: Yes. The only thing I'd add, Paul, just short term, we think it's going to be pressured here in the back half of the year, both crude and NGLs.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Dietert from Simmons.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Dietert from Simmons.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Refining side, you've got a diverse portfolio across multiple regions and in different types of refineries. Could you talk about which regions, which types of refineries might be most impacted as far as refinery runs in a type of market environment
componenttext: On the Refining side, you've got a diverse portfolio across multiple regions and in different types of refineries. Could you talk about which regions, which types of refineries might be most impacted as far as refinery runs in a type of market environment that we are in now?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, it's Tim. I think fundamentally, simpler refineries that run on light sweet crudes are going to be the most impacted. Clearly, there's been a sustained differential on the heavy light side, the bias towards the heavy medium crudes as they're pr
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, it's Tim. I think fundamentally, simpler refineries that run on light sweet crudes are going to be the most impacted. Clearly, there's been a sustained differential on the heavy light side, the bias towards the heavy medium crudes as they're pretty available. So I think that as you think about the system, we expect the heavier-oriented refineries to be very competitive, and the real pinch point comes on the wider refineries around the globe, and then that depends a lot on their configuration as well. And clearly, as usual, we -- if you think around the world, the Atlantic Basin is going to be a pinch point and possibly some of the operations in Asia as we think about that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Secondly, Marketing and Specialty performance was stronger than we had anticipated. Could you talk a little bit about the strength in that segment? Maybe categorize some of the seasonal strength, some of the RINs influence and maybe just comment on what s
componenttext: Secondly, Marketing and Specialty performance was stronger than we had anticipated. Could you talk a little bit about the strength in that segment? Maybe categorize some of the seasonal strength, some of the RINs influence and maybe just comment on what some of the stronger aspects were in that segment.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it begins basically with good demand, right? I mean, you've got pull-through in terms of demand and response that we've seen globally by the consumer. Certainly, in the U.S. our volumes are up across some of the same-store sites roughly 2.5%. So we
componenttext: Well, it begins basically with good demand, right? I mean, you've got pull-through in terms of demand and response that we've seen globally by the consumer. Certainly, in the U.S. our volumes are up across some of the same-store sites roughly 2.5%. So we produced more. We actually moved into the market. So I think it reflects the strength on the demand side. And so we were able to capture a little better margin in terms of the value, if you will, of our distribution wholesale markets. So I think it speaks to strength there. The RINs are always interesting in terms of what's the impact in terms of the costs and the capture as it moves with the price, but I think that put a bias into the price of the product as well. And I think we're able to capture some of that. It certainly shows up as a cost in Refining, but it's a tailwind as well if you generate the RIN in marketing. But fundamentally, the spread, the wholesale margin was improved. And I think that really reflects, in our mind, the strength of the consumer gasoline market. Distillate remains rather flattish from our perspective.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned product exports, 174,000 barrels a day in a quarter, which is a strong quarter for exports. Maybe a quick comment on that, and I'll let you go.
componenttext: You mentioned product exports, 174,000 barrels a day in a quarter, which is a strong quarter for exports. Maybe a quick comment on that, and I'll let you go.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we did. We were able to bring up exports about 50,000 barrels a day, good opportunity. And so I think we just look at the decisions, the better inland placement on export sale. Clearly, the Gulf Coast for us is a big piece of that. And we're ve
componenttext: Yes. Well, we did. We were able to bring up exports about 50,000 barrels a day, good opportunity. And so I think we just look at the decisions, the better inland placement on export sale. Clearly, the Gulf Coast for us is a big piece of that. And we're very well positioned to supply the demand in Latin America as we've seen some reduction in the run rates down there. So it was a good market. And then you had the RIN value on top of that  that provides some incentives as well. So I think the export markets would likely stay strong for U.S. refiners on the Gulf Coast.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think this morning, it's amazing how much controversy this is causing this quarter. Greg, I wonder if I could ask first of all about the decision to defer the second cracker. Can you just frame for us a little bit, has that been driven by yourselves, yo
componenttext: I think this morning, it's amazing how much controversy this is causing this quarter. Greg, I wonder if I could ask first of all about the decision to defer the second cracker. Can you just frame for us a little bit, has that been driven by yourselves, your partners? What was the basis of the decision there? Maybe now that you don't have the associated capital, what do you expect the free cash flow swing to be on CPChem next year?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me just clarify your point. We've -- it was the Frac 2 we've deferred, not the second cracker, although we can certainly talk about the second cracker. [indiscernible] on the second cracker today too. And there -- And Tim, if you want to talk about
componenttext: So let me just clarify your point. We've -- it was the Frac 2 we've deferred, not the second cracker, although we can certainly talk about the second cracker. [indiscernible] on the second cracker today too. And there -- And Tim, if you want to talk about the cracker, go ahead.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the cracker...
componenttext: Yes, on the cracker...

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's what I was referring to, yes.
componenttext: Yes, that's what I was referring to, yes.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We actually continue to do engineering work, do site studies. Still like North America when we think about the long-term supply, we look around the world for that. But I don't see FID on that cracker until sometime 2018, 2019 just as we do the develo
componenttext: Yes. We actually continue to do engineering work, do site studies. Still like North America when we think about the long-term supply, we look around the world for that. But I don't see FID on that cracker until sometime 2018, 2019 just as we do the development work and look at things. So into the second part of your question, so next year, capital spending at CPChem will decline with the completion of the Gulf -- the first cracker so that may be in the order of $1 billion a year on that. And then in '18, as you ramp up the production on the new cracker, you'll likely see at the CPChem level, this is both of those numbers, another $800 million to $1 billion with some upside depending on how the market is. So substantial cash flow swing at CPChem if you think about free cash flow. And so we're anticipating that we'll get strong distributions back from CPChem here beginning particularly in 2018.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color. Apologies for my confusion. I guess, what I was thinking was that when you talk about the swing as opposed to dividend, I always assumed that the capital in 20 -- for the second project would be  -- would start in 2017. I didn't re
componenttext: I appreciate the color. Apologies for my confusion. I guess, what I was thinking was that when you talk about the swing as opposed to dividend, I always assumed that the capital in 20 -- for the second project would be  -- would start in 2017. I didn't realize the timing. So could you -- $1 billion that you're talking about, is that a gross number at CPChem level?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's the change kind of roughly just from the cracker impacts.
componenttext: Yes. That's the change kind of roughly just from the cracker impacts.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up, if I may, is really going back to the capital question broadly. It seems you're maintaining the return of capital to shareholders, whereas the capital seems to be taking the flex on the environment. I'm just wondering, is that the right inte
componenttext: My follow-up, if I may, is really going back to the capital question broadly. It seems you're maintaining the return of capital to shareholders, whereas the capital seems to be taking the flex on the environment. I'm just wondering, is that the right interpretation going forward? In other words, how do you see your buyback strategy as it relates to your proceeds from future PSXP equity sales and drop-down and so on? Is that something we should be expecting to be ratable? Or is there some...

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me kind of dissect that and talk about them both. I think that we've said in terms of the capital spend at PSX, we've always been on a glide slope towards $3 billion. There's no question, our capital in the last 2 years has been very high as w
componenttext: Yes. So let me kind of dissect that and talk about them both. I think that we've said in terms of the capital spend at PSX, we've always been on a glide slope towards $3 billion. There's no question, our capital in the last 2 years has been very high as we've tried to advance the Midstream business and get PSXP to scale quickly. So that was a decision we took really kind of into '12 coming into '13. When we think about share repurchase, we think about intrinsic value. And as long as the shares are trading below intrinsic value, we're going to be in the market buying. So we're in the market every day buying. Some days, we buy more more than others, that's true. And I'd say, consistent with our guidance that we've been giving in 2016, we're going to be between $1 billion and $2 billion of share repurchases this year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that how we look you can get to 2017?
componenttext: Is that how we look you can get to 2017?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given out outlook on that, but I would say we'll probably within that same range in terms of share repurchase for 2017.
componenttext: We haven't given out outlook on that, but I would say we'll probably within that same range in terms of share repurchase for 2017.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First small one, just in the quarter, the cash flow ex working capital was weak. What would be the 3 things aside from, I guess, Refining margins that you'd point to?
componenttext: First small one, just in the quarter, the cash flow ex working capital was weak. What would be the 3 things aside from, I guess, Refining margins that you'd point to?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed, this is Kevin. So bear in mind that the almost $350 million of undistributed equity earnings, so that gets reflected in the earnings number, but the distributions aren't coming back. The bulk of that is in CPChem, but you also see it with WRB, JV
componenttext: Yes, Ed, this is Kevin. So bear in mind that the almost $350 million of undistributed equity earnings, so that gets reflected in the earnings number, but the distributions aren't coming back. The bulk of that is in CPChem, but you also see it with WRB, JV, Excel Paralubes and then the several other smaller JVs. Some of those, it's reflected of the investment that's taking place inside of those JVs that's consuming that cash. Some of it, a portion is just the timing effect. The distributions aren't necessarily ratable. So when you think about the $560  million of cash flow excluding working capital, if you were to add back the undistributed equity earnings to put it on sort of a consistent basis, that's just over $900 million of operating cash flow, which then lines up with the -- what you'd expect from the earnings generated, given the environment.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I do want to touch on NGL Frac 2. So is that just a function of matching upstream customer plans? I mean, is it because cash flow in the short term is a little bit weak because of refining? Or is it because there's maybe better things to do
componenttext: Okay. And then I do want to touch on NGL Frac 2. So is that just a function of matching upstream customer plans? I mean, is it because cash flow in the short term is a little bit weak because of refining? Or is it because there's maybe better things to do out in the broader MLP space, given you've got PSXP and also year-end balance sheet that you could use?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I think -- I mean, we've always consistently said we never build a speculative frac. And I think our view is that NGLs will continue to grow, but they're going to grow slower than what we saw 2 years ago. And so I think that's a decision to push the
componenttext: Well I think -- I mean, we've always consistently said we never build a speculative frac. And I think our view is that NGLs will continue to grow, but they're going to grow slower than what we saw 2 years ago. And so I think that's a decision to push the FID on Frac 2 simply reflects that, Ed.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, okay. And then a broader then on the second part of that around the opportunity set to look at inorganic growth across the portfolio in the MLP lens.
componenttext: Right, okay. And then a broader then on the second part of that around the opportunity set to look at inorganic growth across the portfolio in the MLP lens.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that -- I mean, that's always something we look at every day in terms of the inorganic growth. The other thing I would say is we think we still have a pretty good backlog of organic projects that we can vest in around our own infrastructure,
componenttext: Yes, I think that -- I mean, that's always something we look at every day in terms of the inorganic growth. The other thing I would say is we think we still have a pretty good backlog of organic projects that we can vest in around our own infrastructure, whether it's more terminals, butane blending, ethanol blending, more pipes. So I think that just around the portfolio, we still have a really good backlog of investable opportunities for the MLP, there's no question. When you think about the long-haul third party where there are crude pipes or NGL pipes or fracs, I think those opportunities are probably diminished versus what we thought 2 years ago.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ed, just to comment, we purchased additional small interest in Explorer pipeline is one of the opportunities we look at is the inorganic. But at the pipeline we've been with PSXP today, but predecessor to the PSXP Phillips, we've been investors in tha
componenttext: And Ed, just to comment, we purchased additional small interest in Explorer pipeline is one of the opportunities we look at is the inorganic. But at the pipeline we've been with PSXP today, but predecessor to the PSXP Phillips, we've been investors in that pipe for a long time. So it fits strategically, but I think those are kinds of inorganic bolt-ons, if you look at, that say that can add value and they fit strategically with the overall footprint at PSX and PSXP.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Roger Read from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Roger Read from Wells Fargo.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, kind of coming back to some of the cash flow questions, obviously PSXP is a significant contributor year-to-date and we expect so going forward. Any way to think about what the contributions from that to the overall PSX cash flow statement should
componenttext: I guess, kind of coming back to some of the cash flow questions, obviously PSXP is a significant contributor year-to-date and we expect so going forward. Any way to think about what the contributions from that to the overall PSX cash flow statement should be as we look out through '17?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Roger, it's Tim. So if you look back in history and you think about our spend, we anticipate about $2 billion a year of funding or purchases, if you will, at PSXP. To the extent that those are PSX projects, it's what we do. But I think that's kind of
componenttext: Yes, Roger, it's Tim. So if you look back in history and you think about our spend, we anticipate about $2 billion a year of funding or purchases, if you will, at PSXP. To the extent that those are PSX projects, it's what we do. But I think that's kind of -- to meet our target on distribution growth in our plan to hit the $1.1 billion of PSXP, you're kind of roughly in the that $2 billion a year range of purchases. So that will be a source that equity and debt financing that will finance that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so I'm just trying to think from a modeling standpoint, we could essentially assume a majority of that being available to PSX, but probably not wise to consider 100% of it.
componenttext: Okay. And so I'm just trying to think from a modeling standpoint, we could essentially assume a majority of that being available to PSX, but probably not wise to consider 100% of it.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the majority of -- we have a large backlog of organic that we're developing that would fit logically in the MLP. So that's been the strong connection so far with smaller bolt-on outside inorganic. But yes, so the majority of that I think you
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the majority of -- we have a large backlog of organic that we're developing that would fit logically in the MLP. So that's been the strong connection so far with smaller bolt-on outside inorganic. But yes, so the majority of that I think you can think about as PSX, and -- but we're always looking at opportunities to add to the value through outside opportunities as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great.
componenttext: Okay, great.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're -- Roger, the run rate EBITDA of about, what, $400 million at PSXP today. We feel really good by end of 2018 being at run rate EBITDA of $1.1 billion. We see a clear path to get there and don't see an issue at all in getting there.
componenttext: We're -- Roger, the run rate EBITDA of about, what, $400 million at PSXP today. We feel really good by end of 2018 being at run rate EBITDA of $1.1 billion. We see a clear path to get there and don't see an issue at all in getting there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then my other question, and this kind of ties back into the run cut question and the guidance of the mid-90s. And then just the second quarter kind of undershooting on the expected, I guess, call it -- it's called maintenance expense or the t
componenttext: Perfect. And then my other question, and this kind of ties back into the run cut question and the guidance of the mid-90s. And then just the second quarter kind of undershooting on the expected, I guess, call it -- it's called maintenance expense or the turnaround expense, what specifically on the maintenance side was deferred? And since the guidance makes it sound like it's a pretty modest amount of spending in Q3, I'm assuming deferred out of Q3. I was under the impression a lot of this is not something you can defer. So I was just sort of curious what changed in the operations on the Refining side? And maybe do we have to think about '17 as a higher turnaround year?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basically, our major maintenance turnaround is still on schedule we planned. These are relatively small unit turnarounds that just we're able to defer. So they just move around sometimes on planning basis. But the fundamentals way that we go about the
componenttext: So basically, our major maintenance turnaround is still on schedule we planned. These are relatively small unit turnarounds that just we're able to defer. So they just move around sometimes on planning basis. But the fundamentals way that we go about the major turnaround planning is unchanged. So I think our guidance, where we typically get to a turnaround expense is pretty consistent year-on-year, flexes a little bit depending on which refinery, but we really haven't changed our philosophy on turnaround expenditures and timing of those.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to circle back on some of the CapEx conversations from earlier in the call. Greg, respecting that you said you'll give more detail later this summer, I think, but I'm curious why the CapEx is coming in so low. Obviously, you cited the Frac 2 defe
componenttext: I wanted to circle back on some of the CapEx conversations from earlier in the call. Greg, respecting that you said you'll give more detail later this summer, I think, but I'm curious why the CapEx is coming in so low. Obviously, you cited the Frac 2 deferral, but I wouldn't think that there was any CapEx in the budget for that. And it sounds like the major projects are on budget. So what exactly is it that's leading to the lower numbers?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's several projects in Midstream be on Frac 2 that we're looking at. I also mentioned the project financing of DAPL ETCOP. And so yes, that's going to be a very classic type project finance. And so our share of that would be somewhere around $600
componenttext: Well, it's several projects in Midstream be on Frac 2 that we're looking at. I also mentioned the project financing of DAPL ETCOP. And so yes, that's going to be a very classic type project finance. And so our share of that would be somewhere around $600 million-ish, I would say. Probably most of it will be in '16, maybe a little bit spill over in '17. But you just kind of sum all that up, and that's really how you get to a $3.3 billion level. And frankly, we're still working the numbers. And I suspect it's going to come in below $3.3 billion when we give you guidance in a couple of months.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about the dynamics in the Atlantic Basin on the Refining side right now. Obviously, the orb has been opened, but it seems like products going over a bit in the tanks on the East Coast, so
componenttext: Okay. And then I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about the dynamics in the Atlantic Basin on the Refining side right now. Obviously, the orb has been opened, but it seems like products going over a bit in the tanks on the East Coast, so something seems to have to give on the Refining utilization side. And since you guys see both sides of the market there, how do you see that playing out?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're right. We've had a lot of build of inventory in pad 1 in New York Harbor. There's been an incentive on Europe to continue to run. I think that reflects storage economics right now. But that is a place that reached a rebalance of somewhere betw
componenttext: Yes, you're right. We've had a lot of build of inventory in pad 1 in New York Harbor. There's been an incentive on Europe to continue to run. I think that reflects storage economics right now. But that is a place that reached a rebalance of somewhere between the U.S. East Coast and some of the European refineries. We still look at that. There needs to be some balancing on the inventory side where the production side to balance that out. And that typically tends to be a more marginal or higher cost area is another reason we think about that. So a lot of dynamics in play around that, and we'll have to see how it shakes out. But no matter how you cut it someplace, you've got to get the production and demand back in balance a bit more on the Refining side. So that's why we anticipate that run cuts come, and that would seem to be one place that we look at to think that could occur.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then quickly kind of related, is there any update -- or sorry, update on Whitegate? Is that still in the sale process?
componenttext: And then quickly kind of related, is there any update -- or sorry, update on Whitegate? Is that still in the sale process?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say we're still in process on Whitegate. I think I would tell you we're pleased with the progress at this point. And hopefully, as I said I think in the last quarter, our intention is we get this closed this year.
componenttext: So I would say we're still in process on Whitegate. I think I would tell you we're pleased with the progress at this point. And hopefully, as I said I think in the last quarter, our intention is we get this closed this year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one -- a follow-up question regarding some of the PSX and PSXP strategy. I guess, just curious as to whether organic cash flow business at the base business, if you were to continue to see [indiscernible] refining at the Midstream and so on thr
componenttext: Maybe just one -- a follow-up question regarding some of the PSX and PSXP strategy. I guess, just curious as to whether organic cash flow business at the base business, if you were to continue to see [indiscernible] refining at the Midstream and so on through 3Q and 4Q, does the level of organic cash flow accelerate or change the pace at all if PSXP drops in terms of how you see the timing play out in '16?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think again, we look at PSXP, we talk about our $1.1 billion target. You've got to continue to progress to make the distribution coverage. So we have a strong backlog of MLP-able income available. And so we're going to continue to grow that, hit our
componenttext: No, I think again, we look at PSXP, we talk about our $1.1 billion target. You've got to continue to progress to make the distribution coverage. So we have a strong backlog of MLP-able income available. And so we're going to continue to grow that, hit our target through in 2018. So we're continuing to see good Midstream cash flows in our fee-based assets, and that's a key component of what we want PSXP to do.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just one on M&A. In your strategic update portion of the note, you hinted that you're evaluating all parts of your portfolio, something I hadn't seen in prior releases. Is there -- can you -- I guess, can you expand anymore on that, t
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just one on M&A. In your strategic update portion of the note, you hinted that you're evaluating all parts of your portfolio, something I hadn't seen in prior releases. Is there -- can you -- I guess, can you expand anymore on that, things that you're looking at in the portfolio? Would you be considering selling anything within the portfolio? And if so, is there anything you can comment in terms of noncore things that might potentially be on the table?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that my comments really were around the capital budget and the projects that we have on deck in ensuring that any project we do meets our hurdle rate expectations. In terms of the overall portfolio, of course, we have the process on Whitegate
componenttext: Yes, I think that my comments really were around the capital budget and the projects that we have on deck in ensuring that any project we do meets our hurdle rate expectations. In terms of the overall portfolio, of course, we have the process on Whitegate we just talked about. But I think as we come to the end of the Whitegate process, I don't think there's a lot more in the portfolio that we have on deck certainly for '16 or thinking about into '17. In terms of potential M&A, I mean, we look at it every day. I would say that price is still relatively high to us relative to the organic opportunities we may have in front of us, but we would look at that. And if we can find assets for the right value, we're certainly willing to do that. I think that the Explorer one was a good example, but that wasn't at the PSXP level. And I think in terms of the Midstream, you'll see us doing more and more activity at the PSXP level.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Faisel Khan from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Faisel Khan from Citigroup.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I guess, I want to go back to your prepared comments around the Freeport export facility. I think that is beginning the commissioning phase right now. And I -- if I remember right, I think the contracted volumes were, I think, 6 cargoes a month. I j
componenttext: Greg, I guess, I want to go back to your prepared comments around the Freeport export facility. I think that is beginning the commissioning phase right now. And I -- if I remember right, I think the contracted volumes were, I think, 6 cargoes a month. I just want to make sure I understood some of your commentary around that, since you're talking about a lower number in the commissioning phase.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're about 97% complete on the LPG terminal. There's different pieces. So we're actually right at the front end of our commissioning and drawing out process, getting it ready. So we anticipate that we'll be operational toward the end of the year.
componenttext: Yes. So we're about 97% complete on the LPG terminal. There's different pieces. So we're actually right at the front end of our commissioning and drawing out process, getting it ready. So we anticipate that we'll be operational toward the end of the year. But we are actually essentially completing construction and now working into the commissioning piece of that business. So that's about to become operational. On the market side, yes, about the contracts, we continue to work the contracts. Greg said that commodity environment is challenged today. So I think that the commercial arm or opportunity is narrower than what we had originally planned in the short term, but we still fundamentally see that strength. And as I said, it's got to clear the market here somewhere to really make everything balance just based on the demand side. So we feel pretty good about the longer-term fundamentals there with some stress short term, I think, on the commercial side of that. But the load across that looks really solid to us, and we continue to work that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And do the contracts support the ramp that you guys talked about, up to $300 million to $400 million in EBITDA? I just want to make sure that the current situation in the market doesn't impact how we model those cash flows ramping up into the first
componenttext: Okay. And do the contracts support the ramp that you guys talked about, up to $300 million to $400 million in EBITDA? I just want to make sure that the current situation in the market doesn't impact how we model those cash flows ramping up into the first half next year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've said that the EBITDA on that project, $400 million to $500 million, 20% or so would be commercial opportunities. And so the ramp-up schedule really relates more to the fee. And I think that what we're seeing is that opportunities for that are goi
componenttext: So we've said that the EBITDA on that project, $400 million to $500 million, 20% or so would be commercial opportunities. And so the ramp-up schedule really relates more to the fee. And I think that what we're seeing is that opportunities for that are going to be a bit lower. But in the commercial arm, we're seeing most of the compression in terms of that run rate. But we're ready to ramp up when that thing becomes operational as these contracts start to kick in and we're -- and we get the asset in play. But that takes a bit of time as you bring up the operation.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the Marketing and Specialties side, obviously that business continues to remain strong and generate high returns on capital. It looks like you're investing a little bit more capital in that business if I'm looking at some of the commenta
componenttext: Okay. And just on the Marketing and Specialties side, obviously that business continues to remain strong and generate high returns on capital. It looks like you're investing a little bit more capital in that business if I'm looking at some of the commentary correctly, so the upgrading of sites, buying more additional sites in Europe. And I'm just wondering if you could comment about whether you are sort of increasing the amount of capital into that business with sort of the addition of sites and sort of improvement of branded sites across your network.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Faisel, most of that capital, the capital investment in sites is in Europe. We have a great market position, good return. But it's going to be modest, just given the size of the market and the rate at which it's growing. So it's really, I think, a leve
componenttext: So Faisel, most of that capital, the capital investment in sites is in Europe. We have a great market position, good return. But it's going to be modest, just given the size of the market and the rate at which it's growing. So it's really, I think, a level that we see continuing to go forward. On the U.S. side, a little bit of capital on the marketing site for that, but most of this is done through our dealers and our marketers, our customers. And so it's part of our marketing structure. But making good progress in terms of revamping the sites, particularly on the 76 and the Phillips 66 brand, and we're seeing increased pull-through to the branded chain. So we're strengthening that really through our marketing and commercial relationships versus a capital investment piece that we are driving.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last question from me. You guys talked about sort of the headwind from secondary products pricing during the quarter. Is most of that now resolved, now that crude has flattened out and come off a bit? I just want to make sure I understand sort o
componenttext: Okay. And last question from me. You guys talked about sort of the headwind from secondary products pricing during the quarter. Is most of that now resolved, now that crude has flattened out and come off a bit? I just want to make sure I understand sort of that headwind is still continuing into the third quarter? Or has it completely been sort of resolved?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Crude ran up quite a bit in the second quarter. And so as it comes off, the margin between, say, a coke and the crude, that differential widens back out. That said, some of the other products are LPGs. And to the extent that NGL prices -- I mean, pro
componenttext: Yes. Crude ran up quite a bit in the second quarter. And so as it comes off, the margin between, say, a coke and the crude, that differential widens back out. That said, some of the other products are LPGs. And to the extent that NGL prices -- I mean, propane price has come down significantly here recently. And so as you see that, it's kind of a moving target. But generally, we do better with lower crude prices in terms of the secondary product loss, if you will, that narrows, and it's basically a boost or a tailwind for our margins.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, for the -- is there a number that you can share on the fractionator 1 that seems to come onstream late last year? What's the contribution in the second quarter? And also, when the LPG export terminal are up and running, should we assume that
componenttext: Just curious, for the -- is there a number that you can share on the fractionator 1 that seems to come onstream late last year? What's the contribution in the second quarter? And also, when the LPG export terminal are up and running, should we assume that the entire Sweeny NGL hub is going to report on the NGL business or that the LPG terminal is going to be in the transportation segment?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It shall be in NGL. Let me take a -- maybe a 30,000-foot view on this question, if I can, and then Tim can come in behind me and give you some of the details. So I know you have a concern around this, and we understand that. If I can just go to the 30,000
componenttext: It shall be in NGL. Let me take a -- maybe a 30,000-foot view on this question, if I can, and then Tim can come in behind me and give you some of the details. So I know you have a concern around this, and we understand that. If I can just go to the 30,000-foot level and just talk about the Sweeny hub in general, we still think that, that's a great project and we see value creation opportunity there. If you think about NGL pipes coming out of the Permian, West Texas and the Eagle Ford and going by Sweeny, you think about world-class refining, world-class petrochemicals, we have the largest single site ethylene facility at Sweeny. We have -- we're building 1.2 million tons of polyethylene capacity, building the fractionator. We're building the caverns. We're building the interconnecting pipes to Belvieu and on to Freeport and then the 150,000 barrel a day LPG export facility. So we still like that concept and what we're creating there. I think short term, what you're seeing in the market, there's going to be stress in the LPG side of it. The frac is running well. It's running to design limits. We're seeing certainly heavier feed than what we premised. And so we're running about 80 a day at the frac today versus 100%, but it's completely loaded in the back end of the frac. The other thing I would say is, as this project is coming up, we have a lot of project expenses that are hitting us beyond just the frac. So think about the pipes and the caverns and the commissioning, the startup of the LPG export facility. So you should expect to see those costs continue through the end of 2016. But we talk about the frac itself, we drop it, all of it. It's at PSXP today. The [indiscernible] about $100 million, so $25 million a quarter. There's a little bit of leakage that goes to the noncontrolling interest. But then -- so then you take that and bring it to the net income level. And that was more than offset by the project expenses we had and the seasonal trading activities that we had in our NGL business. So I think that -- but we're not worried about this whole NGL complex that we're building at Sweeny in terms of it coming up. And we're looking forward to getting the LPG export up later this year. We'll start commissioning activities actually in the next couple of weeks as we start thinking about that. And so I just want to say that we still really like this project a lot. And Tim, if you want to fill anything I missed, you're welcome to do that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it really is about the total. And Paul, so you know, it's a PSXP asset today. Greg said we're down a little bit with the ethane. As the ethane comes out of rejection, that comes up naturally. It also starts through a little more of the pipe an
componenttext: No, I think it really is about the total. And Paul, so you know, it's a PSXP asset today. Greg said we're down a little bit with the ethane. As the ethane comes out of rejection, that comes up naturally. It also starts through a little more of the pipe and the caverns are there. So a relatively small contribution, but it's up and it's running a lot better. We had great operational improvement this second quarter. And so that's what we're focused on. And then we've got to get this LPG up and get the entire value chain going on, on that one.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, do you have a number you can share what is the RIN cost and [indiscernible] we sell for the Refining segment? And what is the RIN benefit that [indiscernible] in the marketing segment in the second quarter?
componenttext: Kevin, do you have a number you can share what is the RIN cost and [indiscernible] we sell for the Refining segment? And what is the RIN benefit that [indiscernible] in the marketing segment in the second quarter?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: My first question is you talked about the $400 million of income at PSXP going to $1.1 billion. I just want to clarify is that all, I guess, project-related EBITDA? Or is some of that drops -- I guess, what I mean is I'm just trying to understand how much Midstream EBITDA growth you're expecting from '16 to '17, given that you have a lot of onetime costs that you're incurring this year to ramp the projects?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the $1.1 billion is a target of both existing assets when we began as well as our growth projects. As we think about the compositions -- so exactly what we drop, when is something that we always look at. So it's going to be a combination of both of tho
componenttext: So the $1.1 billion is a target of both existing assets when we began as well as our growth projects. As we think about the compositions -- so exactly what we drop, when is something that we always look at. So it's going to be a combination of both of those. But as you look at the Midstream EBITDA, we put out in 2018, we grow from around $1 billion, say, in Refining and Midstream income when we started in '13, '14, pushing that up over $2 billion. So that's really the growth that's there. Some of that's commodity as well. So there's some -- depending on the commodity markets, it could be something about 20%. And that's really how we think about it is that look through EBITDA, you've got $1 billion-plus of EBITDA growth over that period. But what you put into PSXP is a mixed question that we really don't address specifically.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: So at the end of '17, you put the Sweeny hub, you've got the DAPL ETCOP, you've got Bayou Bridge coming on. So you're pushing up well over probably $500 million of incremental EBITDA in the Midstream, both a combination of PSXP as well as PSX.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. My second question is just for Kevin on the balance sheet. In the past, we've talked about whether your consolidated balance sheet or ex-PSXP, generally curious how you're thinking about that today? And then with this macro environment we're seeing in the back half that could be potentially worse than the first half on free cash flow, general willingness to use the balance sheet in an interim period to continue buybacks, noting that 2Q buybacks were the lowest we've seen in a couple of years?

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, the -- so debt-to-cap, 27% fully consolidated at the end of the second quarter; on a net basis, 22%. And when you exclude PSXP, I think it's 25% total, 19% on a net cash basis. So still a fair amount of headroom from a balance sheet standpoint, ba
componenttext: So yes, the -- so debt-to-cap, 27% fully consolidated at the end of the second quarter; on a net basis, 22%. And when you exclude PSXP, I think it's 25% total, 19% on a net cash basis. So still a fair amount of headroom from a balance sheet standpoint, balance sheet capacity to weather the ups and downs in the market. Most of the capital programming -- Greg talked about $3.9 billion capital budget coming to something $3.3-ish billion for the year. But a lot of the capital is locked in. And so that's where having the balance sheet capability to deal with that over that time period certainly helps us. The MLP model is a critical part of the overall funding. So as we continue to grow the MLP drop-down assets, you'll see cash coming back to the PSX level, and it's going to be in the form of, you'll see, equity raises like we did in the second quarter, and you'll see debt going on in the MLP.

headline: Phillips 66, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one thing, Phil, that I would add to that. We're kind of on a glide slope to $3 billion. And so think about kind of $1 billion-ish of sustaining capital and $2 billion of growth, both of that growth is really directed towards Midstream. And we fully
componenttext: Just one thing, Phil, that I would add to that. We're kind of on a glide slope to $3 billion. And so think about kind of $1 billion-ish of sustaining capital and $2 billion of growth, both of that growth is really directed towards Midstream. And we fully expect that we can fund that coming out of the MLP.
