componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, they're still fairly reasonable. I think, the returns are going to be just a little lower. But as we went back and [indiscernible] these projects, we would still make these investments in Refining.
componenttext: Yes, I think, they're still fairly reasonable. I think, the returns are going to be just a little lower. But as we went back and [indiscernible] these projects, we would still make these investments in Refining.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Dietert from Simmons.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Dietert from Simmons.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would like to ask a question on the Freeport LNG terminal. Obviously, LNG -- or LPG exports have been rising in the U.S. broadly. And you're coming on with inventories relatively high and opportunity to export. Could you talk about what you're seeing de
componenttext: I would like to ask a question on the Freeport LNG terminal. Obviously, LNG -- or LPG exports have been rising in the U.S. broadly. And you're coming on with inventories relatively high and opportunity to export. Could you talk about what you're seeing demand-wise? What the arbitrage looks like in exporting LPGs and kind of how that's evolved this year?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, it's Tim. I'd say that from a demand standpoint, still strong when you look at the numbers on the export side because the link in the U.S. for particularly propane coming out of the U.S. to international markets. So propane dehydro plants, for
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, it's Tim. I'd say that from a demand standpoint, still strong when you look at the numbers on the export side because the link in the U.S. for particularly propane coming out of the U.S. to international markets. So propane dehydro plants, for instance, require propane feedstock in Asia, the heating markets. But the challenge has been as energy prices have -- the dips have narrowed really around the world, the arbs on those have come in substantially. So in the short term, I think, we still see good demand. I feel good about that. But we look at it and say, the commercial side, the arb between the U.S. netback price and the destination price in Europe and Asia is lower than what we would expect long term. So I think, when we start up, we would expect to see that. That said, we're still seeing good underlying demand for the cargoes in the terminal.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And seeing new construction of new facilities, are they going to increase LPG demand in Asia in the years ahead as well?
componenttext: And seeing new construction of new facilities, are they going to increase LPG demand in Asia in the years ahead as well?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there's infrastructure, there's European interest, Latin American as well. And the other thing that is out there, of course, is the flexibility of crackers to run more LPG in place of naphtha on top of new petrochemical projects, for instance
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there's infrastructure, there's European interest, Latin American as well. And the other thing that is out there, of course, is the flexibility of crackers to run more LPG in place of naphtha on top of new petrochemical projects, for instance, that the propane dehydro that are very specific to propane. And then, there's the continuing growth in the thermal market, the heating market for that as well.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug Leggate from Bank of America is online with a question.
componenttext: Doug Leggate from Bank of America is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wonder if I could take 2 quick ones. First of all, it looks like your NGL business, DCP quarter looks like it's started to improve a little bit. I don't know if that's macro on the higher oil price, if you now feel as if you've got other things st
componenttext: Greg, I wonder if I could take 2 quick ones. First of all, it looks like your NGL business, DCP quarter looks like it's started to improve a little bit. I don't know if that's macro on the higher oil price, if you now feel as if you've got other things stabilized and turning in the right direction. I just wondered if you could characterize whether you now think this has now bottomed out?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Happy to do that. A couple of things, Doug. First of all, I think that the work the DCP has done to reduce our cost structure to cash breakeven, they dropped it from kind of $0.60 per gallon NGL to somewhere below $0.35 a gallon NGL. So you're seeing that
componenttext: Happy to do that. A couple of things, Doug. First of all, I think that the work the DCP has done to reduce our cost structure to cash breakeven, they dropped it from kind of $0.60 per gallon NGL to somewhere below $0.35 a gallon NGL. So you're seeing that benefit show up. NGL prices quarter-on-quarter actually just a little bit lower, but natural gas prices were up about $0.80 or so, $0.89, I think. And so that was a benefit to DCC. So you had a combination effect of lower costs plus good throughput volumes and then kind of neutral on NGL prices, a little better on gas prices.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add maybe to that is that there has also been progress, continued progress converting some of the commodity-based contracts to fee-based. And that's helped that a bit as well. So it's really the 3 points that Greg talked about that
componenttext: The other thing I would add maybe to that is that there has also been progress, continued progress converting some of the commodity-based contracts to fee-based. And that's helped that a bit as well. So it's really the 3 points that Greg talked about that helped drive that improvement.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a bit more of a housekeeping issue. I guess, more topical issue given one of your competitors the other day is how you feel about your embedded GP value, Greg? I know we talked about this periodically. But the yield on your MLP is obviously much more
componenttext: Just a bit more of a housekeeping issue. I guess, more topical issue given one of your competitors the other day is how you feel about your embedded GP value, Greg? I know we talked about this periodically. But the yield on your MLP is obviously much more constructive perhaps. I'm just curious, do you have any similar feelings around the market under-recognizing the value of your Midstream business, and particularly any steps you might think about taking to improve the output be it GP monetization, or IPO, whatever? Just general thoughts around what you thought of [indiscernible] you're thinking about going forward.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, I would say, I think, our view continues to be by delivering steady fee-based growth. We can maximize the value of the LP. And frankly, we think the GP is going to be recognized in that. Specifically the question to the GP, we don't have any immedia
componenttext: Doug, I would say, I think, our view continues to be by delivering steady fee-based growth. We can maximize the value of the LP. And frankly, we think the GP is going to be recognized in that. Specifically the question to the GP, we don't have any immediate plans to do anything with the GP. We look at it all the time, and we're certainly considering options to create value. I think that we know and we kind of understand the life cycle of MLPs. And I think, the tool in your tool kit, being able to adjust the GPs to get the optimal capital structure to continue to grow the MLP is very important and it shouldn't be overlooked in that decision process.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You don't feel you're anywhere close to that yet?
componenttext: You don't feel you're anywhere close to that yet?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we have any immediate plans to IPO the GP, if that's the question. It's 100 million [indiscernible] it's relatively small at this point in time.
componenttext: I don't think we have any immediate plans to IPO the GP, if that's the question. It's 100 million [indiscernible] it's relatively small at this point in time.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, what I was really getting at is you've probably got a lot of growth ahead of you in the GP before it becomes a burden on the MLP. So when I said you're not close to that yet, is that fair characterization of it? [indiscernible]
componenttext: Yes, I guess, what I was really getting at is you've probably got a lot of growth ahead of you in the GP before it becomes a burden on the MLP. So when I said you're not close to that yet, is that fair characterization of it? [indiscernible]

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. We think about that a lot and the cost of capital at the MLP. I mean, the IDRs do at some point become a cost of capital burden for the MLP.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. We think about that a lot and the cost of capital at the MLP. I mean, the IDRs do at some point become a cost of capital burden for the MLP.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul Sankey from Wolfe is online with a question.
componenttext: Paul Sankey from Wolfe is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could directly follow up on that, we've seen a strategy shift from Marathon Petroleum, I'm sure you're aware of in terms of accelerating drop-downs. Can you talk about the parameters you have to potentially accelerate what you do in terms of drop-dow
componenttext: If I could directly follow up on that, we've seen a strategy shift from Marathon Petroleum, I'm sure you're aware of in terms of accelerating drop-downs. Can you talk about the parameters you have to potentially accelerate what you do in terms of drop-downs and remind us what your long-term current plans are in terms of guidance for that trade, should we call it?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first of all, we're not going to be on 2018 today in terms of guidance, Paul. And so, I think, we're committed to the $1.1 billion in 2018, that'll represent a 30% CAGR in terms of that. I don't know, Tim, if you've got any other comments aroun
componenttext: Yes. Well, first of all, we're not going to be on 2018 today in terms of guidance, Paul. And so, I think, we're committed to the $1.1 billion in 2018, that'll represent a 30% CAGR in terms of that. I don't know, Tim, if you've got any other comments around that you want to make?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that we see value in continuing that. We continue to invest in the midstream, so I think there's a growth dimension to that. So our view is that we continue to develop the pipeline of projects, grow that business, get the good value from the M
componenttext: No, I think that we see value in continuing that. We continue to invest in the midstream, so I think there's a growth dimension to that. So our view is that we continue to develop the pipeline of projects, grow that business, get the good value from the MLP and the whole midstream business, Paul. So it's really that commitment to getting that size and then just looking beyond that is to continue to grow.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, we have to say that if you've got a 30% CAGR, it's probably pretty healthy basically, to say the least. If I could totally change subjects, Greg, we've seen in the upstream side across the board, costs have fallen dramatically in every aspec
componenttext: Yes, I guess, we have to say that if you've got a 30% CAGR, it's probably pretty healthy basically, to say the least. If I could totally change subjects, Greg, we've seen in the upstream side across the board, costs have fallen dramatically in every aspect of the industry. Your chemical project, which I think you said is 85% complete, has actually come in somewhat over budget, somewhat delayed. We thought about this years ago in terms of controlling the costs. Could you just remind us or update us on how it is that in this cost environment, we still have seen upside costs in the downstream?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, there's quite a bit of downstream activity still going on, Paul. Just to kind of point that out, there's a lot of construction, a lot of crackers under construction. So I think our polyethylene facility will come on kind of within expectations
componenttext: Yes, well, there's quite a bit of downstream activity still going on, Paul. Just to kind of point that out, there's a lot of construction, a lot of crackers under construction. So I think our polyethylene facility will come on kind of within expectations in terms of both the timing and the costs of the facility. We've signaled that we think the cracker is going to be in the second half of the year. And so the cost of cracker probably will be 5% to 10% more than what we would have expected just due to the delays that we're seeing in construction. I would tell you that Tim's working that really hard. And I don't know if you want to make a couple of comments on what we're seeing on the ground today and some of the things that we're doing to try to mitigate that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. And I think about it as really not been equipment and engineering particularly. It's really been on the construction side and productivity. So the labor input to get the work done has gone up as we've seen less skilled craft. Each contractor ha
componenttext: Yes, Paul. And I think about it as really not been equipment and engineering particularly. It's really been on the construction side and productivity. So the labor input to get the work done has gone up as we've seen less skilled craft. Each contractor has a different set of workforce. We've been -- I think, the contrast is that polyethylene unit's pretty much complete on time, on budget, as we've talked about in the second quarter of next year. The cracker, we've struggled a bit more. And really, the challenge now that we've risen to really as owners is to reorganize working with the contractor, the work front, put additional resources from the owners as well as CPChem on that to really improve that productivity. And so we're starting to see better progress here as a result of that, but that's really what's left is to finish the construction.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs is online with a question.
componenttext: Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get your perspective on the refined product macro as we're going into 2017. Specifically, any differentiation in thinking between gasoline and diesel and then also crude spreads as you see the market right now?
componenttext: I wanted to get your perspective on the refined product macro as we're going into 2017. Specifically, any differentiation in thinking between gasoline and diesel and then also crude spreads as you see the market right now?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neil, this is Tim. I think, fundamentally, we just look at the market. And I've seen -- recently, you've seen both crude and product inventories in the U.S. start to come down. That's encouraging, but it's got a long way to go would be our view. So w
componenttext: Yes, Neil, this is Tim. I think, fundamentally, we just look at the market. And I've seen -- recently, you've seen both crude and product inventories in the U.S. start to come down. That's encouraging, but it's got a long way to go would be our view. So we think that fundamentally keeps kind of a weaker outlook when you think about the product and the crude spread and the crack margin on the business. And the other comment I'd make is if you look at the forward curves, it's different than last year, you're seeing less carry. And so I think that if we readjust going into the fourth quarter, probably not as much incentive as there was last year to continue to produce the higher rates in the northern hemisphere is a seasonally weak time. So I think, going constructively, continue to get those inventories down is required, both on the crude and the products side to structurally change that. And then, I think, seasonally, you should expect that as the U.S. demand really, you look out, distillate looks pretty good right now in terms of carry, still not a strong crack. Gasoline weaker than it has been. And I think that reflects what we'd see as a seasonally normal driving season. And the real outlet piece of this is you get turnarounds right now, those come out, and then, you've got to turn to export markets to absorb the excess, or there will be some type of utilization decrease to balance the markets, but that's really what's required is more balancing.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Through your marketing arm, are you able to see what gasoline demand trends are looking like in the U.S. and any change in terms of the pace of demand growth?
componenttext: Through your marketing arm, are you able to see what gasoline demand trends are looking like in the U.S. and any change in terms of the pace of demand growth?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we look at our branded piece, and we're still seeing it at same site. We would say we're seeing that 2% to 3% year-on-year increase. So when you look at vehicle miles driven, all the indicators, some changes there, but generally still a pretty good d
componenttext: Yes, we look at our branded piece, and we're still seeing it at same site. We would say we're seeing that 2% to 3% year-on-year increase. So when you look at vehicle miles driven, all the indicators, some changes there, but generally still a pretty good demand picture on the gasoline side. So that's another piece that helps balance that long run is you've got to continue to have good demand growth to balance that. Maybe as an aside, we've actually seen similar patterns in Europe through our German retail operations or Central Europe operations. So it does -- it has been a response on the price side to demand really across the world.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, my follow-up is on capital spending. You guys indicated in the release that you're going to target below $3 billion in 2017. Can you provide an early look at what you see is changing 2016 to 2017 from a capital spending prospective, recognizing
componenttext: And then, my follow-up is on capital spending. You guys indicated in the release that you're going to target below $3 billion in 2017. Can you provide an early look at what you see is changing 2016 to 2017 from a capital spending prospective, recognizing that come December, we're going to get even more clarity?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think that -- I think, we'll finish this year right around $3 billion in 2016. And we're going to be -- we'll go to our board in December for approval of the capital budget. It's going to be somewhere between 2 5 and 2 9 at this point in time, N
componenttext: Yes, so I think that -- I think, we'll finish this year right around $3 billion in 2016. And we're going to be -- we'll go to our board in December for approval of the capital budget. It's going to be somewhere between 2 5 and 2 9 at this point in time, Neil. We deferred investment in frac, too. And so that's a piece of what we're seeing. And then, we're just finishing up the big projects. And so there's -- given the uncertainty in the markets and everything that's going on, we're pivoting to smaller projects, so that's actually positive in my view because if we need to make adjustments to capital next year, we can. So we don't have these long run committed projects we have to follow through and invest in. So I think, we feel good about the 2017 capital program. We've got some good projects in there that we want to execute. And obviously, our full attention right now is on commissioning and starting up this LPG export facility. But we'll load cargoes next month actually.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil is online with a question.
componenttext: Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe this is the last call before year-end, so I'm not sure if Clayton's on the line or not, but I just like to thank him and wish him and his family well. Greg, my question is on DAPL. I see the commentary about potentially still expected first quar
componenttext: I believe this is the last call before year-end, so I'm not sure if Clayton's on the line or not, but I just like to thank him and wish him and his family well. Greg, my question is on DAPL. I see the commentary about potentially still expected first quarter start. Obviously, looking at the news headlines, that could prove ambitious. Could you have maybe just some commentary around that? And assuming there is a deferral, is it fair to think that, really, the only impact is simply deferring the EBITDA? I mean, obviously, your costs would slow and no other impact on other operations?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's accurate. It may slip a little bit. And I think, we're still optimistic, I would say, that we'll get this resolved. There's -- the work is continuing except for about, I don't know, a couple of miles actually. So there's not that much l
componenttext: No, I think that's accurate. It may slip a little bit. And I think, we're still optimistic, I would say, that we'll get this resolved. There's -- the work is continuing except for about, I don't know, a couple of miles actually. So there's not that much left to be finished once we get the easement to go underneath the Missouri River. So I think that can be wrapped up in relative short order. Obviously, we need to go ahead to get started on that. And we just -- we would expect that we'll get that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Secondly, buybacks were still healthy, but rolled over a bit quarter to quarter. And obviously, we did have the drop in this quarter. So I'm just curious, for one, should we think about this new liquidity coming in to help kind of support buybacks g
componenttext: Okay. Secondly, buybacks were still healthy, but rolled over a bit quarter to quarter. And obviously, we did have the drop in this quarter. So I'm just curious, for one, should we think about this new liquidity coming in to help kind of support buybacks going into next year? And do you have a net cash amount that you're expecting to receive from the -- I think it was a $1.3 billion total drop?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, buybacks, we've always guided to $1 billion to $2 billion, I think. Certainly, for this year, we'll be towards the lower end of that range, and we'll see what happens. But remember, we cut CapEx from $3.9 billion to $3 billion this year. And we w
componenttext: I think, buybacks, we've always guided to $1 billion to $2 billion, I think. Certainly, for this year, we'll be towards the lower end of that range, and we'll see what happens. But remember, we cut CapEx from $3.9 billion to $3 billion this year. And we were kind of targeting a $1.5 billion-ish, $1.6 billion-ish this year. And so, if we come in closer to the lower end of range, we'll do share repurchases, not as much, but still a significant amount. But I still think that $1 billion to $2 billion is good guidance for 2017 as we look at our balances and what we think we're going to do.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Blake, this is Kevin. On the drop, so it's a $1.3 billion drop, $200 million of that was take back units, so no cash effect. The other $1.1 billion was funded with cash, so debt offering by PSXP that's then used to pay for the bulk of the drop transaction
componenttext: Blake, this is Kevin. On the drop, so it's a $1.3 billion drop, $200 million of that was take back units, so no cash effect. The other $1.1 billion was funded with cash, so debt offering by PSXP that's then used to pay for the bulk of the drop transaction.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Kevin, there's no tax leakage or anything we need to be aware of there?
componenttext: But Kevin, there's no tax leakage or anything we need to be aware of there?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank is online with a question.
componenttext: Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could, one question on the Midstream. I mean, earlier this year, you took down the Midstream EBITDA guidance for 2018 10% to 20%, driven primarily by current market environment. Can you run through what were the biggest drivers of the reduction
componenttext: Maybe if I could, one question on the Midstream. I mean, earlier this year, you took down the Midstream EBITDA guidance for 2018 10% to 20%, driven primarily by current market environment. Can you run through what were the biggest drivers of the reduction, what the assumed commodity environment was? And on the flip side, relative to that assumption, the potential for any of that to come back as oil price and other commodities potentially recover?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes Ryan, this is Tim Taylor. The primary driver on the -- we gave 20% to 30% off than what we had thought originally in the 2018 run rate. Most of that was the commodity. And the primary variance would be the arb on the LPG exports that we were expecting
componenttext: Yes Ryan, this is Tim Taylor. The primary driver on the -- we gave 20% to 30% off than what we had thought originally in the 2018 run rate. Most of that was the commodity. And the primary variance would be the arb on the LPG exports that we were expecting at the time when -- back when crude was toward $100. And so as that's come off, that's really narrowed that arb. And so that's a piece of that. So your view on energy going forward is really important when you think about what's the LPG price in the U.S. and what's the alternative values around the world. So I think that if your view on energy strengthens, then that should widen those arbs out, but that's essentially the biggest driver. And then, that was where most of the commodity exposure came.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible]
componenttext: [indiscernible]

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, the other part of the reduction is we did deferred frac, too, the condensate pipe from the Eagle Ford, and those were essentially fee-based earnings, but that was not commodity exposed. The bulk of that reduction related to that commodity.
componenttext: And then, the other part of the reduction is we did deferred frac, too, the condensate pipe from the Eagle Ford, and those were essentially fee-based earnings, but that was not commodity exposed. The bulk of that reduction related to that commodity.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, maybe just a follow-up on the last question on the drop, the recent drop you did with PSXP. I mean, it was a very large drop. And there was, as you highlighted, attractively structured from your point of view in terms of the cash proceeds.
componenttext: Okay. And then, maybe just a follow-up on the last question on the drop, the recent drop you did with PSXP. I mean, it was a very large drop. And there was, as you highlighted, attractively structured from your point of view in terms of the cash proceeds. Any thoughts as you look forward in terms of just general commentary on ongoing health of the recovery of that market in terms of the ability of PSXP to fund kind of the foreseeable future drop program?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, we demonstrated we can access the capital markets in 2016. That's kind of the pace we need to be at to achieve the $1.1 billion level by 2018, at least run rate EBITDA by 2018. So I think, we're confident that we can execute the plan, that the ma
componenttext: I think, we demonstrated we can access the capital markets in 2016. That's kind of the pace we need to be at to achieve the $1.1 billion level by 2018, at least run rate EBITDA by 2018. So I think, we're confident that we can execute the plan, that the markets will be there for us. So just beyond that, we like the profile we have with the master limited partnership. We like the backlog of projects that we're constructing. We like existing EBITDA that's still left, that's droppable. So I just -- I look at all of that and say that $1.1 billion is really doable.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul Cheng from Barclays is online with a question.
componenttext: Paul Cheng from Barclays is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, several questions. First, Tim, the European, Asian refining margin, we have seen some very strong counter-seasonal uptick in March and over the last 3 months. Curious that what you guys see on the ground in your European operation? Is it demand-drive
componenttext: Tim, several questions. First, Tim, the European, Asian refining margin, we have seen some very strong counter-seasonal uptick in March and over the last 3 months. Curious that what you guys see on the ground in your European operation? Is it demand-driven? Or it's because of some supply outage or anything?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I alluded to earlier, we've seen pretty good demand when we look at Europe. The demand growth there and the crude dips have certainly improved their competitive position. So when we look at, for instance, at Humber, we see it's much more competit
componenttext: Well, as I alluded to earlier, we've seen pretty good demand when we look at Europe. The demand growth there and the crude dips have certainly improved their competitive position. So when we look at, for instance, at Humber, we see it's much more competitive than it was, say, when the [indiscernible] in the U.S. So I think it reflects opportunities to continue to export out of Europe more competitive cost basis. And then, we've seen relatively good demand there. And in Asia, we've seen recent strengthening, whether it be in chemicals or even in the fuels business. So it feels like Asia seems to be on the upswing. And the kinds of markets on the transportation side for instance and consumer markets, we're seeing that same kind of thing that's helped pull that through. And we had a fairly high turnaround season, I think, in China, and that's coming back. So I think that, that supply may impact that. But generally, Asia feels better than it did probably 3 or 4 months ago.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Because it feels like that market may be underestimating the demand on the global basis. Secondly, just curious, with the IMO 2020 bunker fuel switch, is there any [indiscernible] that would change the way how you run your refinery in Europe, Bayway
componenttext: Yes. Because it feels like that market may be underestimating the demand on the global basis. Secondly, just curious, with the IMO 2020 bunker fuel switch, is there any [indiscernible] that would change the way how you run your refinery in Europe, Bayway and the Gulf Coast system?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We've looked -- it really doesn't feel like that. I mean, I think, you always got to think about the incremental values. But really, as a system and the way we look at competitiveness, when you still see that European, north and eastern U.S. as one of
componenttext: No. We've looked -- it really doesn't feel like that. I mean, I think, you always got to think about the incremental values. But really, as a system and the way we look at competitiveness, when you still see that European, north and eastern U.S. as one of the more challenged market areas. But I think it fundamentally has not changed the way that we look at the business on that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you will not need to say adjust because the high sulfur, we see the demand would be dramatically lower. And you've gone to pick up the lower sulfur gas oil demand. So you don't believe that, that will lead you to -- may have to adjust the way how you r
componenttext: So you will not need to say adjust because the high sulfur, we see the demand would be dramatically lower. And you've gone to pick up the lower sulfur gas oil demand. So you don't believe that, that will lead you to -- may have to adjust the way how you run it?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, sulfur continues to tighten over time. We've seen sufficient markets that take some of the higher sulfur products, But that's diminished and people continue to invest that, Paul. But I think that's more gradual conversion. There still seems
componenttext: Well, I think, sulfur continues to tighten over time. We've seen sufficient markets that take some of the higher sulfur products, But that's diminished and people continue to invest that, Paul. But I think that's more gradual conversion. There still seems to be a plenty large enough market sink out there to absorb that, even as I've made the adjustments in the marine part of the business, et cetera, to manage that, through blending or through other markets that can come absorb that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And based on your -- the current fourth quarter estimate on the turnaround, so your full year turnaround expense will be probably slightly below $500 million, a bit lower than at the beginning of the year when you initially forecast. Is that driven
componenttext: Okay. And based on your -- the current fourth quarter estimate on the turnaround, so your full year turnaround expense will be probably slightly below $500 million, a bit lower than at the beginning of the year when you initially forecast. Is that driven by delay of activity? Postponement of activity? Or just the work has been done more effectively? In other words, just trying to understand whether that's [indiscernible] activity that we should expect from you guys in 2017?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's mostly push on expenditure into future periods, both on turnaround and also [indiscernible] expense, Paul. I will give an update on where we expect 2017 to be coming in next call [indiscernible]
componenttext: So it's mostly push on expenditure into future periods, both on turnaround and also [indiscernible] expense, Paul. I will give an update on where we expect 2017 to be coming in next call [indiscernible]

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So some of them that we should expect is going to show up in 2017, Kevin?
componenttext: So some of them that we should expect is going to show up in 2017, Kevin?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right, yes.
componenttext: That's right, yes.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, a final one, Kevin, since I got you here. As a company, what is your overall strategy that over the next several years, as you continue to drop down in the organic investment in the LP level, so LP debt is going up, so we assume as the LP
componenttext: Okay. And then, a final one, Kevin, since I got you here. As a company, what is your overall strategy that over the next several years, as you continue to drop down in the organic investment in the LP level, so LP debt is going up, so we assume as the LP debt going up, you would want to accommodate it by lower your C corp debt, so that your overall consolidated would be more or less flat or even going down? Or that you think that, okay, I mean, C corp is C corp, LP is LP, so you don't look at them together?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do look at them together, Paul. And I think, you're right on there in terms of your initial lead-in comment that, over time, certainly, the LP, that is going to increase. And of course, we just done the $1.1 billion. And while it won't have an imm
componenttext: Yes, we do look at them together, Paul. And I think, you're right on there in terms of your initial lead-in comment that, over time, certainly, the LP, that is going to increase. And of course, we just done the $1.1 billion. And while it won't have an immediate offset at the C corp, over time, you can expect that the C corp should start to delever if you look at the C corp. on a stand-alone basis.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on that basis then, I mean, given Greg earlier talking about the volatility in the market uncertainties, should the company or the industry actually even take a more conservative approach and start benefiting yourselves?
componenttext: And on that basis then, I mean, given Greg earlier talking about the volatility in the market uncertainties, should the company or the industry actually even take a more conservative approach and start benefiting yourselves?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've always guided that we're going to stay between 20% and 30% debt to cap. And so we may drift over that just a little bit at one point in time. We're going to try to stay very disciplined within that band, Paul. And it's probably not a bad time
componenttext: Well, we've always guided that we're going to stay between 20% and 30% debt to cap. And so we may drift over that just a little bit at one point in time. We're going to try to stay very disciplined within that band, Paul. And it's probably not a bad time to build some cash, too, as you think about that going forward.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger Read from Wells Fargo is online with a question.
componenttext: Roger Read from Wells Fargo is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I guess, 2 things here. One is a follow-up on Blake's question about DAPL. Are there any seasonal concerns if we don't get started sooner rather than later that you can't do the construction work out there?
componenttext: Hey, I guess, 2 things here. One is a follow-up on Blake's question about DAPL. Are there any seasonal concerns if we don't get started sooner rather than later that you can't do the construction work out there?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that we'll be able to do the drill and do what we need to do.
componenttext: No, I think that we'll be able to do the drill and do what we need to do.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, essentially, you're preparing -- you're doing ditch work when the weather is fine. So the drill is not really that impacted from a weather standpoint.
componenttext: Yes, essentially, you're preparing -- you're doing ditch work when the weather is fine. So the drill is not really that impacted from a weather standpoint.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Perfect. And then, a little more on the sort of the Midstream with changing in the overall CapEx structure and total plans and, let's just say, some change in the ownership structure of one of your JV partners, how do you think about M&A in the Mids
componenttext: Okay. Perfect. And then, a little more on the sort of the Midstream with changing in the overall CapEx structure and total plans and, let's just say, some change in the ownership structure of one of your JV partners, how do you think about M&A in the Midstream sector? I mean, generally speaking, when things start tighten up and slowdown, cash gets a little harder to get, then M&A should pick up. And I guess, we have seen that somewhat in the MLP sector that controls most of those assets. How do you look at M&A opportunities and what is your appetite for that sort of thing right now?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, we kind of look -- like everyone, we look at everything that's out there. I think, our assessment is the values are still relatively high, aspirational levels are high. We did 3 smaller transactions at PSXP level in the quarter. Or I guess, one w
componenttext: I think, we kind of look -- like everyone, we look at everything that's out there. I think, our assessment is the values are still relatively high, aspirational levels are high. We did 3 smaller transactions at PSXP level in the quarter. Or I guess, one will close in this quarter. But -- so I think that we'll look at everything that's out there, Roger. There's nothing big that I see at this point on the horizon for us. We still have a great organic portfolio of opportunities to invest in. It still makes sense for us to invest at a 6 or 7 bill multiple and trade that up versus paying 15x or 20x or something out there.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question was along the lines if you're personally a little less interested in scaling in the larger projects, are you seeing any change in the value of those larger projects that are already in existence? Or they just remain at very high multi
componenttext: I guess, my question was along the lines if you're personally a little less interested in scaling in the larger projects, are you seeing any change in the value of those larger projects that are already in existence? Or they just remain at very high multiples?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- our view is we haven't seen the valuations come down. I'm kind of a view right now that I think Permian is going to be more challenging in the future than it's been in the past and that existing assets, particularly pipe, is probably goin
componenttext: I don't think -- our view is we haven't seen the valuations come down. I'm kind of a view right now that I think Permian is going to be more challenging in the future than it's been in the past and that existing assets, particularly pipe, is probably going to be more valuable in the future than it is today.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So wouldn't that argue to make an acquisition today?
componenttext: So wouldn't that argue to make an acquisition today?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, probably so, if you can find the right acquisition. But the same thing, I think, we still have the ability to grow our portfolio, to hit our targets that we've laid out there for folks. And I feel comfortable we've got that opportunity portfolio in f
componenttext: Yes, probably so, if you can find the right acquisition. But the same thing, I think, we still have the ability to grow our portfolio, to hit our targets that we've laid out there for folks. And I feel comfortable we've got that opportunity portfolio in front of us well in hand.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Spiro Dounis from UBS securities is online with a question.
componenttext: Spiro Dounis from UBS securities is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just I just want to follow-up on the previous comment. I think, you mentioned potentially utilization rates coming down, or I mean, what sounded like maybe run cuts might be necessary. And I think, Valero mentioned earlier in the week that you could see s
componenttext: Just I just want to follow-up on the previous comment. I think, you mentioned potentially utilization rates coming down, or I mean, what sounded like maybe run cuts might be necessary. And I think, Valero mentioned earlier in the week that you could see some run cuts down the Mid-Con. Just from a seasonal basis, that might actually need to happen. Curious if you sort of view the same way, and maybe you see other regions that are may be more at risk of a run cut than others heading into the end of the year?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take a stab at it and Taylor can correct me maybe. As I think about it, inventories are high through the chain. And certainly, they're coming down in the U.S., which is constructive. But I would say that in turnarounds, when we come out of turnaround
componenttext: I'll take a stab at it and Taylor can correct me maybe. As I think about it, inventories are high through the chain. And certainly, they're coming down in the U.S., which is constructive. But I would say that in turnarounds, when we come out of turnarounds, typically, we tend to run better. And so you've got that as an offset. But I do think the industry's looking at some run cuts in the fourth quarter. And given the carry that's out there, we're not going to be incented to run like we did in the fourth quarter of last year. So I don't think we're going to repeat that problem again. So I think you'll see. I think light sweet crude refineries are going to be challenged. I think, Mid-Con is going to be challenged. If you look at the crack stay in Mid-Con, they're not that great. So I think, folks are just going to have to look at that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think it is the light sweet is a real push, real pinched. The heavy sour, medium sour, that's really -- you've got that capacity. That's what's going to -- that's the most competitive. And then, the Mid-Con, it's very seasonal, right? In the su
componenttext: Yes. No, I think it is the light sweet is a real push, real pinched. The heavy sour, medium sour, that's really -- you've got that capacity. That's what's going to -- that's the most competitive. And then, the Mid-Con, it's very seasonal, right? In the summer, it goes short, winter goes long. So I think that's a place where you see the light sweet and the balance come into play there. And you're seeing the market kind of respond to data to well-supplied markets. So I think, it's the usual things around Atlantic Basin and just that light sweet complex that's out there with the crude side with narrow differentials.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Second question, just modeling, a bit of a two-parter here. So when I think of it as there were some unplanned downtime at CPChem in the third quarter, just wondering if that lead into fourth quarter, or was it ring fenced? And then, just along mo
componenttext: Got it. Second question, just modeling, a bit of a two-parter here. So when I think of it as there were some unplanned downtime at CPChem in the third quarter, just wondering if that lead into fourth quarter, or was it ring fenced? And then, just along modeling line of things, as far as EBITDA contribution from the LPG terminal, it sounds like maybe it will hit in the fourth quarter a bit. How should we expect the ramp-up to get to that full run rate? Should we -- is that all going to be in 1Q? Or will it be maybe throughout the first half of '17?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So On Chemicals in terms of utilization, we have 2 major crackers in turnaround right now. One in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Polymers company, and the second is the Cedar Bayou cracker. And so those continued through roughly half the quarter, so that's the g
componenttext: So On Chemicals in terms of utilization, we have 2 major crackers in turnaround right now. One in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Polymers company, and the second is the Cedar Bayou cracker. And so those continued through roughly half the quarter, so that's the guidance down is primarily the planned turnaround there. And so that was the -- that's a big -- that's the change from -- to the guidance in the mid-90 -- or the mid-80s. On the LPG, we'll begin loading. You've got to go through the qualification and the cleanup, the start up. And so I think, our view is it ramps through the first couple of quarters through next year. But hopefully, we can accelerate that. But I think, the volume piece of that comes -- depends on how quickly the operations stabilize and we can get that on and running.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets is online with a question.
componenttext: Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I was wondering if we could go back to a comment that you made earlier in the call, which is, I think, you said you'd expect the business to generate $5 billion in cash flow sort of on a cycle average basis. I also noted that the commentary around t
componenttext: Greg, I was wondering if we could go back to a comment that you made earlier in the call, which is, I think, you said you'd expect the business to generate $5 billion in cash flow sort of on a cycle average basis. I also noted that the commentary around the current refining market hasn't seemed particularly bullish to me, and so I'm wondering how you reconciled those 2 things? And what makes you think that the cash flow picture next year is going to look significantly better than it did this year, if that is what you think?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, it will be better next year. I'm not sure we're going to get all the way back to mid-cycle. I think, it's going to be into the second half of '17 before you see kind of the inventory corrected. Even though it's going the right direction today, I
componenttext: I think, it will be better next year. I'm not sure we're going to get all the way back to mid-cycle. I think, it's going to be into the second half of '17 before you see kind of the inventory corrected. Even though it's going the right direction today, I think, it's going to take a while to work through that. And so, I think, it will be the back half of the year before we see margin improvement in the Refining business.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there's always a seasonal impact, right?
componenttext: And there's always a seasonal impact, right?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fourth and the first quarter are typically weaker with a stronger driving season. So if the inventories stay in balance, it kind of sets up for that. So there is the inherent seasonality cycle that comes on the Refining side. But I think, generally, o
componenttext: The fourth and the first quarter are typically weaker with a stronger driving season. So if the inventories stay in balance, it kind of sets up for that. So there is the inherent seasonality cycle that comes on the Refining side. But I think, generally, our view would be that probably a bit below mid-cycle, but hopefully better with a stronger summer season next year.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Sure. I guess, maybe ask this slightly different way, have your thoughts on when mid-cycle is changed at all, given what we've seen in 2016?
componenttext: Okay. Sure. I guess, maybe ask this slightly different way, have your thoughts on when mid-cycle is changed at all, given what we've seen in 2016?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no. Yes and no. I think, 2 years ago, we told you we thought that mid-cycle was probably $1 a barrel better because of the crude dips. I think, that's probably gone away. And so I'm kind of back to more of a normal mid-cycle in my own thinking in t
componenttext: Yes -- no. Yes and no. I think, 2 years ago, we told you we thought that mid-cycle was probably $1 a barrel better because of the crude dips. I think, that's probably gone away. And so I'm kind of back to more of a normal mid-cycle in my own thinking in terms of that. And just kind of rule of thumb, I kind of use between $2 and $2.50 a barrel net income as a good mid-cycle number for us.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. A then, a question on DCP. Obviously, you're having a partner change there. And so I was curious if you see that changing the way the partnership runs in any significant way? And also, if you like that as being a 50-50 JV? Or if somehow the other ha
componenttext: Okay. A then, a question on DCP. Obviously, you're having a partner change there. And so I was curious if you see that changing the way the partnership runs in any significant way? And also, if you like that as being a 50-50 JV? Or if somehow the other half of the partnership fell out as part of that process, if you would be interested in owning all of it?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is the third or the fourth partner change. I lose track. It's changed so many times in 16 years. But yes -- look, I think, it's a great company. We know them. They're going to be a terrific partner. I think we're happy with the model as it is. This i
componenttext: This is the third or the fourth partner change. I lose track. It's changed so many times in 16 years. But yes -- look, I think, it's a great company. We know them. They're going to be a terrific partner. I think we're happy with the model as it is. This is a long-standing partnership. It's survived a lot of different name changes. We like the assets. We like the footprint the DCP has in the areas that they're operating in. And they've had a great year just in terms of getting their house in order in terms of reducing their cost structure, point in the capital expenses and running much better. They're actually running well this year from a reliability standpoint. They've just done all the right things. It's a great asset. So we'd be very happy to stay in a 50-50 JV.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel Khan from Citigroup is online with a question.
componenttext: Faisel Khan from Citigroup is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Cedar Bayou project, Tim, I know you said the start-up sort of second half of next year, but are there certain parts of the plant that are going to start up before the main cracker comes online? Or how is the start-up going to be sort of sequenced?
componenttext: On the Cedar Bayou project, Tim, I know you said the start-up sort of second half of next year, but are there certain parts of the plant that are going to start up before the main cracker comes online? Or how is the start-up going to be sort of sequenced?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just to be clear, crackers at Cedar Bayou, the derivative polyethylene units are down at Sweeny, so 2 existing operations. So the polyethylene plants will be starting up in advance several months in front of the cracker. Now if you get to the crac
componenttext: Yes, so just to be clear, crackers at Cedar Bayou, the derivative polyethylene units are down at Sweeny, so 2 existing operations. So the polyethylene plants will be starting up in advance several months in front of the cracker. Now if you get to the cracker, you'll be starting up utility systems, steam, those kinds of things, energizing, but you really need the furnaces and the whole cracker in operation before you get to production. So it's really the issue of derivatives first, then the cracker. And within the cracker, there are a number of systems that start to come up in advance of the hydrocarbon in tube for the feed system.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. So the derivatives plant at Sweeny, you said several months ahead if you put that sometime in the first or second -- I guess, second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Got it. So the derivatives plant at Sweeny, you said several months ahead if you put that sometime in the first or second -- I guess, second quarter?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second quarter is what we -- looking at schedule and everything we're seeing, so that's still a good time for mechanical completion.
componenttext: Second quarter is what we -- looking at schedule and everything we're seeing, so that's still a good time for mechanical completion.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Makes sense. And then, on the partnership, is the preference still to build and then drop? I know you've got some organic growth projects taking place at the partnership, but I'm just trying to figure out how you're balancing sort of the build at th
componenttext: Okay. Makes sense. And then, on the partnership, is the preference still to build and then drop? I know you've got some organic growth projects taking place at the partnership, but I'm just trying to figure out how you're balancing sort of the build at the parent and then drop at partnership versus the organic growth of the partnership? Is there enough sort of internal cash flow generation at the partnership to fund all the growth?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel, when you think about the size of the MLP today, and it would be -- it's hard to carry a multiyear, multibillion dollar project there, even though it may make sense. So I think, as the partnerships get bigger, we're going to shift more and more of
componenttext: Faisel, when you think about the size of the MLP today, and it would be -- it's hard to carry a multiyear, multibillion dollar project there, even though it may make sense. So I think, as the partnerships get bigger, we're going to shift more and more of the CapEx to the partnership. And you've seen that this year with additional acquisitions, organic builds on the Bayou Bridge pipe, et cetera. So I think, that's the progression over time. But we kind of look at it as a total Midstream business and what's right way to drive a project that creates value for the company. And then, you can decide, if you will, the financing between the 2. But I think, longer term, we'd like to see the partnership doing more and more of that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as you think about the partnership in the long run, what percentage of the revenues do you think will come from third-parties sort of on that $2.3 billion number that you have out there? I think, in the past, you've talked about some of th
componenttext: Okay. And then, as you think about the partnership in the long run, what percentage of the revenues do you think will come from third-parties sort of on that $2.3 billion number that you have out there? I think, in the past, you've talked about some of the number close to 50% or maybe less than that, but I'm just trying to understand if that number has changed at all?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's still in that range. I mean, a lot of what we've done to date in the partnership has been existing systems that are really related to our infrastructure around our Refining and existing Midstream business. And as you go forward with -- as Phillip
componenttext: No, it's still in that range. I mean, a lot of what we've done to date in the partnership has been existing systems that are really related to our infrastructure around our Refining and existing Midstream business. And as you go forward with -- as Phillips 66 builds additional projects, some of the new things like the Bayou Bridge pipe, DAPL, if it were to end up there, fractionation is through third-party. So that's where that shift begins to get where you start to drive it up when you have a more balanced portfolio between internal PSX and third-party income that's in the Midstream in the MLP space.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. On the Refining side, the -- have you gotten any more traction on the rail facility at Santa Maria, especially with the Plains Pipeline still down? Have you been able to sort of solve the feedstock issue there to sort of get your capture ra
componenttext: Okay. Got you. On the Refining side, the -- have you gotten any more traction on the rail facility at Santa Maria, especially with the Plains Pipeline still down? Have you been able to sort of solve the feedstock issue there to sort of get your capture rate so your realization is back to where they should be?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still impacted in the West Coast with the Plains Pipeline outage is not -- we've made progress through getting more crude incrementally into the Santa Maria via truck, but not via rail. That's been a very difficult permitting process. So we continue
componenttext: We're still impacted in the West Coast with the Plains Pipeline outage is not -- we've made progress through getting more crude incrementally into the Santa Maria via truck, but not via rail. That's been a very difficult permitting process. So we continue to work that, but it's all over the West Coast. Any type of rail facility has really struggled from that permitting process. So we really need the pipe back in operation and we'll continue to work that incrementally, but it's still an impact in terms of our West Coast operations, the reduction that we're seeing, say, roughly 10,000, 15,000 barrels a day of incremental capacity. That's still a burden, so to speak, because we can't fully utilize Rodeo-Santa Maria system.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a situation where you got to shut down one of the plants? Or are you still comfortable sort of running the whole system the way it is?
componenttext: Is there a situation where you got to shut down one of the plants? Or are you still comfortable sort of running the whole system the way it is?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, longer term, you always have to look at that. But right now, we still think it will eventually get that supply back, it's just a question of when. So we want to run that as a system when we do that.
componenttext: Well, I think, longer term, you always have to look at that. But right now, we still think it will eventually get that supply back, it's just a question of when. So we want to run that as a system when we do that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Last question from me. Just on M&A related to refineries, is there ever a situation where you would consider buying a refinery in the Lower 48? I just wanted to ask question. I know, historically, it's been no. But since there are a few assets up
componenttext: Got you. Last question from me. Just on M&A related to refineries, is there ever a situation where you would consider buying a refinery in the Lower 48? I just wanted to ask question. I know, historically, it's been no. But since there are a few assets up for sale, I just want to ask the question again.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, the historical answer is still a good answer for us. We're not in the hunt for any ones that are for sale today. Having said that, if we could find the right asset for the right value, certainly, we would look at it. But none of the ones that
componenttext: So I think, the historical answer is still a good answer for us. We're not in the hunt for any ones that are for sale today. Having said that, if we could find the right asset for the right value, certainly, we would look at it. But none of the ones that are on the market today, we're not in the hunt for those.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have no further questions at this time. I will now turn the call back over to Rosy Zuklic.
componenttext: We have no further questions at this time. I will now turn the call back over to Rosy Zuklic.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Julie. And thank you all for your interest in Phillips 66. If anyone has any additional questions, please give C.W. or I a call. Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you, Julie. And thank you all for your interest in Phillips 66. If anyone has any additional questions, please give C.W. or I a call. Thank you.
