componenttextpreview: This is the third or the fourth partner change. I lose track. It's changed so many times in 16 years. But yes -- look, I think Enbridge is a great company. We know them. They're going to be a terrific partner. I think we're happy with the model as it is.
componenttext: This is the third or the fourth partner change. I lose track. It's changed so many times in 16 years. But yes -- look, I think Enbridge is a great company. We know them. They're going to be a terrific partner. I think we're happy with the model as it is. This is a long-standing partnership. It's survived a lot of different name changes. We like the assets. We like the footprint DCP has in the areas that they're operating in. And they've had a great year just in terms of getting their house in order in terms of reducing their cost structure, point in the capital expenses and running much better. They're actually running well this year from a reliability standpoint. So they've just done all the right things. It's a great asset. So we'd be very happy to stay in a 50-50 JV.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel Khan from Citigroup is online with a question.
componenttext: Faisel Khan from Citigroup is online with a question.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Cedar Bayou project, Tim, I know you said the start-up sort of second half of next year, but are there certain parts of the plant that are going to start up before the main cracker comes online? Or how is the start-up going to be sort of sequenced?
componenttext: On the Cedar Bayou project, Tim, I know you said the start-up sort of second half of next year, but are there certain parts of the plant that are going to start up before the main cracker comes online? Or how is the start-up going to be sort of sequenced?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just to be clear, the crackers at Cedar Bayou, the derivative polyethylene units are down at Sweeny, and so 2 existing operations. So the polyethylene plants will be starting up in advance several months in front of the cracker. Now, if you get to
componenttext: Yes, so just to be clear, the crackers at Cedar Bayou, the derivative polyethylene units are down at Sweeny, and so 2 existing operations. So the polyethylene plants will be starting up in advance several months in front of the cracker. Now, if you get to the cracker, you'll be starting up utility systems, steam, those kinds of things, energizing, but you really need the furnaces and the whole cracker in operation before you get to production. So it's really the issue of derivatives first, then the cracker. But within the cracker, there are a number of systems that start to come up in advance of the hydrocarbon end tube for the feed system.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. So the derivatives plant at Sweeny, you said several months ahead, if we put that sometime in the first or second -- I guess, second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Got it. So the derivatives plant at Sweeny, you said several months ahead, if we put that sometime in the first or second -- I guess, second quarter?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second quarter is what we -- looking at the schedule and everything we're seeing, so that's still a good time for mechanical completion.
componenttext: Second quarter is what we -- looking at the schedule and everything we're seeing, so that's still a good time for mechanical completion.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, makes sense. And then, on the partnership, is the preference still to build and then drop? I know you've got some organic growth projects taking place at the partnership, but I'm just trying to figure out how you're balancing sort of the build
componenttext: Okay. Okay, makes sense. And then, on the partnership, is the preference still to build and then drop? I know you've got some organic growth projects taking place at the partnership, but I'm just trying to figure out how you're balancing sort of the build at the parent and then drop at partnership versus the organic growth of the partnership? Is there enough sort of internal cash flow generation at the partnership to fund all the growth?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel, when you think about the size of the MLP today, and it would be -- it's hard to carry a multiyear, multibillion dollar project there, even though it may make sense. So I think as the partnerships get bigger, we're going to shift more and more of t
componenttext: Faisel, when you think about the size of the MLP today, and it would be -- it's hard to carry a multiyear, multibillion dollar project there, even though it may make sense. So I think as the partnerships get bigger, we're going to shift more and more of the CapEx to the partnership. And you've seen that this year with additional acquisitions, organic builds on the Bayou Bridge pipe, et cetera. So I think that's the progression over time. But we tend to look at it as a total Midstream business and what's the right way to drive a project that creates value for the company. And then, you can decide, if you will, the financing between the 2. But I think, longer term, we'd like to see the partnership doing more and more of that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as you think about the partnership in the long run, what percentage of the revenues do you think will come from third-parties sort of on that $2.3 billion number that you have out there? I think, in the past, you've talked about sort of a
componenttext: Okay. And then, as you think about the partnership in the long run, what percentage of the revenues do you think will come from third-parties sort of on that $2.3 billion number that you have out there? I think, in the past, you've talked about sort of a number close to 50% or maybe less than that, but I'm just trying to understand if that number has changed at all?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's still in that range. I mean, a lot of what we've done to date in the partnership has been existing systems that are really related to our infrastructure around our Refining and existing Midstream business. And as you go forward with -- as Phillip
componenttext: No, it's still in that range. I mean, a lot of what we've done to date in the partnership has been existing systems that are really related to our infrastructure around our Refining and existing Midstream business. And as you go forward with -- as Phillips 66 builds additional projects, some of the new things like the Bayou Bridge pipe, DAPL, if it were to end up there, fractionation is through third party. So that's where that shift begins to get where you start to drive it up, where you have a more balanced portfolio between internal PSX and third-party income that's in the Midstream in the MLP space.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. On the Refining side, the -- have you gotten any more traction on the rail facility at Santa Maria? Especially with the Plains Pipeline still down, have you been able to sort of solve the feedstock issue there to sort of get your capture ra
componenttext: Okay. Got you. On the Refining side, the -- have you gotten any more traction on the rail facility at Santa Maria? Especially with the Plains Pipeline still down, have you been able to sort of solve the feedstock issue there to sort of get your capture rate so your realization is back to where they should be?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still impacted in the West Coast with the Plains Pipeline outage. It's not -- we've made progress through getting more crude incrementally into Santa Maria via truck, but not via rail. That's been a very difficult permitting process. So we continue
componenttext: We're still impacted in the West Coast with the Plains Pipeline outage. It's not -- we've made progress through getting more crude incrementally into Santa Maria via truck, but not via rail. That's been a very difficult permitting process. So we continue to work that, but it's all over the West Coast. Any type of rail facility has really struggled from that permitting process. So we really need the pipe back in operation and we'll continue to work that incrementally, but it's still an impact in terms of our West Coast operations, the reduction that we're seeing, say, roughly 10,000, 15,000 barrels a day of incremental capacity. That's still a burden, so to speak, because we can't fully utilize our Rodeo-Santa Maria system.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there ever a situation where you're going to have to shut down one of the plants? Or are you still comfortable sort of running the whole system the way it is?
componenttext: Is there ever a situation where you're going to have to shut down one of the plants? Or are you still comfortable sort of running the whole system the way it is?

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, longer term, you always have to look at that. But right now, we still think we'll eventually get that supply back, it's just a question of when. So we'd want to run that as a system when we do that.
componenttext: Well, I think, longer term, you always have to look at that. But right now, we still think we'll eventually get that supply back, it's just a question of when. So we'd want to run that as a system when we do that.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Last question from me, just on M&A related to refineries. Is there ever a situation where you would consider buying a refinery in the Lower 48? I just wanted to ask question. I know, historically, it's been no. But since there are a few assets up
componenttext: Got you. Last question from me, just on M&A related to refineries. Is there ever a situation where you would consider buying a refinery in the Lower 48? I just wanted to ask question. I know, historically, it's been no. But since there are a few assets up for sale, I just want to ask the question again.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think the historical answer is still a good answer for us. We're not in the hunt for any of the ones that are for sale today. Having said that, if we could find the right asset for the right value, certainly, we would look at it. But none of the ones
componenttext: So I think the historical answer is still a good answer for us. We're not in the hunt for any of the ones that are for sale today. Having said that, if we could find the right asset for the right value, certainly, we would look at it. But none of the ones that are on the market today, we're not in the hunt for those.

headline: Phillips 66, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
